"Look here, it's no good!" said my Dad. We were in the car going back to London. My father, with my brother Maurice, had just picked me up from my school. I had won the Latin prize and the prize for doing best in my exams. My father talked with my headteacher, and now we were going home for the holidays.
"What isn't?" I asked, though I knew what he was thinking. My father usually talked a lot. "You can't fool me. You'll do what you want now," he said. "With all those certificates, I was told you will get a scholarship to Oxford."
"So?" I said, trying to be brave. "Mightn't that be useful?"
"I also heard," he continued, "that you want to be a barrister. A barrister of all things!" My father knew a lot about barristers and the law.
"I just said that," I replied. "I couldn't think of anything else to say!"
"And apparently," he went on, "you have the right personality - you can understand things quickly, you talk well, and you like performing."
"I don't know about that," I said. "I only know what I see on TV."
"Anyway," he said, "I feel you won't want to be in the family business now. You'll go to Oxford, and after that, I can't see you wanting it."
Like many children, I felt trapped by family expectations. I wanted to explore other jobs. But I didn't want to upset my father. I wasn't as scared of him as Maurice was - I was the favorite - but I found him strong.
"It's too soon to know," I said weakly.
"I tell you, you're not going to want to join us," said my father, who was often right, "and it's a pity because you've got the gifts - the brains, the nerves, the vision."
"There's still Maurice," I said, unhappy. My father snorted. We both knew Maurice hated the business.
"Anyway," I continued, "you could always use me as a consultant."
My mother wasn't around to help - she died when I was young, and my father raised me and Maurice. Maurice was two years younger, and I often took care of him. I loved Maurice. Because the business was successful, we lived well - a big house in London, good schools, nice clothes, parties, theatres, operas. My father knew many people - politicians, actors, businessmen - and our house was always lively.
"I tell you what," my father said. "You can help us during holidays until you leave Oxford, and then decide. It will give you some pocket money and help me."
"OK," I said, happy to avoid making a decision. My father would get upset if I opposed him. This was how he controlled us.
So it happened. In my last term at school, and during university vacations, I helped out, never more than twice a year, and always on easy tasks. I became a smart student, with a little house, a small white car, designer clothes, and a black dress from Paris for my final exams.
In my last term, my father visited me. He took me to a village for a meal and a chat. There were only a few weeks left. My tutor said I would get a First Class degree in Law. I felt confident and focused.
But my father told me he needed me for one last job, the most important for the family business. He promised it would be worth it.
"But Dad," I protested, "I have my final exams soon, and I need to focus. It's really important."
I could tell my father didn't understand my pressures, or maybe he was jealous of my life away from him. He would see a refusal as a betrayal.
As he explained the job, I saw his dedication and energy. He was a sort of genius, and I respected that. It made my own plans seem less important.
"All right," I said. "I'll do it."

Simon Costello realized that buying the house in Pembroke Square was a mistake within a year of moving in with his wife, Lois. They could only afford it by being very careful with money. At first, it seemed like a good idea because Simon had many successful cases, and Lois had returned to her job at the advertising agency with a higher salary. Lois wanted to move because their flat was too small for a family, and they needed more space and a garden. They could have found a bigger place in a less expensive area, but Lois wanted a better address. She felt their old address wasn't good enough for a young lawyer and a successful businesswoman.
To save money, Lois decided one of them should use public transport. Since her job was far away, Simon had to take the crowded tube, which made him unhappy. He often thought about his grandfather's house in Hampstead, where he was treated well after a long day at work. But times had changed, and Lois made it clear that her career was as important as his. They needed both their salaries to maintain their lifestyle.
Now, their situation was at risk because of Venetia. She came to their office upset and accused Simon of knowing that a client, Brian Cartwright, had bribed a jury four years ago. She also said Cartwright gave shares to Simon's fiancée before the trial. Simon denied it, but his denial didn't sound convincing. He felt guilty and remembered being punished as a child. Venetia didn't believe him, and he worried about what she might do. If the rumor spread, his career could be ruined.

I chose this place to live because I thought I could be anonymous. I hoped people here wouldn't care if the houses looked old and the gardens were messy. But I was wrong. People in the shops soon start to recognize you. The roses next door remind me that the gardens were once loved. Usually, I stay inside, but tonight, I am watching the birds fly. I made space for a chair in the garden, and my arms are scratched from cutting plants. It's a small London garden. My neighbor, Jaz, leans out of the window. She writes books that aren't published, and I sometimes talk about them because I am an English teacher. I have her latest book now. 'How's the work going, Jaz?' I ask. 'In no other job do people ask you about your work all the time,' she says. 'I'll bring a drink down.' I don't want Jaz in the garden, and I see it looks messy. The only way to the garden is through my flat, and Jaz is knocking on my door. 'You're on holiday now,' she says. She sits on the chair while I put a cushion on the grass. 'Cheers,' she says. 'I should've been a teacher - writers don't have holidays. They say, those who can, do, those who can't, teach.' And some can't do either. 'What plans for the holidays?' she asks. I feel worried about the school year ending. Empty days. Hot streets. The walk to the shops. The park with its fountain, and feeling lonely. 'I'm going to Stonebridge tomorrow. Can you feed the cats?' I ask. 'Of course,' Jaz says. 'If I'm around,' knowing she will be. 'Where will you stay?' 'With my friend Ruby at the Rising Sun. We've known each other since we were eight.' It's not true, but I often deal with fiction. 'Going back to your roots. What do you think of my book?' Jaz asks. Her book, The Cruelty of Red Vans, is on my desk. I like the title and tell her. I can see how red vans could be cruel, bringing gifts to other houses and returned manuscripts to hers. I decide to be honest. 'Try writing about nice people for a change,' I say. 'Teachers!' Jaz says, upset. 'I keep a journal where I write something good about each day,' I say. 'Keep a journal! Nice people! Get a life, Ann.' I have a life. I have my work, and I go out sometimes. When we go inside, my kitchen feels calm. Then I remember my school geography teacher, Miss Tarrantine, who was about my age, winking and saying, 'I've had my moments.' We almost died laughing.

**Heritage**
Heritage is important because it connects people with the past. We often feel connected to our personal heritage, like knowing about our grandparents and their stories. But we also need to learn about our wider past to understand our future. Heritage gives us a sense of belonging and continuity. Just like we inherit genes, we also inherit culture from past generations. Even if there are parts of our heritage we don't like, it is still ours. Heritage teaches us a lot and is important for our well-being. It affects our customs and traditions. In the past, we learned about our heritage through stories from our ancestors. But now, because of changes in society, many of these stories are lost. Instead, we learn from places and buildings that remind us of the past. It is important to keep these links to honor our ancestors.
**The Fens**
I wrote a book called "Waterland" about a place in England called the Fens. At first, I thought the Fens were just flat and empty, a good setting for my story. But I learned that the Fens are not just flat or empty. They are very English but also strange and mysterious. Many people in England find the Fens different from other places. The Fens are both wild and cultivated, open yet mysterious. I didn't visit many places in the Fens while writing my book. As a fiction writer, I like to imagine places rather than just describe them. The Fens are not just a landscape; they are also a state of mind.
**Museums**
Museums should make their collections easy to see and understand. In the past, museums just put things in cases with long labels. Now, displays should be interesting and use creative ways to catch people's attention. Museums should also reach out to the community. For example, they can lend objects to schools or use them to help elderly people with memory loss. Museums show real objects, not copies. They help people see and understand things from the past. This is what makes them different from theme parks or books. Museums that make their displays exciting and accessible will attract more visitors.
**Architecture and Environment**
People have always wanted to keep things from the past, but now changes in our towns happen very quickly. This makes some people want to preserve things more. People who have lived through big events, like wars, often want to keep things stable. If people need preservation, city planners should consider it. Change is not bad if we know how to manage it. Changes in our towns show changes in our society, like how many people live there and what they need.

**Einstein**
If you ask someone to name a scientist, they will probably say Albert Einstein. His face is used to sell smart products like computers and books. Many people do not know much about what Einstein did, except that he made some difficult theories called 'relativity'. These theories are famous for being hard to understand and for making strange predictions. Einstein was part of a big change in science in the 20th century. Scientists were trying to understand the universe better by studying matter and forces. Einstein helped by looking at time, space, matter, and energy in a new way. Before, people thought time and space were the same for everyone, but Einstein said they are different for each person.
**Young Readers**
When we were children, Lydia and I did not like prize-winning books because we thought they were boring. Our mother did not like this, but our father would give us money to read these books. He also gave us some good books as gifts, saying they were not just literature. We thought most of these books were for boys, but we did read some short stories and a book of poems.
**Language**
In 1851, Jacob Grimm said that the start of human language is a big mystery. Many strange ideas have come from this mystery. In 1928, Charles Caller said early humans made sounds like "meuh" when they were scared. Some people thought these sounds became words like "malaria" for "fever" or "mors" for "death". Because of these strange ideas, many people did not talk about the origin of language. But now, it is an important research area. Language probably started in East Africa about 100,000 years ago. It was mainly used for friendly talking and power struggles, not just for sharing information.

'Writing Reviews Frank Kermode talks about how to write reviews. Reviews are often written quickly and are not kept for long. They have deadlines and are usually short. Once published, they are only read for a short time, like a day or a week. People often think reviews are not important. Many believe writers do reviews because they need money or because they can't work on their main projects all the time. But writing reviews is a skill. It is different to write a short review for a newspaper and a long one for a journal. Reviewers must think about who will read their work, from casual readers to those very interested in the topic. A good reviewer knows a lot about many things and can write clearly. Reviewers often write other things too. For example, the American writer John Updike writes reviews when he is not working on his novels. He collects his reviews in books. Some people think only famous writers should keep their reviews, but others believe anyone can if they want to. I feel the same about my work. I am mainly an academic, and my serious books are for professors. In English-speaking countries, it is common for people to both review and study literature. In the past, some academics did not like professors writing reviews, but now it is more accepted. There are more reviews today, so many people can write them. I think this is good for readers because they know the reviewer understands the topic. It is also good for professors because it helps them communicate better with non-professors. Writing reviews is a secondary job. You can only do it well if you are also doing something else well.'

Ralph opened the door to his apartment. It was dark and quiet inside. Even after three years, he sometimes felt strange when he came home alone at the end of the day. When he first bought the apartment, he was excited to come home. He would wonder what the apartment was like while he was away. It felt like a welcoming place where he was in control. He thought he should worry about things like burglars or broken pipes, but the apartment was always there, waiting for him. Sometimes it looked neat, and other times it looked messy, depending on how he left it.
Over time, Ralph started to see the apartment as just another part of himself. It was a place where he could relax and be alone. He liked to see the letters by the door and the blinking light on the answering machine when he got home. He was glad nothing was broken or stolen. From his small office on the Holloway Road, Ralph often looked forward to his evenings at home. After leaving work, he felt more like himself on the bus ride home. He wanted to be alone with his things, but once he was home, he felt empty. He thought that working at a job he didn't like had changed him.
Ralph often read or listened to music at night. But he started to wonder why he did these things. He felt lost and confused. He remembered a time when he felt more in control of his life. After university, he wanted to make a plan for his future, but he only wanted to survive quietly. He applied for jobs he heard about from friends. He followed their paths, not thinking about his own happiness. He went to one job interview and was happy to have a nice talk with Neil, his boss. Neil offered him the job because Ralph was the only graduate who applied. At the time, Ralph thought this was a compliment.

**Goat Racing**
I was going to see goat racing. It was Easter Monday in Buccoo Village. There were many ice-cream vans, lots of people, food stalls, and loud music. Everyone was moving to the racecourse. I pushed through the crowd to find a good spot. A part of the area was marked for the race. It was not like big racecourses, but people stood on both sides of the track. They tried to keep some special goats in order. It was not easy because goats like to eat anything they find.
**Canoe Trip**
As the day ended, I thought about the night and felt scared. The canoe was too wet to sleep in, and there was no place to stop. We had not seen any villages or huts since morning. In the dim moonlight, we used our torch to see the cliffs. The torch batteries were low, so we put in new ones, but they did not work. We could not find a camping place. A few miles later, Lesley said she saw a light, and we felt hopeful. But it was just moonlight on the waves. Soon, we heard loud water rushing, but we could not see it. Time felt slow, and we kept moving.
**How to be Presentation Perfect**
I am not good at making presentations, but as a managing director, I have to present to my colleagues and shareholders. How can I get better at it and feel more confident? You are not alone. Presenting is a different skill from running a company, but many senior executives need to be good at it. If you want to convince your audience, you must believe in what you say. Show your belief with passion and enthusiasm. Do your homework and prepare well. Ask colleagues to think of difficult questions the audience might ask. Start with something everyone agrees on and slowly build to your main point.

'Some things cannot be rushed. They need time. If you are late for a meeting, you can hurry. But if you add oil too fast to mayonnaise, it will not work. If you pull hard on a tangled fishing line, the knot gets tighter. The mind also works at different speeds. Some things we do very fast, like solving puzzles. But some things need more time. If we rush them, they will not work well, like the mayonnaise or the fishing line. We learn and think in different ways. Some things need fast thinking, like when you are in danger. For example, when my motorbike slipped on a wet road, my body reacted fast to keep me safe. This fast thinking is called 'wits'. Other times, we need to think slowly and carefully, like when solving a problem or making a decision. This is called 'intellect'. Sometimes, we need to think even slower, like when we are dreaming or relaxing. This slow thinking is also important. It helps us understand difficult things. Scientists say that slow thinking is good for solving complex problems. When we do not know what to do, it is better to think slowly. This slow thinking is linked to creativity and wisdom. Poets and philosophers have always known this. Now, scientists are also studying slow thinking. They find that the mind can do amazing things if we give it time. It can see patterns and solve problems that are too hard for fast thinking.'

**Surviving in a Foreign Land**
I am in a friendly place. It is a camp with many things we need, but it is very far from other places. There are about forty people here. They are scientists, students, and other workers. We all help each other. I can speak a little French, but not very well. I cannot make jokes or have long talks. I miss small details in conversations, and my phrasebook does not help at breakfast. This is not a big problem, but at first, I felt shy. I was nervous about eating with others. I did not know which table to sit at. I was scared when everyone was quiet and I had to speak. I felt like I was back in school. I still smile a lot or get nervous when people talk to me. I think I feel sad sometimes because I cannot talk as much as I want. I am used to being good at talking.
**Elliot**
When I first met Elliot, I was a new writer. He did not pay much attention to me. But he always remembered people. When we met again, he was friendly but did not want to be friends. If I saw him at a show with important people, he did not notice me. But then I became a successful playwright. Elliot started to like me more. One day, he invited me to lunch. I thought he wanted to know me better. After my success, I met many new friends, and I saw Elliot more often.
**Alfred Hitchcock**
Alfred Hitchcock was a film director. He said he did not care much about the story or acting in his films. He cared about the pictures and sounds. He thought people liked films because of how they looked and sounded, not because of the story. He believed that if a film was made well, people from different countries would feel the same emotions. Hitchcock was very smart and knew what he wanted. He liked to make people feel scared when watching his films. He focused on making films that were beautiful and made people feel something.

**Amateur Astronomy**
Many things have changed in astronomy in the last 50 years. About 30 years ago, there were not many charts and catalogues. Telescopes were few, and there were not many books on practical astronomy. Today, you can buy many types of telescopes and equipment. Electronic calculators and computers have changed how we make charts and analyze observations. This might be the best time for amateur astronomy. But, some things are not as good. Now, you might need to travel 80 km to see a sky like the one in cities 50 years ago. Airplanes leave trails in the sky that can last for hours, making it hard to see the sun and stars.
**Too Much Choice**
Today, there are too many choices. There are many things to do and many options. People always want the new product or service. Technology makes things change fast. There are many new goods and services, giving more choices. When a new product comes out, another one is ready to be launched. This can make people tired and stressed. More choice means more stress and less time. People now look for simple things that give meaning. But, it is hard to make life simple when there are so many products. There are more types of detergent and breakfast cereals than we need, and more software updates and phone plans than we can follow.
**McAndrews Hotel**
Every summer, we spend two weeks at McAndrews Hotel in North Mayo, Ireland. It is a family tradition started by my grandmother. It is very important to us. We are a special group at McAndrews: old-fashioned and maybe a bit snobbish. I do not like the bad manners of shop assistants today. I do not like waiters who try to be too friendly. I know most of the guests' names because they have been coming here since they were children. But, we only say a polite hello. Respect for privacy is hard to find in hotels these days.

**Othello**
A special show of Shakespeare's play "Othello" moved from Stratford to London. I want to say sorry for a bad review I wrote when the show started last spring. I said Ray Fearon was too young to play Othello and I was wrong about his acting. I still think Othello should be older than Desdemona, but Mr. Fearon's acting is great. The whole cast is great. Some memorable scenes are when Cassio plays games with other officers and things get dangerous, and when Iago starts to lose control. The scene where Emilia helps Desdemona get ready for bed is very moving. The show is exciting and full of tension. Don't miss it.
**Lake Vostok**
In the middle of Antarctica, there is no life. On the edges, there are many penguins, seals, and birds. But inside, on the big white ice, there is no life. Except for a big hidden lake called Lake Vostok, under 4 kilometers of ice, at the coldest place on earth. The water has been without air and sunlight for up to 25 million years. Biologists are excited to explore the lake and find strange life forms. Geologists and glaciologists are also interested. For two years, scientists from around the world have been planning to study the lake. In the next few years, we will learn more about Lake Vostok.
**Scientists**
There was something interesting on the radio last week. Some scientists are talking about why they want to be scientists. We know they want to learn about everything, from atoms to black holes. But they are asking why we want to know these things and why science can't explain this. It is more important to know if what scientists do is right, instead of talking about why we do it. The important thing is to see science as a tool, and we should decide how and when to use it.

**Food**
Food is important and makes us happy. Many people like cooking and buy cookbooks. We often think we need a special occasion to cook, but that's not true. You can make a tasty soup with just carrots, a leek, celery, and herbs. This is better than buying soup in a packet or can. Instead of buying chocolate mousse with many chemicals, you can make a delicious one in five minutes that everyone will love. Cooking is a way to show care and love. We often celebrate with food, like birthdays and weddings. No one would have a takeaway for a wedding party!
**In the Elevator**
This morning, Alistair tried to clean his messy office. Papers were everywhere, and he had many books. He was going to meet Mallory, who was always on time and liked things neat. He worried about what she would think of the mess. Mrs. Wilson, the cleaning lady, came while he was cleaning. She didn't want to clean his office because it was too messy. She thought Alistair was from another world, not from her neighborhood in Brooklyn.
**Karen**
Karen wanted to be different from her mother. She made her own story of strength. When she was twelve, her brother accidentally hit her with a golf club. She thought she was blind, but the doctor said she was okay. She only needed a few stitches. When she saw her mother in the doctor's office, she felt she was saved for a reason.
**Miss Fogerty**
Miss Fogerty was walking across the village green. She was excited and sad about what she saw. She was the first to know something important in her small village. She was sad because Dr. Bailey, her doctor, was not well. He was a good doctor who listened to his patients. He was loved by everyone in the village because he gave his time and care.

Joanna's Lessons
Joanna MacGregor is a busy concert pianist. She also writes books for children learning the piano. Joanna is famous for her amazing piano skills. She plays many types of music like classical, jazz, and blues. At a concert for children, a boy asked her to play "Match of the Day." Joanna found it funny and played it for him. She believes the first piano lessons are very important.
Joanna has written a piano book for children called "Joanna MacGregor's Piano World." She is very busy with concerts and running her own recording label, Sound Circus. But she still finds time to write because she cares about how children learn music. She thinks music should be for everyone, not just for those who want to be stars.
When Joanna was young, her mother taught piano at home. Many children came to learn, and Joanna saw how different they were. Some children learn fast, but others take their time. Joanna is interested in helping all children enjoy music, not just those who are very talented.
Joanna worries that some parents push their children too hard in music. She thinks music should be fun and not just about meeting parents' expectations. Her books are colorful and have stories to make learning fun. They come with CDs for children to play along with.
Joanna believes practice is very important. She didn't practice a lot until she went to the Royal Academy of Music. Now, she practices eight hours a day. She says practice is more important than performing. Her advice is to know what you want to achieve before you start practicing. Also, mix easy and hard pieces to keep it interesting.

**Writing by Hand and on Screen**
Dr. Johnson said, "If writing is easy, reading it is not fun." This means good writing is hard. When I look at my old school essays, I see few mistakes. Today, I would rewrite them many times. I think it was because writing by hand was hard. Writing slowly made me think carefully. With computers, it is easy to make mistakes. Many writers spend the same time fixing computer drafts as they did writing by hand. Emails, unlike handwritten letters, can be heavy with emotion. People say emails have brought back love letters. Many love emails are sent now, instead of just talking. That's good. At least they are written in some form of English. But words on a screen can be boring. Writers often don't know the power of words and can exaggerate. Words typed quickly lack the care of handwriting.
**The CD**
I put down my cup and looked at the CD. The case was not special, but the shiny disc was interesting. "Wonderful little things, aren't they?" Mr. Warriston said. I agreed and gave the disc to him. "Amazing they hold seventy minutes of music," he said, turning on the music player. He pressed a button, and a drawer opened. He put the disc in and closed it. "Some say they sound sterile, but I think they..." "Do you have to turn them over, like records?" I asked. "No," Mr. Warriston said. "You only play one side." "Why?" I asked. He thought and said, "I don't know. You could have two lasers or turn it over by hand." He smiled. "Good point." He pointed to my chair. "Let's get you in the best place for the stereo sound." I was happy to ask a question he couldn't answer.
**Books versus Electronic Text**
Malcolm Bradbury said if matches came after lighters, we would think they are better. People say electronic text is like the invention of printing. They forget that big changes take time. In 1979, a book said, "The 1980s will see books disappear." That was wrong. Reading long texts on a screen is hard, so people don't do it. Computers make people read bits of text. Some say this creates new ways of storytelling. But reading parts of a text is not new. Many books, like religious texts and dictionaries, are not read from start to finish. What is new is that computers don't encourage reading everything.
**The Office**
Charles walked into a tidy office. The carpet was clean, and the desk was dark wood. Files were in drawers, and journals filled the shelves. Kathleen tried to close a filing cabinet and said, "You need computers, Charles. This is too much." "Hello, Kathleen. This is amazing," he said, looking at the room. He didn't think about computers. They had talked about this many times. She didn't understand why he didn't like technology, even though he was good with computers and wrote a paper on it. She inspired that paper. She could use a keyboard to change software into something new.

"You don't take sugar, do you?" shouted his secretary. She wasn't really asking because she had been making Lancelot coffee for many months. She sometimes forgot because he wasn't supposed to be there. But now, he was there all the time. He found out that staying away caused problems. He thought about how he went from being an important advisor to someone always trying to fix problems. There was no place to park when he arrived at work. "This came," she yelled, waving a folder. "From that guy in Los Angeles. You said you wanted to see it." The label said: "A World History of the Short, by Ian Cuthbert." It also said "An Expanded Synopsis." Lancelot did not want to see the word "synopsis." He wanted to see "A First Draft." Lancelot had already seen a synopsis of this book and did not want to see another one. Ian Cuthbert got a lot of money in advance for this book when Lancelot bought the company. Ian was an old friend, and Lancelot made a mistake by asking him to write books. Ian was proof that friends can be unreliable. Lancelot read the synopsis again. It was not new. He closed the folder. Ian's manuscript was not coming. The synopsis was not brilliant, and it seemed like Ian had lost interest. Lancelot remembered a story about a famous author whose last book was published after his death, chapter by chapter. But Ian had already been paid a lot. Lancelot remembered when Ian was a promising talent at Cambridge. Ian's friends took over British theatre, but Ian did not succeed. He was difficult to work with. He was supposed to edit a magazine, but it never came out. He had a contract with a fashion magazine, but he did not produce much. At meetings, Ian was critical and did not like other people's ideas. Ten years later, he was unreliable. Lancelot thought that "A World History of the Short" was a mistake from the start.

'Breakfast in England
Health experts say breakfast is very important. But in history, breakfast is quite new in England. In medieval times, people did not often talk about breakfast. Sometimes, travelers ate early before long trips, and sick people had breakfast for health reasons. But most people did not eat breakfast unless they were kings or nobles. 
In the sixteenth century, breakfast became normal for everyone. Some people think this is because there was more food. But there were also big social changes. For example, people started working set hours and often began work very early. So, eating in the morning became necessary, not just for rich people.'

**Photography**
When a photographer takes a picture, they choose what to show based on their skills, personal ideas, and culture. In this book, we will see how these things change the style and meaning of a photo. We will also see how people look at and feel about these photos. For example, when someone reads a newspaper, they might think they understand the photos. But we can ask if the photo shows the scene as it really was. Or does it show what the photographer thinks? Is the exact moment important, or is the photo a symbol of something bigger?
**More than a Game**
For me, sport is more than just playing. The best people in sport believe in themselves completely. You need to focus if you want to be the best. You have to put other things aside. Sport is tough, and no one will do it for you. You have to try hard or you will fail. Sport has taught me to be disciplined and determined. It also shows how to work well in a team. My sport lets you be great alone, but it is also a team game. It is like life - you can do well alone, but you must remember others. Sport has given me a lot, not just money. It has opened many opportunities for me and let me see the world. But you also have to give up a lot for these benefits.
**Tuning In**
Some experiences stay very clear in our memory. For me, one special moment happened one night in California. I was awake, listening to a bird singing beautifully in a tree. I don't usually have trouble sleeping, but the bird's song kept me awake. The bird's music was like jazz and Indian music. It felt like the bird was performing a special show just for me. I listened and enjoyed the music until I finally fell asleep.

People have always talked about birds. But what do birds say about us? Paul Evans writes about this. There is a noise from the greenhouse. A small brown bird is hitting the glass. It is a wren. Some people think wrens bring messages or signs. Is it trying to tell me something? Or is it just stuck? Maybe both are true. Wrens have been part of British culture for a long time. In the past, people watched wrens to see if they would have good or bad luck. Today, we see wrens in pictures and decorations in many British homes. Even if old beliefs are forgotten, people still like wrens. A forest without wrens feels empty. This is because there is a lot of folklore about birds. In the past, people needed to understand nature to survive. They created stories about birds. These stories can change over time. For example, the red kite was once common in London. People liked them because they cleaned the streets. But later, people thought they were pests, and they disappeared from most places except Wales. Now, red kites are protected and are a symbol of conservation. Our connection with birds is very old. Early humans watched birds to know about danger, weather, and food. Birds also connected them to their dreams. When we think about why birds are important, we also think about who we are. Birds can fly and sing, and we admire them for that. Some people think our feelings about birds are old and not needed now. But losing these feelings is hard. Birds show us how the environment is changing. In Britain, 30 bird species are in danger. This is sad because it means losing part of our culture. Birds like the skylark, turtle dove, and lapwing have special meanings in stories and poems. Losing them is a big loss. But birds not in stories are often ignored. Folklore is important. Stories and songs about birds have a strong connection to them. They help us feel and think about birds in a way science cannot. Watching birds, whether on TV or in our gardens, is exciting. Birds are interesting, and we still do not fully understand why. The wren in the greenhouse makes me think about the past and the future. It is a mystery that keeps me wondering.

'Maps A map shows how places and features on the earth are related to each other. This is shown by distance and direction. In the past, people often measured distance by time, like 'a few hours' walk' or 'a day's journey by river'. This told more about how easy it was to travel the land than the actual distance. Direction was also important, but for most travelers, the main questions were 'Where do I go from here?' and 'How far is it?'. Because of this, written directions were often used instead of maps. Even today, some maps, like train maps, do not show true directions. Early maps used signs to show important landmarks along a route. These signs could be realistic or simple and were different sizes to show their importance. The way maps were made changed depending on their purpose and where they were made. So, when looking at old maps, it is important to understand how they were made. The history of making maps is about getting better at showing distance and direction and adding more details. Map makers used other sciences to help them. For example, they used the magnetic compass to find direction instead of using the sun or stars. They also used tools to measure angles accurately. As people explored more, they tried to map the world. Astronomers found out that the earth is not a perfect sphere, but is slightly flat at the poles, which changed how large areas were mapped. Over time, different people needed maps for different reasons. Soldiers needed accurate maps for planning battles. Archaeologists, historians, and geographers also needed special maps. Today, map makers create maps showing many things, like weather, land use, and more. Maps are now very important in many sciences. The making of maps has not always been a smooth process. Sometimes, old ideas stayed around even when new ideas came. Map makers often knew how to improve maps but had to wait for better tools. Since it was easy to copy old maps, some map makers did not want to change. So, maps should not always be seen as perfect evidence of what people knew at the time. Many maps we have today show a lot of human work and thought. They are a valuable record of human history. This is why studying old maps is so interesting and educational.'

'TIM RICE I went into the young man's living room. It was a nice and calm place, different from the messy rooms around it. Moving from the kitchen to his room felt like going from economy to business class on a plane. He had the largest collection of records I had ever seen, the first stereo record player and tuner I had come across, and he had bought Georgian wine glasses, pictures, and furniture. His name was Andrew Lloyd Webber. He had won a scholarship to Magdalen College, Oxford, to study history, and he had nine months before starting. He wanted to become England's answer to the composer Richard Rodgers. I also had big dreams. I wanted to be a pop star for reasons like women, money, and fame. The difference between Andrew and me was that my dreams were not as serious to me. But when Andrew suggested I try to become a famous lyricist like Oscar Hammerstein, I decided to try. Andrew played me three tunes he had composed, and I could tell he was very good. He played more music from shows he had written at school. I had little to impress him with, except for a song I had written that was recorded by a pop group. We promised to meet again and write something together. I was still more interested in pop music than in theatre, but I thought Andrew was very talented and determined. I didn't want to miss the chance to work with him. The next day, at my office where I was training to become a lawyer, I wasn't as sure about a life in show business. I would keep looking for groups needing a singer and write more songs. But I thought I would probably become a lawyer by the time I was twenty-five. My father said I would stop liking pop music by the time I was twenty-one, which worried me. But I had nothing to lose by seeing Andrew again. It would be fun to write musical lyrics with him. Andrew was interesting and talked about good food and Victorian architecture. I wasn't sure about his idea for a musical about Dr. Thomas Barnardo, who started orphanages. The story didn't excite me, but Andrew believed in his music, and it was good. I didn't know much about musicals, but I decided to try. I skipped a day at the office, pretending to be sick, to write my first musical lyrics. I didn't know it then, but I had changed my career.'

**Language**
Humans have a special ability. We can use language to share ideas with each other. Language is very important in our lives. It is hard to think about life without it. If you see two or more people together, they will probably talk. When people are alone, they might talk to themselves, their pets, or even their plants. I think language is like an 'instinct'. This means people know how to talk naturally, like spiders know how to make webs. Spiders did not learn to make webs from school or special training.
**Climate and Weather**
Climate and weather are made by the air around us. They are very important for animals and plants. Climate can change how a place looks. For example, warm and wet places can have tropical jungles with many different plants and animals. Cold and windy places have fewer living things. Weather changes every day and makes the climate over time. Air moves because the earth spins and because of the sun. The sun is a big reason why air moves.
**Coffee**
I worked as a bar-person and served drinks. I also had to make coffee, which was a bit scary. In Lygon Street, Melbourne, a restaurant's success can depend on its coffee. I had to learn a lot about making coffee and taking care of the espresso machine. I learned how to make a good cappuccino. After the first week, I realized making coffee is not easy. I thought I might have to do simple jobs like cleaning ash-trays again. But my boss was patient. He said, 'Making coffee is both an art and a science, and you need time to learn it.'

**Art on TV**
Why does TV often fail with art shows? Painting and sculpture are good for cameras. Cameras can show a whole artwork and then zoom in on details. But few TV series show the joy and complexity of art. An example is Robert Hughes's series, "American Visions." Hughes is a trusted critic with a strong personality. He had almost eight hours to show British viewers American art, which British galleries often ignore. I thought the series would focus on great art. Instead, it was about how American history and culture are seen in art and buildings.
**Dealing in Metals**
For 20 years, I worked as a metals dealer. I became known for taking risks. Metals are less controlled than other markets. With luck, risk-taking, and market knowledge, you can make a lot of money. Risk is a big part of the industry. This fits well with a free-market global economy. But now, free-trade economists see that the market does not keep metal prices high. More minerals are being taken, and raw material costs are going down. Adjusted for inflation, metal prices are about half of what they were 20 years ago. Recently, I was asked to check claims against a big company that benefits from cheap raw materials.
**Extract from a Holiday Brochure**
Abaco and its small islands are part of the 700 islands of the Bahamas. They stretch from Florida to Cuba. Each island is unique and has something special. To get around Abaco, you need a boat. If your room does not include a boat, don't worry. There are many ferries and water-taxis. You can also rent a boat. Sailing is very popular here. Abaco is called "The Sailing Capital of the World." The calm waters are great for fishing, diving, snorkeling, and swimming. The islands and beaches stretch for 200 miles like a string of pearls. At night, the lights of restaurants and cafes in Hope Town and Green Turtle Cay shine brightly.

'Build your own bike at the UK's first bamboo bike workshop The Bamboo Bike Club, started by engineers James Marr and Ian McMillan, offers a course where you can make your own bike frame and have a fun weekend. It's Saturday morning in Hackney Wick, east London. The Bamboo Bike Club is the only place in Britain where you can build a bamboo bike. I went to see what happens there. There is a lot of energy and fun. Bamboo is becoming popular for making bikes. Companies like Calfee Design in California and Bamboo Bikes in Yorkshire are using bamboo, a method first used in 1894. But these bikes are expensive. A ready-made bamboo frame costs $2,995, or £1,868. James and Ian wanted to make bamboo bikes affordable. They spent years working in a shed in Brecon, Wales. They wanted to create a business where people could enjoy making their own bikes. The Bamboo Bike Club is more like a community. James and Ian have other jobs too. James makes wind turbines and Ian is a civil engineer. They offer monthly courses where you can design and build your own bike frame. On the first day, they teach you how to choose strong bamboo and make strong joints. You glue the bamboo tubes together: first the front triangle, then the seat and chain parts. Metal tubes are used for the handlebars and other parts that need to be very strong. James and Ian help you with every step. If you make a mistake, you can try again. Bamboo is easy to work with. You can choose plain, black, or mottled bamboo. On Sunday, you wrap hemp around the joints and glue it to make the frame strong. Then you add a coating to make it waterproof. The bike is ready for wheels, brakes, gears, and a saddle. The bike is strong and can last a long time. Ian has used his bike for over a year, and James has tested one off-road for three months. 'Our bikes are very strong,' James says. Bamboo bikes look different from professional bikes. The hemp can look like tape, but each bike is unique. I think bamboo bikes are best for a relaxed ride. I chose a 'Classic English' frame for a smooth ride. Bamboo bikes are light and easy to ride. I tried James's bike, and it was smooth and fun. The price? Less than £500.'

**Self-help Books**
Dione Reverend was an editor at Random House in New York. She found a book by Dr. John Gray, a pop psychologist. She thought it would be a bestseller, and she was right. Dr. Gray is now very rich, and Dione Reverend has her own company. Dr. Gray's book helps people understand how men and women can talk better to each other. This book is part of a big self-help industry in America. This industry helps people who want to improve their lives. It also makes a lot of money for book publishers in New York. In Britain, many self-help books are published, but many are not very good. For every book published, many are not accepted because they are too similar to others. Editors look for books that can sell well. They ask questions like, "Is the author easy to promote? Is the idea interesting to many people?" Dione Reverend says that a good title is very important. It helps to sell the book.
**Autobiographies**
When someone writes an autobiography, they make a promise to tell the truth. But often, writers do not tell everything. They might feel too embarrassed to share some things. Or they might think some details are not important. Sometimes, writers change the truth to make their story more interesting. They might even call their book an autobiography to make readers believe it is true, even if it is not. Some readers might think they read a true story, but it is actually fiction. Writers do this not to be mean, but to tell a better story.
**Dashiell Hammett's Detective Stories**
Detective stories became popular in the late 1800s and early 1900s. These stories show the problems in society. A crime in the story shows human desires like wanting more money. Solving the crime helps society work well again. In Hammett's stories, society is not perfect even after the crime is solved. The detective and the criminal understand each other. The detective is both a good guy and a bit of a bad guy. He is not fully on the side of the law or the criminals. Sometimes, he feels guilty about this. Other times, he is very eager to catch the criminal because of this feeling.
**Science Writing**
Stephen Jay Gould is a famous science writer. I met him at the Grand Hotel to talk about writing. We both felt out of place there. Gould said that to write well, you need to understand the culture you are writing about. Science is like its own world, and only scientists can explain it well. If you do not know the rules of this world, it is hard to write about it. Gould believes you should not make things too simple for the reader. You can use simple words, but you should not change the main ideas. If readers feel you are treating them like they do not understand, they will not like your writing.

**Air-conditioning**
At Cannons Gym in London, the air is very cold. The gym uses a lot of air-conditioning because of the hot summer. Sometimes, it feels like the Arctic inside. This is an example of how people use too much air-conditioning. Many buildings could stay cool in other ways. They could use natural light and air, and have thicker walls to keep heat out. These ideas can help reduce the need for air-conditioning.
**Sundials**
Sundials are tools that tell time by the sun. A long time ago, they were very important for keeping time. But when clocks and watches got better, sundials became just garden decorations. Now, people are interested in them again. David Harber, who makes sundials, says they connect us to the planets. When a sundial starts working, it feels magical. They are calm and remind us of our place in the universe.
**Paint Your Own China**
I once saw older women painting china cups with flowers. They were very good at it, and their hands were steady. I wondered who would take a china-painting class. Would they be as good? The class was not scary. The students were there to have fun, and even the teacher did not want to paint quickly like I remembered.

**The Wrong Country**
Uncle chose a holiday for Keith and Dawne. It was a good price. They would fly from Gatwick Airport and stay twelve nights in Venice at the Pensione Concordia. When they went to the travel agency, the clerk said other people on the trip were students learning Italian. But something went wrong. Keith and Dawne ended up in a hotel called the Edelweiss, in Room 212, in Switzerland.
At Gatwick, they gave their tickets to a girl in a yellow-and-red uniform. She checked their tickets and said everything was fine. On the plane, they heard people speaking with North of England accents. Keith thought maybe the Italian class was on another plane. They ordered drinks and relaxed.
When they arrived, a woman with glasses said, "The coach will take us on." Keith thought it was an overnight stop. It was late, and they were tired, so they went to bed. The next morning, they realized they were staying there for the whole holiday. The receptionist said they could enjoy the lake and take a boat to Interlaken.
Keith told the receptionist there was a mistake. They were supposed to be in Venice. The receptionist said their group was booked for twelve nights in the Edelweiss Hotel. Dawne described the travel agent who booked their trip. A woman named Mrs. Franks, who they saw at Gatwick, came over. She explained that many holidays have similar tickets and labels.
Keith insisted they were not meant to be in Switzerland. Mrs. Franks said she would check and left. Keith thought about what happened at the airport. An old man named Nottage talked to them. He and his wife enjoyed their sleep because of the fresh air.
Keith and Dawne left the reception area. They realized it was ironic. On their first holiday since their honeymoon, they ended up with a group of elderly people. They wanted to escape the needs of the elderly, just like Uncle had said.

'HE WAS A PEOPLE PERSON American business leaders are learning from the explorer Ernest Shackleton. Eluned Price reports. Many people in Britain know who Sir Ernest Shackleton was and what he did. In America, he is becoming popular now. The Wall Street Journal called Shackleton 'an Antarctic explorer whose achievements were mostly unnoticed for most of the 20th century.' But now, Americans are very interested in him. Books about Shackleton's journey on the Endurance are being written and are expected to sell quickly. The American Museum of Natural History is having a big exhibition, and Columbia Tristar is making a movie about Shackleton's life. Some American managers see Shackleton as a role model. They talk about his actions with admiration and learn lessons in leadership and communication from him. Shackleton, with his reindeer sleeping bag and blubber-stove, is now a model for modern managers. Jim MacGregor, a manager in New York, has used Shackleton as a role model for years. His company deals with communication during company problems. For example, when a company's factory has an accident or when many workers lose their jobs. Shackleton worked in public relations for a Glasgow steel company, so he understood communication. MacGregor says, 'Even if a company handles its problems well, it can still cause harm by not communicating well.' Shackleton is a model for management because he was a good leader and communicator. He made important decisions, like turning back 97 miles from the South Pole to save his men's lives. In a crisis, people want to know someone is in charge. Shackleton was always ready to take responsibility. His 1914 expedition became legendary. His ship, the Endurance, was stuck in ice for nine months and then crushed. Shackleton told his men, 'We will all be safe if you trust me and do your best.' Shackleton planned everything, kept his men informed, and asked for their opinions. He was flexible and ready to start again if needed. Shackleton believed an explorer needs optimism, endurance, and patience. MacGregor says, 'In difficult times, doing nothing can be hard, especially in America, where people want quick solutions.' Shackleton led by example. On the way back from the Endurance, he gave his gloves to a photographer who had none. He also shared a biscuit when they were starving. Caroline Alexander, author of Endurance, says, 'People want heroes. Shackleton shows us true heroism, which we miss today.'

'Finding Food in Madagascar In the forests of Madagascar, there is a special animal called the aye-aye. It lives like a woodpecker. Both the woodpecker and the aye-aye look for insect larvae in wood. The woodpecker uses its beak to make holes and its long tongue to get the insects. The aye-aye uses its teeth to make holes and its long, thin middle finger to find and scoop the insects. Scientists have studied how the aye-aye finds insects inside the wood. Dr. Carl Erickson from Duke University studied two male aye-ayes, Nosferatu and Poe, a female, Samantha, and her baby, Annabelle. He wanted to know if they find insects by looking for signs on the wood. He gave them logs with holes. Some holes had mealworms, and some did not. The aye-ayes went to the holes with food without needing to see signs. They did not use smell or sound to find the insects. They even found dead mealworms that made no noise. Dr. Erickson found that aye-ayes can sense empty spaces in the wood. They tap the wood with their middle finger and listen with their big ears. They might hear echoes or feel vibrations that show a hollow space. The aye-aye might also hear insects move when it taps. The idea that the aye-aye is like a woodpecker in Madagascar is interesting. But there are birds like the Sickle-billed and Nuthatch Vangas that also look for insects in wood. The aye-aye is like a woodpecker, a bat, and a squirrel. Its teeth grow like a squirrel's, and it can open nuts with its finger.'

'Ordinary people, ordinary lives Many of us have photos of our grandparents, but do we know what their lives were like when they were young? Diaries and family stories give us only small pieces of their past. What will our grandchildren know about us? We often want to write things down but never do it. We might leave videos, but they are still just images. Hannah Renier has an idea: she writes autobiographies for other people. She makes a book of at least 20,000 words, with pictures if needed. These books are not about famous people, but about ordinary people. Hannah got this idea when she talked to her family and saw how much of the past was disappearing. "At first, I didn't take it very seriously," she says. "But then I met people with interesting lives. They do it for their children or the future, but they also enjoy it." People feel safe to be honest with her. A 62-year-old man shared his life story, including painful parts like his divorce. "I did it for my family, so they might learn something," he says. "But I haven't let my children read it yet. Maybe after I'm gone." He saw patterns from his childhood in his life. Hannah noticed this in others too. "Many people are influenced by their parents," she says. "They follow their parents' wishes or rebel against them." People often talk about old disappointments. Even after many years, they still feel upset about things with their parents. Hannah listens and writes their stories. "It's not for the public," she says. "People sometimes tell me things and then change their minds. I include everything, but they can remove parts later. Most people want to be honest." "It's not about showing off," she says. "Life is moving fast, and we forget the past. These books give us a connection to our ancestors." Each book takes about 30 hours of interviews. Hannah uses these to write the life story. Modern technology helps her make the book, except for the cover. The book is for a private audience and costs nearly £3,000, with extra copies at £25 each. She gets about 10 inquiries a week, but the cost stops many people. "I thought it would be cheaper," she says. "But my clients are usually wealthy people who want to leave something for their descendants."'

**A. The University Museum of Classical Archaeology**
The Museum of Classical Archaeology has many copies of Greek and Roman sculptures. There are over six hundred works. Remember, nothing here is real. All the sculptures are copies made from the originals, mostly in the late 19th and early 20th centuries. The Museum is in a special gallery with good natural light. The plaster casts have many advantages: sculptures that were originally together but are now in different museums in Europe can be seen together here. You can see almost all the famous Greek and Roman sculptures in one afternoon.
**B. Cambridge Darkroom**
Cambridge Darkroom is a place for photography. It has community darkrooms and a gallery with different photography exhibitions. We have courses and workshops for all ages and skills, like our Beginner's Course, a short Induction Course, and Master Classes with guest photographers. Members can use our darkrooms. We also help young photographers (aged 12 to 16) with our Young Members scheme, led by our resident photographer. We sell photographic books, magazines, and materials.
**C. Sedgwick Museum of Geology**
The Sedgwick Museum has a great collection of fossil animals and plants, rocks, and minerals from all over the world. It also has Britain's oldest geological collection, from Dr. John Woodward (1665-1728). It includes nearly 10,000 rare specimens in their original 18th-century cabinets. Adam Sedgwick was a Professor of Geology and added a lot to the collections. The collection is arranged by geological age, showing changes in life on Earth over time. The new Whewell Gallery has beautiful minerals and gems. The displays have labels to explain their nature and modern use.
**D. The Cambridge University Collection of Air Photographs**
There are over 400,000 air photographs in the collection, taken by university staff over the past 45 years. The University has its own aircraft at Cambridge Airport and takes photos throughout Great Britain. The photos show the landscape and human activity from prehistoric times to now. There is a small display in the entrance hall, and the library staff can help with questions. The photos cannot be borrowed, but copies can be bought. These take about a month to make.
**E. Cambridge Medieval Brass Rubbing Centre**
The Cambridge Brass Rubbing Centre is one of the oldest and longest-running centers in the world. It is a unique tourist attraction. You can enjoy making wall hangings by rubbing one of over a hundred brass plates from tombs of medieval knights and ladies. The center makes resin copies, called facsimiles, to preserve the originals and make brass rubbing available to everyone. The brass plates were a way to remember people and spread from Germany across medieval Europe and Scandinavia. Most of the original brasses were destroyed, but many are still in Britain, and the Cambridge Centre has a wide range of examples.

**From Here to Fatherhood**
**A. The Theatre Director**
I have had small children for 35 years because of my unusual personal life. I love being a father. This morning, I fed the baby, and that is what being a father means to me. I am lucky because my children and I love the same things: opera, theatre, books, and music. This makes us close, especially now that they are older. I try to be there for them if they need me, but I wait for them to call me. I don't want to make them feel guilty by asking why they haven't called. My parents did that to me, and I don't want to do it to my children.
**B. The Advertising Executive**
I was about 25 when my children were born. It was hard to handle the responsibilities, but it also kept me young. As they grew up, they showed me new music, clothes, and youth culture. This helped me in my job. I missed some important events when they were young because I was busy with work, but now I can take them on nice holidays. They like coming to parties and events with us. They think my job is interesting.
**C. The Politician**
My first child was born when I was starting my political career. My wife and I wanted to spend time with our children, but my work made it hard. I try to take them with me to weekend meetings and events. This way, they know what I do, and they don't feel like I am gone. More politicians are bringing their kids to work now. We all want to include our children in our lives.
**D. The Writer**
My first marriage ended when my children, Kate and Bonnie, were young. I tried hard to stay in touch with them. My ex-wife and I even lived next to each other for a while, but it was confusing for the kids. Kate says I was always there for her, but I am not sure I was a good father. I treated them like adults too soon. Kate thinks we were too easygoing. I wish I had been more organized. I still worry about my children, even the older ones.
**E. The TV Presenter**
I was ready to have kids when I turned 30. My wife and I had a nice house, so we decided to have a child instead of buying more things. Having my daughter Betty made me think about who I am. Being a parent is special, but it also makes you like other parents. Sometimes I feel annoyed, but one look at Betty's smile makes everything better. A baby's smile can make anyone happy.

'Hide and Seek Yvonne Coppard Emma and her friends are playing a holiday game. They are watching a strange bookshop. Emma sees her Uncle Jim there. He tricks her into a world of lies and crime. He tries to make her leave her friends. Emma's life becomes dangerous. She is locked in a dark cellar. This book shows family life and childhood friendship. It warns that adults are not always good. A strong and believable story. Backtrack Peter Hunt Two teenagers, Jack and Rill, work together. Their families were part of a 1915 train accident. Eight people died. They try to find out what happened. The story uses maps and old records. It is a smart and complex book. Pigeon Summer Ann Turnbull Mary Dyer is a girl who loves her father's racing pigeons. Her father leaves to find work. Mary takes care of the pigeons and wins prizes. The story is set in 1930. It shows that there are different kinds of smart. Thoughtful readers will like it. Yaxley's Cat Robert Westall Rose rents a cottage with her two children. She wants to leave her old life. A fierce cat and strange things in the house show why Yaxley disappeared. The local people do not like Rose and her family. Their lives are in danger. The story is very exciting. Someone's Mother is Missing Harry Mazer Sam is from a poor family. His cousin Lisa is from a rich family. Lisa's life changes, and Sam helps her. They learn about family and reality. The story is slow in parts but has gentle humor. It is good for both boys and girls. Stanley's Aquarium Barry Faville Robbie works for Stanley, an old man. At first, Robbie likes him, but then he finds out about Stanley's aquarium. The story becomes a thriller. It is set in New Zealand and is very interesting. Dodger Libby Gleeson Mick has problems at home and school. The story uses flashbacks and letters. Mick finds confidence in a school play. A kind teacher helps him. The story is sad but very good.'

'Science in the Air Journalist Tom Mumford joins students testing ideas in weightlessness. From the outside, it looked like a normal airplane. The pilot told the young passengers it was a Boeing KC-135, made in 1964, based on the Boeing 707. But inside, it was different. The 13 students from Europe and America were ready for an exciting flight. Inside, it was a long white tunnel with few windows and lights on the walls. Most seats were gone, except a few at the back. The students sat there, looking nervous. For a year, they competed with other students to join this flight. The European Space Agency asked for creative experiments to do in weightlessness. The best ideas won a place on this special flight, like a roller-coaster ride. For two hours, the Boeing would fly up and down like a big bird. At the top of each curve, the pilot cut the engines at 3,000 meters. The plane went higher by itself before falling back to Earth. In those few seconds, everything inside became weightless, and the students felt like they were closer to the moon. The plane took off smoothly, but soon it climbed at a 45-degree angle for 20 seconds. The engines were loud, and we felt the blood leave our heads. Then the engines stopped, and we were weightless. For 20 seconds, we floated in silence. The floor felt like a trampoline, and one step sent us to the ceiling. We floated without direction. After ten seconds of falling, the pilot pulled the plane up. Gravity returned, and some students landed hard. There were 30 curves in total, giving ten minutes for experiments. Dutch students studied their robotic cat, Leonardo, to see how cats land on their feet. They used a device to turn it over in the air. A German team looked at how metal joins in space, thinking about future space stations. Students from Utah State University tried to make solar sails from thin films. They believe these sails could use the sun's rays like a yacht uses the wind. After two hours, we felt a bit sick, but mostly excited. 'It was unforgettable,' said one student. 'I want to be an astronaut even more now.''

**My Time in New Zealand**
I had a special time in my life when I didn't have any summers. I went to New Zealand every summer from here, which is winter in New Zealand. So, I had nine winters in a row. I like winter, so it was great. My parents had an idea to buy a small piece of land in New Zealand. My brother, sister, and I could take care of it. My mother said, "If you plant trees on it, you can have it." This way, we would always have a connection to New Zealand. My father grew up there, so it was a nice idea.
They found land about 20 miles north of Auckland, in a place called Rangitoupuni. The land was not very good, but it was okay for planting trees. I have always liked land. I spent a year in Australia working on farms, so planting trees sounded nice to me. I started planting in 1968, and by 1972, we planted all 70 acres.
In 1968, it rained a lot in New Zealand. It was a happy time, even though it rained almost every day. I was often wet and cold. Every morning, I got ready to plant more trees. I had a helper who knew how to plant trees, which was good because I was new to it. We used a planting bag to carry the trees. It was hard work, but I enjoyed it. We had to plant the trees in straight lines, which was tricky. Once you get used to it, planting becomes easier.
While planting, I thought a lot about life and nature. These thoughts have stayed with me. I have visited New Zealand four times since then to see the trees grow. It makes me happy to see them doing well. I worry when I read about bad weather in New Zealand, but the trees are now 20 years old and healthy.
In 1984, I took time off from teaching and went back to New Zealand alone for three months. I wrote my first book, "Seeing Green," there. I stayed in a small cabin with just a bed, table, and chair. I wrote in the mornings, pruned trees in the afternoons, and did research in the evenings. I still feel a strong connection to that place. It is where I feel most connected to the earth.

**Bringing Up Badgers**
"What now?" I thought when a helper handed me a cardboard box. My husband Derek and I have an open farm in Somerset. We are known for taking care of orphaned animals. The noise from the box was strange, like a mix of a cackle and a bark. I looked inside and saw three small grey badger cubs, each about eight inches long. Their fur was soft like velvet, and they had milky-colored eyes. I had never seen badger cubs before. Most are born between January and March and stay underground. If they lose their mother, they often die of hunger.
These cubs were found by builders who accidentally dug into their home. The mother was dead, and the babies were still with her. They were healthy but cold and crying. I cleaned them and put them by the stove in the kitchen to warm up. There were two females, Primrose and Bluebell, and a male, Willow. At first, I fed them with a syringe and wiped them with a warm cloth to help them go to the bathroom. For the first few days, they ate every four hours. Soon, they started drinking from a bottle and moving around a bit.
Three weeks later, Willow seemed tired but was still eating. The next morning, I found him dead. The vet said he had a lung infection. When bottle-feeding, it's important not to let the animal drink too fast, or liquid can go into the lungs. This happened to Willow, and he got an infection.
I was sad but continued to care for the others. Six days later, a local farmer brought me another male cub, also named Willow. He was found alone and cold. Willow II was hard to feed. I had to move the bottle around in his mouth to get him to drink. By the end of April, the females were eating solid food, but Willow II was still learning. He finally started eating sausages.
At five months old, they all ate cereals for breakfast, meat and vegetables for lunch, and fruit, nuts, cheese, eggs, and seeds in the evening. Badgers usually eat earthworms, beetles, bugs, and small animals. My badgers were lucky because the summer was hot, and finding earthworms was hard.
By August, the cubs became more active at night. We often walked through the orchard, and they played and chased each other. Derek sometimes joined us but often got nipped by the playful cubs. During these walks, I saw other badgers in our field. Badgers are territorial and can be aggressive to outsiders. We were warned they might harm our cubs, so we made their pen secure.
The local press took pictures of me with the badgers, and we started a project to build a home for them on the farm. With help, we designed a sett with tunnels and chambers. Our son Daniel made the plans. The cost was high, but a local bus company and other businesses helped. Everyone wanted the badgers to have a home.
One evening, the badgers moved into their new home. I checked on them later and saw them sleeping peacefully. Now, I don't walk with them as often because they are active late at night. We see Primrose sometimes, but Bluebell and Willow II still come to say hello before going off into the night. This is their home now, and they are happy here.

'Finding True North - and the Man Behind Halley's Comet Dr. Toby Clark, a researcher at the British Geological Survey, wants to follow Sir Edmund Halley's journey to study compass changes. Anjana Ahuja reports. Sir Edmund Halley (1656-1742) is famous for the comet named after him. But he also did important work on compass variations, now called 'declination'. Declination is the angle between magnetic north and true north. Without knowing this, sailors could not correct their compasses and find their way at sea. Halley, one of the few people paid to do scientific research at that time, sailed to the Cape Verde Islands to study declination in the Atlantic Ocean. The first trip stopped early because of problems with the crew, but Halley tried again. This time, he traveled to Rio de Janeiro, South Georgia, Newfoundland, and back to England. In 1701, Halley published a map showing compass variations in the oceans. This map helped sailors for over a hundred years until changes in Earth's magnetic field made it less accurate. Dr. Clark, who loves sailing, plans to celebrate the 300th anniversary of Halley's trip by following the same route. He needs to raise £70,000 for the trip, and Sir Vivian Fuchs, a famous explorer, is helping him. Dr. Clark became interested in Halley while working in Antarctica, where he read about Halley's life. 'Halley was an amazing person,' says Dr. Clark. 'He was a respected scientist and led expeditions. He was not just an astronomer but also did research in geophysics. He even helped Sir Isaac Newton with his famous book, Principia Mathematica.' Dr. Clark's trip, called 'In the Wake of the Paramore', will also have scientific value. He will make the same measurements as Halley, but with better tools. These measurements are important because Earth's magnetic field is always changing. The data will help improve the model of Earth's magnetic field. 'We usually measure the size but not the direction of the magnetic field. To measure direction, you need to know true north,' says Dr. Clark. 'We can use satellites to find true north on our trip.' The British Geological Survey and the United States Navy will provide instruments. A Danish satellite will also take similar measurements around the world. Dr. Clark hopes his data will fill any gaps in the Atlantic Ocean. Halley's journey was the first scientific sea expedition, and he was the first civilian naval captain for this purpose. Is Dr. Clark ready for his journey? He has spent two years in Antarctica and worked with the geomagnetic group at the British Geological Survey. He has also sailed from Rio de Janeiro to England. He plans to complete the trip in four parts, with different crews. Does he share Halley's passion? 'I am ready to spend eight months on this, so maybe some people think I'm obsessed. But I wouldn't sail across the Atlantic without a good reason. Halley and his life give me a real sense of purpose.'

**Peacocks and Their Beautiful Tails**
Every summer, peacocks at Whipsnade Wild Animal Park in Bedfordshire show off their beautiful tails to the female peacocks, called hens. This display is a mystery that puzzled Charles Darwin. In nature, animals usually need to be strong and fast to survive. So, why do peacocks have such big, fancy tails?
Darwin thought animals change over time through evolution. The strongest and smartest animals survive and have babies. But peacocks have big tails that seem to make life harder. Darwin suggested another idea called "sexual selection." He thought females liked beauty, so they chose males with beautiful tails.
Darwin's friend, Alfred Russel Wallace, had a different idea. He believed that if hens chose peacocks with fancy tails, those peacocks must have other good qualities. The tail was like an advertisement for these qualities.
Today, scientists like Marion Petrie study peacocks at Whipsnade to find answers. They want to know if hens really choose males with the best tails and if these males have other good qualities. Observations show that hens like peacocks with many eye-spots on their tails. These peacocks get more mates.
Some scientists think that showy male birds are healthier and have fewer parasites. But this is hard to test in peacocks. Dr. Petrie is studying if the children of attractive peacocks are healthier and grow faster.
There is another idea called "Fisher's Runaway." It suggests that if a female picks a male with a slightly better tail, their children will inherit these traits. Over time, this can lead to very fancy tails, supporting Darwin's idea of "beauty for beauty's sake."

'THE BOAT OF MY DREAMS The best boat design should mix old and new, says Tom Cunliffe. He did this with his boat, 'The Westerman'. This week, the Summer Boat Show in London has many new yachts with the latest technology. Most of these boats are from a design change that happened 25 years ago. My boat is different. It is on a quiet creek on the south coast. It was designed last year, but it looks like it is 100 years old. Some people might think I am a romantic person. Maybe I am, but I think my boat is better because it uses both old and new ideas. Modern technology is important for building boats today, but sometimes it makes sailing too easy. Sailors want to feel the real experience of being at sea. I think boats should have some comforts, like a warm stove and a good bed. But if everything on the boat is automatic, it takes away the fun of sailing. For example, steering should be at the back of the boat, not in the middle, just to make more space inside. A boat should feel like a boat, not a house. My old boat, Hirta, had comforts but no luxury. It had heavy sails and no modern equipment, but it was the best boat I ever sailed. Old boats need a lot of care. When I hurt my back, I had to sell Hirta. I could not find a new boat I liked, so I decided to build one. The Westerman was designed by Nigel Irens and Ed Burnett. They used both hand drawings and computers to design it. The boat has crossed the North Atlantic and won races. It looks timeless and is very comfortable. It was designed as a sailing boat first, not as a place to live. It shows that you do not need to follow new trends to be happy. The boat is made of wood with special glue, so it does not let water in. It has the good things of a modern boat but looks and feels like a classic one.'

'RETREAT, RELAX, RECHARGE Health farms and country house hotels with spa facilities are very popular. We asked five journalists to visit some of these places. A. HENLOW GRANGE I was happy to go to Henlow Grange for six days because I was tired and needed to relax. My room in the big 18th-century house was very comfortable. On the first day, I did nothing and slept a lot. From the second day, I started going to classes like yoga and body conditioning. The instructors are very good. I felt more flexible as the week went on. They offer many treatments like aromatherapy, seaweed baths, manicures, and pedicures. The facial, which lasts an hour, makes you feel new. The staff are friendly and professional. Henlow is planning to add a swimming pool and a Light Diet Room. You can also ride bicycles around the grounds. If you want to relax, you can read a magazine or walk in the garden. During my stay, I felt better and had more energy. I want to visit again. This is a great break for a busy working woman.
