Marcella D'Argy Smith B. SHRUBLAND HALL This calm and relaxing place is a big house. When I arrived, I had a medical check-up. They called us patients, which was strange because I am healthy. They found a shoulder problem and helped me with it in fitness classes. Each person gets a special diet. I lost weight but was hungry and had a headache on the second day. My meals were grapefruit and honey for breakfast, salads for lunch, and fruit with yoghurt for dinner. If you are not on a diet, you eat in the main dining hall. The food is tasty. You get a massage or water therapy every other day. Extra treatments are not too expensive. Liz Gregory C. CAREYS MANOR Careys is not a health farm. It is a nice old manor with log fires and a big lounge. The food is very good, but not for people counting calories. The hotel has a gym and pool. There is a spa bath, steam room, and sauna. They also have a sports injury clinic. I got advice for my shoulder injury. Careys is comfortable and relaxing. You can also explore the countryside. Beverly D'Silva D. CLIVEDEN Cliveden is a big country home and a five-star hotel. It offers health and beauty treatments, a gym, saunas, swimming pool, tennis, and horse riding. There are beautiful walks and gardens. Waldo's is a famous restaurant with many dishes. The food is amazing. I enjoyed a facial and an aromatherapy massage. Cliveden has many fitness and beauty options. Kay Letch E. SPRINGS HYDRO The best and worst thing about Springs Hydro is the carrot cake. It is delicious but has many calories. The aromatherapy massage is also great. I chose relaxing oils and had a good sleep. The place is modern and well-run. There are many therapists and beauty rooms. They offer treatments like manicures, pedicures, and facials. The guests are a mix of people, like football teams and friends. I would like to visit once a month. Eve Cameron

'NATURAL TALENTS In the seven million years since humans separated from chimpanzees, we haven't changed much: we are still more than 98% the same as chimps. On this big evolutionary scale, what makes humans different from animals is very recent. Our history shows that our ability to make art and other human things must come from a small part of our genes. This is a big job for just a few genes. So, it's not surprising that studies of animal behavior show that many things we thought were only human are also in animals. For example, not only humans use tools; wild chimpanzees use sticks to eat and as weapons, and sea otters use rocks to open clams. Monkeys have a simple language with different sounds for 'leopard', 'eagle', and 'snake'. These findings show that there are few absolute differences, other than art, between us and animals. But if human art came from a special genetic gift, it's strange that our ancestors didn't use it for most of the 7 million years since they split from chimps. The first art might have been wood carvings or body painting, but we wouldn't know because those materials don't last. We only have clear evidence of human art from the Cro-Magnons, about 35,000 years ago, with cave paintings, statues, necklaces, and musical instruments. If we say our recent creativity sets us apart, how is our art different from similar animal works? Three differences are often mentioned: human art is not useful, it's made for beauty, and it's learned, not genetic. Let's look at these ideas. First, as Oscar Wilde said, "All art is quite useless". This means human art doesn't help us survive or pass on our genes, unlike most animal behaviors. Human art is different because it communicates thoughts or feelings, not genes. Birdsong, for example, helps defend a territory or attract a mate, passing on genes. The second idea is that only human art is made for beauty. We can't ask birds if they enjoy their songs, but they sing mainly during breeding season, so they probably don't sing just for beauty. Again, human art seems unique. The third idea is that human art is learned, not instinctive. Each human group has its own art styles that are learned. For example, songs in Tokyo and Paris are different, but people can learn each other's songs. Some birds inherit their songs and would sing them even if they never heard them. It's like a French baby raised in Japan singing the French national anthem without learning it. Human art changes quickly. Geese honked 2,000 years ago, as they do today, but human art changes so fast that even a casual museum visitor can tell a 20th-century painting from the Mona Lisa. Experts can often tell when and who painted a work. But they might mistake two mid-20th-century artists, Congo and Betsy, who were actually chimpanzees. Congo made up to 33 paintings in one day and got upset when his pencil was taken away. Congo and Betsy had a show in 1957 at London's Institute of Contemporary Art, and most of their paintings sold. These paintings by chimps blur some lines between human art and animal activities. Like human paintings, the ape paintings were not made for practical reasons but for the painter's satisfaction. You might say human art is different because artists want to communicate. The apes didn't care about communicating and just discarded their paintings. But this isn't a big problem, as some human art that became famous was also made for the artist's own satisfaction.'

'A Big Adventure The Taklamakan Desert in western China is one of the last unexplored places on earth. It is also very dangerous. Charles Blackmore crossed it and survived. There are not many big adventures left and not many heroes. In the past, children's stories were about brave explorers with sunburnt skin and eyes looking far into the distance. Today, you don't find such people in stories or real life. But then I met Charles Blackmore. Blackmore's big adventure was leading a team across the Taklamakan Desert in western China. Its name means 'once entered you never come out', but local people call it the Desert of Death. He talked about the dangers and excitement of the journey at his home. The team had four Britons (one was a doctor), an American photographer, four Chinese experts, 30 camels, and six camel handlers. The camel handlers had never worked with camels before; they were truck drivers. This mistake could have been very dangerous. This group started to cross 1,200 kilometers of desert. Charles Blackmore wrote a book about their journey. At that time, he was leaving the Army after 14 years. He started the expedition for fun and to learn more about himself. 'I always thought I would stay in the Army. I was offered a promotion, but I wanted to see who I really was. It was a big risk. My wife, Tina, was worried because nobody had done that route before. We went into it without knowing what to expect. It took 59 days to cross from west to east, and the desert was kind to us.' When you read his story, you might wonder why he says 'kind'. The team faced many problems: illness, hot and cold temperatures, thirst, and losing some of their water. 'But', Blackmore says, 'when we were very tired and the camels had no water for seven days, we found some. We didn't have the desert's big sandstorms. And we didn't face the very cold weather that could stop us. But we had many problems. The sand got into everything, especially blisters and wounds. The high dunes were hard to climb for us and the camels, which often fell over. 'What kept me going was the need to survive. We had no backup plan. No planes flew over us. Once we were in the desert, we were alone. 'I knew I was mentally strong, but I was scared about my physical strength. I remember the first day -- we sat at the edge of the desert, and it was so hot you couldn't breathe. I thought, "We have to do it now!" I was very scared.' How did they feel towards the end? 'When you've walked 1,000 kilometers, you don't give up. We were very thin but strong. My body was fit, and my legs were strong. I could walk over anything.' In the book, Blackmore talks about lying in the desert looking at the moon and thinking of his family. How did he feel about their worry? 'Inside me, there's someone trying to find peace. When I doubt myself, I think of the desert and how we did it. I am proud of that expedition. But for a lifetime achievement, I think of my family and our happiness. The desert does not compare.' Has Charles Blackmore found peace? 'I want the challenge and open spaces. We had a purpose. Now, I find it hard to be part of modern life.''

Susan Harr is tired of technology. She turns off her gadgets and enjoys doing things by hand. Many people love technology because it makes life easier. But Susan thinks we depend too much on it. She had a problem with her word processor, which was expensive to fix. This made her think that gadgets might not be worth the trouble. Susan is letting her old gadgets stop working and not replacing them. She wonders if technology really gives us more time or just makes us buy more gadgets. 
When her sewing machine broke, she decided to sew by hand. She likes that she can take her sewing anywhere and doesn't have to listen to a noisy machine. She also got rid of her color TV and now watches a small black-and-white one. This makes her think more about what she watches. Without the TV, she spends more time walking her dog, reading, and talking with family.
Susan enjoys sewing by hand. She can listen to the radio or talk with friends while she sews. She finds it relaxing and satisfying. She also likes washing dishes by hand because it gives her time to think. Now, she looks around her house and wonders if she really needs things like the freezer or microwave. She thinks she could save money by using fewer gadgets.

'The Cabinet-Maker Charles Hurst makes a living from making furniture. Joanna Watt meets him. Charles Hurst seems like a man in a hurry. I arrive at his workshop in East London, and he greets me quickly, saying: 'Well, fire away then!' It is not clear if he is really in a hurry or just shy. But his workshop is very busy. There are many half-made pieces of furniture and planks of wood in different natural colors. Hurst has been a cabinet-maker for ten years and is well-known. His order book is always full for months, even though he does not advertise. People know that if you want a good cupboard, table, bookcase, or kitchen units, Hurst is the person to go to. Finding a furniture-maker is not hard. But finding one who makes beautiful furniture with simple lines is not easy. 'There are few real cabinet-makers now. People call themselves furniture-makers,' Hurst says. He is not happy with some modern furniture. 'I am amazed by what some furniture-makers get away with, and saddened by what people will put up with.' He does not like bad, mass-produced furniture. Hurst wants perfection and has talent. He is confident about his ability. 'I have a huge natural ability,' he says. 'I have always been good at making things.' Hurst is self-taught. How did he learn? 'I asked the right questions and picked it all up,' he says. Most of his work comes from private people. Some clients come back many times. 'You end up doing the whole of their house. That is very satisfying.' But he admits that working with clients is not always easy. 'The most annoying clients are those who don't know what they want, and then decide they do when it's too late ... my favorite clients are the exacting ones.' Hurst is happy with his work but also praises others. 'There are people far better than me. I can admire other people. After all, I wasn't trained at Parnham' (a top furniture design school). He is critical of craftsmen who 'are trying to be artists and take a year to make one piece.' He also does not like degree shows where students try to make fashion statements. 'A piece of furniture is not about making a statement. It has to be something that people really can use.' Hurst is confident but not pretentious. As I leave, he says, 'After all, I am only making furniture.''

'Why do we sleep? People sleep for about one-third of their lives. This means sleep is very important. But scientists do not agree on why we need sleep. There are three main ideas. The first idea says sleep is good for our body. When we sleep, our body fixes itself and gets ready for the next day. The second idea says sleep helps us learn. When we sleep, our brain works on the things we learned during the day. Without sleep, we cannot learn well. The third idea says sleep gives us energy. We sleep to get more energy for the next day.'

'ECCENTRICS An eccentric is a person who behaves differently from most people. They do not follow the usual rules of society. This makes us ask, "What is normal?" Many of us have our own little habits. It could be entering newspaper competitions, collecting beer mats, or writing letters to the newspaper about many topics. Eccentricity is about being unique. Inside us, there are two forces. One is called individualism, and the other is conformity. Most people want to be accepted and loved, so they follow the crowd. But some people have unusual hobbies or strong opinions. They like to meet others who share their interests. They form clubs and hold meetings. They feel better when they are with others who understand them. We all feel a pull between being unique and fitting in. Sometimes, we want to show we are different. For example, a person might say, "I say what I think," or "You must take me as you find me." We can choose to be more individual. Many successful people have done this. Bob Dylan, an American singer, said, "When you feel what you are doing and keep doing it, you will surprise many people." But being different on purpose is not the same as being eccentric. A pop singer wearing strange clothes for attention is not eccentric. But if they always act this way and cannot go back to 'normal', they might be eccentric. Eccentrics do not try to be different; they just are. They do not care about what others think. They are not like enthusiasts, practical jokers, or exhibitionists, who are aware of society. Eccentrics live their lives without worrying about what others think.'

'Natural Books We asked four nature experts to tell us about the wildlife book that influenced them the most. A Geoffrey Lean Choosing the author was easy for me. As an environmental journalist, I have met many important people in this field. None impressed me more than Barbara Ward, a small, frail woman who was very important in environmental issues in post-war Europe. She combined her experiences into a strong philosophy. As a young journalist, she helped me understand the field. Choosing the book was harder. It could have been Only One Earth or Progress for a Small Planet. But The Home of Man is, to me, her most important book. It talks about the fast growth of cities and the big themes she cared about. It is a strong call for what we now call 'sustainable human development'. I have read many books since, but none match it. B Linda Bennett When I read Signals for Survival by Niko Tinbergen, I can imagine the sounds and smells of a herring gull colony. This book explains animal communication with words and pictures. After reading it, watching a gull colony becomes a lesson in social structure. You can see which birds are partners and where the boundaries are. Niko Tinbergen was a great behaviourist who wanted to share his findings with everyone. He worked with Eric Ennion, a talented wildlife artist, to create this book. Ennion's paintings show how one gull is aggressive and another is peaceful. This is the work of a true field naturalist. C Lee Durrell My Family and Other Animals by Gerald Durrell is the book that influenced me the most. It led me to a wonderful husband and a career in conservation. This book made me love the natural world. I was in Madagascar studying animal sounds when I first read it. I was having a hard time, but reading this book made me happy. It shows animals, people, joy, and beauty together. Many people say humans are the worst because of the harm we do, but Gerald saw the world as a family. This is an idea we all need to understand. D Bruce Pearson I found The Shell Bird Book by James Fisher in my school library in 1966. I loved the 48 color plates of birds by Eric Ennion. I already had other bird books and spent holidays learning to identify birds. They encouraged me to start sketching birds. The Shell Bird Book had more to offer. It had chapters on bird migration, the history of birds in Britain, and birds in music, literature, and art. This book showed me that my emotional and creative response to nature was as important as a scientific one. Since I was better at art than maths or physics, it opened a new path for me.'

'DO REVIEWS SELL BOOKS? We asked five important British publishers if book reviews help sell books. Here is what they said. Publisher A Reviews are very important for publishers. The Book Marketing Council found that many people buy books because of reviews, more than for other reasons like ads or word of mouth. Authors and publishers feel sad if there are no reviews, but publishers are less upset by bad reviews. They think any review can help sell books because people want to decide for themselves. Publishers like reviews that agree with their own opinion of the book. Publisher B Publishers and newspapers both care about book reviews, but they want different things. Newspapers want to entertain readers, while publishers want their books reviewed positively. Book reviews are better now than 40 years ago, but paperbacks are often ignored. Publishers need reviews because they help make books and authors known. A good review by a trusted person can help sell books. Publisher C Reviews are very important for literary publishers. They help sell books, especially for authors who are not famous. Good reviews are better than ads because they are honest. Reviews can help a book become popular, but they need help from other things like word of mouth and good marketing. Publisher D In Britain, the link between publishing and reviews is unclear. In the US, a review in the New York Times can make a book popular. In Britain, it can take many years for good reviews to help a writer. Some books sell well even with bad or no reviews. Non-fiction reviews often talk more about the subject than the book. Publisher E Publishers and writers want long, good reviews. But do they sell books? I published a biography with great reviews, but it did not sell well because people felt they knew the book from the reviews. The reviewer's name used to matter more. Now, a surprising reviewer or a strong, funny, or original review can make people want to buy the book.'

'WEATHERVANE MAKER Making weathervanes is a very old skill. It started in early Egyptian times. Today, Graham Smith keeps this craft alive in his workshop. He is one of the few people in the country who make weathervanes by hand. Graham makes special designs for each customer. 'This way, I can make a unique item,' he says. 'Many of my customers are women buying gifts for their husbands. They want a special gift that shows the man's job or hobbies.' This is different from the usual cockerel design. Graham's first weathervane was a witch on a broomstick, not a cockerel. He made it as a surprise gift for his wife. Friends liked it and asked him to make weathervanes for them. 'I saw that I could make many different designs,' he says. Graham decided to start a weathervane business. He was a precision engineer for 15 years. Then, he and his wife, Liz, changed roles. She worked as an architectural assistant, and he stayed home to care for the children and grow the business. That was five years ago, and he is happy with his choice. 'My old job was not artistic, but this is fun and creative,' he says. 'I love designing.' Graham has made over 100 original designs. He works with fine details and always asks the customer to approve the design before cutting it by hand. Graham also keeps many traditional designs because they are popular. 'People like hand-made things,' Graham says. 'They want something a little different.' Graham does not want to expand his business. He wants to keep it as a small craft. 'I have found my place in the market. People love the unique designs, and I enjoy turning a simple shape into something almost real,' he says. 'For a long time, weathervanes have helped people know the weather by showing wind direction changes,' he explains. 'Now, more people are moving to the countryside, and they want a special touch for their homes. This helps crafts like mine.' Graham is very busy now, sending flat-packed weathervanes to clients around the world. American and Danish buyers are especially interested. 'The price,' he says, 'depends on how detailed the design is.' His latest request was for a curly-coated dog. Whatever the occasion, Graham can make a special gift.'

'Beginner Takes All Before it was published, The Horse Whisperer was already a very popular book. It is the first novel by British writer Nicholas Evans. He talks about his inspiration and success. At the start of the year, things were not going well for Nicholas Evans. He is a screenwriter and producer. A film he was working on, Life and Limb, was canceled suddenly. He was worried because he had not earned money for two years. The film was his only hope to pay the bank. Instead of finding a job, Evans decided to go to America for three months to write his first novel. He got the idea for the story from a farrier he met in Dartmoor. The farrier told him about a horse that became wild. A gypsy, known as a 'horse whisperer', calmed the horse by talking to it. Evans was interested in this story. He wanted to write a screenplay, but after Life and Limb was canceled, he decided to write a book. He traveled across the US, visiting ranches and learning about horses. He felt alone and worried about his future. By August, he had written half of the book. He showed it to a friend who was a literary agent. The agent thought it was good and said Evans might get $30,000 for it. Evans needed more money to pay his debts. In October, the first part of the book and a summary were sent to publishers. Soon, his agent told him that someone offered $75,000 for the book. Evans was surprised. In a week, the book was sold for $550,000 in the UK and $3.15 million in the US. This was a record for a first novel. Hollywood studios also wanted to make a movie. Evans decided not to write the screenplay for the movie. He wanted to stay involved but not too closely. The success of his book also brought new interest in Life and Limb, but Evans was not sure if he wanted to make it. He thought it would be better to write another novel.'

'Young Chess Players Bobby Fischer is trying to play chess again, but he is older now. Chess is a game for young people. After 20 years away, Bobby Fischer is playing against Boris Spassky. Bobby won the first game, but he is not the same as in 1972. He is 49 years old and not in practice. Boris Spassky is even older. Chess has changed a lot in 20 years. Now, chess is more about winning than about art or science. Players need strong nerves and stamina. The games are longer, and there are no breaks. Young players have an advantage. In the last 30 years, each new world champion is younger. Eight of the top ten players in the world are under 30. Chess is also different because of computers. Players use computers to study their opponents' games. A small computer can have one million chess games. Being ready for the start of the game is very important. There are many good players now. They play for small prize money. A game can last up to eight hours. Players must focus all the time. A mistake can mean losing the game. The chess clock makes the game more tense. At the end of the game, players have only seconds to make moves. They must be fast and focused. Winning feels great, but losing is very hard. Chess tournaments last 9-11 days, with games every day. World championship matches are even harder. In 1984, a match between Anatoli Karpov and Gary Kasparov stopped because they were too tired. Karpov lost about 10kg. Can Bobby Fischer win again? He once said, "All I want to do is play chess." He left chess in 1972, which was surprising. If he came back for money, he will earn a lot. But if he wants to be the best again, it might be very difficult.'

**Fame and Success**
Imogen Edwards-Jones talks to some new British talents, from poets to pop stars, who are becoming famous.
**A. Nick Grosso**
Nick Grosso is in his early 30s and has written three successful plays. He is now turning his first play, "Peaches," into a movie script. "It's a low-budget film, but we don't know how low," he says. "It won't be more than £30 million, but it could be as little as £30." Before writing "Peaches," Nick had never seen or read a play. "When I wrote it, I never thought it would be performed," he says. "It's set in a car. I wouldn't do that now because I know it's difficult. I knew nothing back then." He left school at 16 but returned a year later. After finishing school, he joined the Young People's Theatre. "I wanted to write for actors. I wanted my writing to be heard, not just read," he says. "It was the first time I enjoyed being in an educational place. It was exciting."
**B. Simon Pegg**
Simon Pegg, 28, has made great progress since studying drama at Bristol University. He is writing a TV comedy series and just finished a tour with comedy star Steve Coogan. He has always worked hard. Even at university, he performed in comedy clubs. "University was very theoretical," Simon remembers. "It made me realize I didn't want to be a serious actor. I was more interested in comedy. People think comedy is the hardest job, but it isn't. If you have courage and good material, making people laugh is wonderful." He performed with the comedy group Funny Business, but working with Steve Coogan has been the best. "He saw my show, and since I was a big fan, he probably saw me copying him," Simon admits.
**C. Ciaran McMenamin**
Ciaran McMenamin, 24, became famous when he starred in the series "The Young Person's Guide To Becoming A Rock Star." The show was very successful, and his career took off quickly. "It's been a great opportunity for me," he says. "Now I can choose what I do, which is what I always wanted." This is a rare position, especially since he just graduated. Looking at Ciaran's early career, it's clear he was always talented. Encouraged by his mother, he played lead roles at school and joined the Ulster Youth Theatre for four years. "I used acting as an excuse not to do homework," Ciaran laughs. "But then I decided to take it seriously because I was good at it and loved it." Now he waits for praise but says, "When you're 18, you think you'll love the fame, but you realize it's not about that. It's about respect for good work."
**D. Neil Taylor**
Neil Taylor, 25, is the lead singer of the pop band Matrix, which signed a three-album deal with Domino Records. Neil and his bandmate Rick Brown are expected to be very successful when their single "Chimera" is released. "The record company talks about a big hit, but I don't know. If two people buy it, I'll be happy," he says. Unlike many new pop stars, Neil worked hard for his success. He left school at 16 and tried to enter the music business. "It's funny how things happen," he says. "I was doing student gigs for eight years and was about to give up when I met Rick Brown, who had contacts at Domino, and we formed Matrix." It was perfect timing. "I was often depressed and in bad bands, but hopefully, it will all be worth it."
**E. Stephen Richards**
Stephen Richards, 27, is a poet and author who has won many prizes and awards. He is well-known in the poetry world and has been touring and reading his work for six years. His first novel, "Hidden," will be published in March. "It's a story of obsessive love. It was a strong idea that couldn't be a poem." Stephen loved creative writing at school but later became bored with education. "I decided not to go to university, but when I got bored with a job at a theatre, I decided to go." After university, he published a children's book in 1992. "My parents didn't expect me to be a writer. They thought I'd be a reader because I read a lot as a child." With his poetry being praised, moving to novels is brave. "There's a structure in poetry, so less can go wrong," he explains. "A novel can be any length, so there are more chances for mistakes. My goal is not to write without caring about quality."

A. Isabel is an art student who is 31 years old. She likes historical romance stories and is looking for Mr. Right. She thinks she looks good in jeans but doesn't wear them often because she doesn't want to meet the wrong people. Isabel worries about her knees, but she always has hope. This hope helps her and others in the story. The book is written in a fun and exciting way, like an old silent movie.
B. This story is about a local radio station in America. A smart child named Francis With works for WLT Radio, which was started by Roy and Ray Soderbjerg to promote their sandwich shop. The station plays music, shows, and more. The story is set in a small American town and takes the reader back to the 1940s and 1950s. The author uses humor and simple writing to tell the story.
C. In this story, a professor named Richard Vaisey falls in love with a Russian poetess. He talks about it with his wife's first husband. The poetess writes bad poetry and wants Richard to help her brother, who is in prison. The author makes the story interesting by solving these problems in a funny and smart way. The book is enjoyable and clever.
D. Two women and two men become best friends in London during the 1960s. One of them, James Hudson, starts a newspaper with his friend Richard Blake. They both loved a woman who died years ago. The story is about murder, ambition, love, and jealousy. The book is long, so readers can really get to know the characters.
E. This story is about Ian Bedloe, who feels guilty about something he did. To make up for it, he takes care of his brother's three children. Ian is 40 years old and lives alone. The story shows his special relationship with the youngest child, Daphne. It is a warm and funny book with the right mix of sadness and laughter.

**Volunteer Tourism**
Four writers talk about international volunteer work.
**A.** Volunteer tourists often help build homes or schools. They pay a lot of money to do this work. If they gave this money directly to the local community, it could pay for more work than one volunteer can do. This is true for gap year volunteers, who usually do not have special skills. Some studies question if gap year volunteering is really to help others or to improve the volunteer's career. However, these projects can help volunteers learn to act kindly in their future lives.
**B.** Volunteering can help people understand each other better and solve problems. It can also help people from different countries work together and make friends. This can be good for everyone. But if only rich people from wealthy countries volunteer, it might help them more than the communities they visit. These volunteers might use the experience to get ahead in their careers.
**C.** Sometimes, international volunteering can be seen as charity from rich countries. It can also be a way for volunteers to improve their own skills. At its best, volunteering helps both the volunteers and the communities. It allows people to share skills and learn from each other. Volunteering can also make people aware of global problems like poverty and injustice.
**D.** Volunteer tourism is popular because people want to help others. It seems positive because it is not about big government or business. But it can also ignore the real needs of poor communities. Volunteering is a good act, but when it is called "sustainable development," it can be misleading. It might not really help solve big problems like poverty.

**Sound the Alarm: Stuart Harris Reports**
Many people listen to the radio in the morning. Most of us need something to help us wake up. This is why we have clock radios. But how do you choose a good one? Our team, including me, inventor Tom Granger, and broadcaster Paul Bridges, tested five clock radios.
One model has a 'dual alarm function'. This means you can set two different wake-up times, one for workdays and one for weekends. But not everyone needs this. This model also has a cassette player, which is nice because you can listen to your own tapes. The radio quality is good, but the clock radio is big. Paul Bridges said he needs space on his bedside table for his keys, wallet, glasses, and phone. He also books a wake-up call just in case the alarm doesn't work.
Another model was the best-looking and the overall winner. Paul Bridges liked it a lot, but the clock sometimes got stuck at 16:00. The digital display is nice, and the snooze bar is easy to use. It has a self-power back-up, so you don't have to reset it if the power goes out. But it was hard to set up. Tom Granger said the model with a built-in lamp was 'tacky'. The lamp was hard to use, and the radio was hard to tune. The buzzer was very loud, like a submarine alarm. This model is popular with young people because of its bright colors.
One model was easy to set up without reading the instructions. But the alarm can be 10 minutes early or late. Paul Bridges thought this was not good. The simplest and cheapest model was small and easy to use. It has old-fashioned dial tuning, which Tom Granger liked. He said it was more intuitive. The radio quality was fine, and the buzzer worked well.

'Hedgehogs A hedgehog is a small animal with sharp spines on its body. Hedgehogs live in many places in the world, but not in America or Australia. All hedgehogs can roll into a tight ball when they are scared. This helps them because their spines point outwards. How well this works depends on how many spines the hedgehog has. Some hedgehogs that live in the desert have fewer spines. They might try to run away from danger first and roll into a ball only if they have to. Hedgehogs are mostly active at night and sleep during the day. They sleep under bushes or in holes in the ground. All hedgehogs can hibernate, but not all of them do. If the weather is good, some hedgehogs stay awake all year.'

'Great Sports Women Winning in Sports It is hard to be good at sports, even for men, but women have to work even harder. Training and competitions take a lot of time, so they have to give up many things. But they are winning and breaking records. Here, we talk to some great British sportswomen who are reaching their goals. A. Jill, 27, skier "It's amazing to fly through the air and land well, but it can be scary. Sometimes you feel sick or it's windy and hard to see, but you keep going. It's hard to have a job outside skiing because we train for ten months a year. You give up a lot of your social life and friends. But it was my choice. There are six men and three women in the British team. We all compete on the same courses and get treated the same - it's a young sport." B. Caroline, 22, cyclist "Two years ago I borrowed a bike for a charity race. I won because I cycled faster than everyone else, which was amazing because I had never cycled before! I get good money as a pro, and cycling has many chances for sponsorship. But I worry people think I succeed because of how I look, not because I'm the best cyclist. So I focus on cycling now, not on earning money. I train at least four hours every day on the bike, plus stretching, swimming, and running. My boyfriend is a cyclist too, so he understands the time you need to put into it -- it would be impossible otherwise." C. Annabel, 26, rower "Rowing is hard for girls to start because few girls' schools offer it. So most start at 19 or 20, which makes it harder to succeed internationally. Also, coaches usually stay only a year. There's no continuity, so the women's team is not well organized. But it's fun and I love being fit, plus there's a good social life." D. Ffyona, 24, long-distance walker "At 13, I dreamed of walking around the world -- I didn't know how big it was then! Britain felt too small and safe. I was very strong-willed; I hated anyone controlling me. Now I am more careful. Each walk is different. The walk across Australia was the hardest because of pain. I walked 50 miles and 21 hours each day with three hours of sleep in high temperatures and 15 blisters on each foot. But I got the record! I had to, because my sponsorship money was going to run out after 95 days. Men think women are more likely to fail, so sponsoring them is seen as a higher risk." E. Lisa, 26, car racer "Some men have big egos when driving - you see it on highways. When I'm doing well, they don't talk to me. Being a woman has its disadvantages. When I get to a corner, men think 'I've got to beat her', so I've had a lot of bumps! You have to be naturally competitive and aggressive. It's very hard to earn money and what I do make goes back into the sport. Women have been racing since the twenties and have always been seen as unusual. It's great that more women are racing every year. For me, the appeal of car racing is aiming for perfection, always trying to get a perfect lap." F. Alison, 28, triathlete "I get up at 5.30 three mornings a week to swim. I need Tuesday and Thursday mornings to catch up on sleep. In the evening I just cycle or run. Yes, I do fall asleep at my desk sometimes! There is a lot of nervous build-up before a race and when you're racing you really push yourself - you don't feel good if you don't. Several times I've asked myself why I do it. The answer is a) I'm happier when I keep fit, b) I'm lazy at heart and if I didn't make myself do this I'd really be lazy, c) racing is very social. Men and women usually compete together but when an event is in the news, 90 percent of the article will explain the men's event and 10 percent will say, 'Oh, by the way, so-and-so won the women's event'. The prize money isn't as good either, of course. But now we've formed an International Triathlon Women's Commission, so we're working on it."'

**The Day I Met Picasso**
Richard Cork remembers the day he met the famous artist, Picasso. Richard was 18 years old and traveling around Europe and Morocco before starting university. He had little money, so he worked painting boats in Cannes. One day, he saw Picasso having lunch at a restaurant with his wife and friends. Richard was surprised because Picasso was usually a private person.
Richard's friend encouraged him to ask Picasso for his autograph. Nervously, Richard approached Picasso and offered his sketchbook. Picasso kindly signed his name and drew a little picture on the page. Richard was very happy and started a conversation with Picasso, even though they needed help from an American woman to translate.
Richard's friend suggested he draw Picasso's portrait. Richard returned to Picasso's table and began to draw him. Picasso made funny faces to make it difficult for Richard, but eventually, he sat still. Richard noticed how young and strong Picasso looked, even though he was almost 84 years old.
After Richard finished the portrait, Picasso wanted to see it. Richard was shy but showed it to him. Picasso then drew a quick picture on the same page, adding a playful touch to Richard's work. Richard asked Picasso to sign the drawing, but Picasso said he had already signed once.
Richard felt very lucky to have met Picasso and to have received his attention. It was a special moment for him.

**Shopping Tricks**
Have you ever gone to a store and bought more than you planned? Stores use tricks to make you spend more money. Here are some of them:
**A. Fresh Look**
Supermarkets know people like fresh food. They often put fruits and vegetables at the entrance. They might also have a bakery with the smell of fresh bread. The store might use green colors because it reminds people of fresh things. Most of what they sell, like frozen foods, is not fresh.
**B. Smart Display**
Where products are placed in a store is very important. Supermarkets use computers to know where people shop the most. They put expensive or fast-selling items there. Shelves at eye level are popular because people see them first. Special offers in big bins attract people who love bargains. Stores also put items that go well together, like salad dressings near salads.
**C. Staples Spread Out**
Supermarkets put basic items like bread and sugar far from the entrance. This way, you pass by other tempting products. Stores also put popular items far away so you see other things while looking for them.
**D. Less is More**
Some stores, like Next, show fewer items to make them look special. This makes people think the clothes are unique, even if they are not. The store design helps sell the clothes.
**E. Total Temptation**
People care more about the total bill than the price of each item. Supermarkets mix cheap and expensive items. They might sell some items at a loss to attract customers. They buy in large amounts to get discounts from manufacturers.
**F. Price Tricks**
In chain stores, people notice individual prices more. Pricing something at $14.99 instead of $15 makes a difference. It also helps reduce theft because staff must ring up the sale to give change.
**G. Lighting Magic**
Stores use special lighting. Chain stores want natural light so clothes look the same outside. Supermarkets use lighting to make fruits and vegetables look better.
**H. Walking Paths**
Stores use different carpets to guide you. One type is for walking paths, and another is for sales areas. Some stores use wood or marble for paths to make the carpeted sales areas more inviting.
**I. In-Store Ads**
When you enter a supermarket, you see big pictures of delicious food. In the U.S., some supermarkets use video screens on shopping carts. These screens show ads for products as you shop. They are for people who buy on impulse and can increase sales by 30%.

'Chris Bonnington (58) is famous for climbing Everest in 1985. He has also made new climbing routes in Britain and the Alps and written books like Quest for Adventure and Everest the Hard Way. Robin Knox-Johnston (53) started his sea career in the Merchant Navy. In 1968-9, he was the first person to sail around the world alone in his yacht, Sunhaili. He also broke the transatlantic record, taking 10 days to sail from New York to the Lizard. Chris and Robin worked together to sail and climb in Greenland, and they wrote about it in their book: Sea, Ice and Rock. In 1979, Chris was working on Quest for Adventure, a book about adventure after the war. He called Robin for an interview, and Robin invited him to sail. Chris could teach Robin climbing, and Robin could teach Chris sailing. It was Chris's first time on a yacht. They sailed and then stopped. Robin's wife and daughter stayed on the boat, and Chris and Robin went to the shore to climb. The climb was hard, but Robin was calm. Chris asked Robin if he had climbed before. Robin hadn't, so Chris showed him how. Robin wanted to go down the way he did on his boat, using his arms. Chris wanted him to use his legs, but Robin went down safely. During the trip to Skye, Chris and Robin became good friends. Robin suggested they use their skills together on a trip to Greenland. Robin was a good leader. He asked everyone for their opinion before making decisions. Chris found sailing boring and hard. He liked being on land more. Robin liked fixing things on the boat. Chris felt a bit useless sometimes. The yacht was small, with six people on it. When they got to Greenland, Chris led the climbing. He was worried about Robin's safety. Climbing the Cathedral, Greenland's highest mountain, was hard. Robin was not a natural climber, but he did well. They tried to reach the top for 24 hours. They were very tired and had to turn back. Robin trusted Chris and followed him. Robin was also worried about the boat. On the way home, there was a small problem. Chris was supposed to be on watch at 4 am, but Robin didn't wake him. Chris thought Robin didn't trust him, but Robin explained it was not true. They became closer after the Greenland trip. Chris found out that Robin was a kind and sensitive person.'

**A Simple History of the Apple**
**Early Apples**
People have eaten apples for a very long time. In ancient times, people in Britain and around Swiss and Italian lakes ate wild apples. These apples were small and not like the apples we eat today. In Switzerland, people even kept apple halves for winter.
**Apples in Britain**
Around 1000 AD, the French learned how to grow fruit from the Romans. They brought this knowledge to Britain. British monks then created new types of apples. One famous apple from 1200 was the Old English Pearmain. It was a dessert apple. Another was the Costard, used for cooking. But, because of problems like droughts and wars, fewer apples were grown, and more were imported. In the 1500s, King Henry VIII sent Richard Harris to France to learn about apples. Harris brought back many apple plants and started a big orchard in Kent.
**Apples Around the World**
By the 1700s, apples were very popular in Britain. People took apples with them when they moved to places like Canada, Australia, the US, South Africa, and New Zealand. In America, a man named Johnny Appleseed planted many apple trees.
**Famous Apples**
In 1850, a farmer in Iowa found a new apple and called it 'Delicious'. It became very popular. In Australia, Maria Anne Smith found a new green apple in 1868. It became known as the 'Granny Smith' apple.
**Modern Apples**
Today, apples are grown all over the world. Most apples come from just a few types. These apples are chosen because they look good and travel well, not always because they taste the best. People now want more different kinds of apples. We need to protect the variety of apples for the future.

**Explore Worldwide - Small Groups, Big Adventures**
Explore Worldwide offers exciting travel for people who want more than just a beach holiday. We focus on new and unusual places with interesting plans. Our brochure has over 100 adventures like tours, treks, safaris, and expeditions in more than 60 countries. Most trips last 1-4 weeks.
**Small Groups**
Our groups have about 16 people. They are small and friendly, led by experts. This helps you learn more about the places we visit. You can get closer to local life and people. It's an exciting experience for everyone.
**Different Ways to Travel**
We use many types of transport, sometimes on the same trip. We travel by bus, train, minibus, boat, canoe, camel, plane, and often on foot. Each trip matches the local area.
**Who Travels with Explore?**
Our travelers are interesting people who like new experiences. They come from the UK, Europe, Australia, New Zealand, Canada, and the USA. Our trips are for anyone in good health, fit, and adaptable. Most are aged 25-55. About half are couples, and the rest travel alone.
**Activities and Interests**
Each trip is unique. We have 8 categories of adventures, each with special highlights. Many things make our trips successful, like unique places, local customs, and personal involvement.
**Cultural/Adventure**
Most trips have a strong cultural focus. Some tours focus on local cultures and historical sites. We have trips in places like Egypt, India, China, and Peru. Short walks of 2-4 hours to special sites are often included.
**Wildlife and Natural History**
Our safaris visit famous game parks and let you see animals in their natural homes. In Africa, you can explore the wild, track gorillas, or ride a canoe. We provide camping equipment, or you can stay in hotels or lodges.
**Ethnic Encounters**
Meet ethnic or tribal peoples like the Tuareg in the Sahara or the Maya in Mexico. We travel in small groups to help spread understanding between different cultures.
**Easy/Moderate Hiking**
Some trips include easy walks through the countryside, staying in hotels or village huts. Your main luggage is transported separately, and you carry a daypack.
**Major Treks**
For strong walkers, we offer treks in high mountains like the Himalayas and Andes. We stay with local people or camp. Support vehicles or animals carry heavy gear.
**Wilderness Experience**
Explore remote wilderness areas like the Amazon Rainforest or the Sahara Desert. These places offer a unique adventure.
**Sailtreks/Seatreks**
Relaxing holidays on local boats, like sailboats in Egypt or yachts in Turkey. We explore islands and unique wildlife habitats.
**Raft and River Journeys**
River trips last from a few hours to several days. You can paddle yourself or enjoy whitewater rafting with skilled guides. No experience is needed, and safety skills are taught.

'Richard Nerurkar is a long-distance runner from Britain. He is one of the top 10,000-metre runners. Richard visits a training camp in Kenya. The camp is ten miles south of the equator, near Mount Kenya. This place is called Nanyuki. Richard has been coming here for three years to train in the winter. But he never trained with Kenyan runners before. On his fourth trip, he decided to change that. He ran his first race in Kenya and stayed at the national team training camp. This is where the best Kenyan runners train for the World Cross-Country Team Championships. Richard was invited by the Kenyan coach after he finished fifth in a big race. Training at high altitude helps runners because it makes more red blood cells. This helps carry more oxygen. Kenyan runners have been very successful because of this. Richard's first race in Africa was in Nairobi. It was the first international cross-country race in Africa. Many Kenyan runners finished before him, but he still felt he did well. Richard thinks Kenyan success is not just because of altitude. Kenyan runners have a simple way of running and living. They enjoy competing. Richard wanted to know how they train. At the camp, he found out. The camp is at St Mark's College, 6,200 feet up Mount Kenya. It is basic, with few comforts. Athletes live with students and share rooms. They train three times a day: a morning run, interval training, and an afternoon run. They run about 40 kilometres each day. On Sundays, they run 20 kilometres. Life at the camp is simple. Breakfast is tea, bread, and eggs. Lunch and dinner are ugali, stew, cabbage or spinach, and tea. After running, they bathe in streams from Mount Kenya. Richard learned that Kenyan success is not just about genetics or altitude. It is also about their simple lifestyle and hard work. This might be why they are so good at running.'

'Advertising Problems
Advertising is not doing well. This is not only because of the recession. Advertising started to go down in 1989, before the recession. The problem is bigger and affects the whole world. Advertising has not changed with the economy. Advertisers think about big markets and big media, but now markets are smaller. Big brands should focus on smaller groups, but they often do not. This is a big mistake in advertising.
Think about your shopping. When you go to a supermarket, you might buy 30 to 50 items. Many of these are not advertised brands. You might buy a few advertised brands from the 15,000 items in the store. In a year, you might buy a few hundred brands. For big items like cars, you might buy one every three years. You do not buy many clothes, and most are not advertised brands. Even with other things like candy, medicine, and services, you probably do not buy more than 400 different brands a year.
There are 32,500 advertised brands, but most people buy only 400 of them. This means 96% of advertising is wasted. When you watch TV, count how many ads are for brands you buy or might buy. For most people, it is about 1 in 16 ads. This means 94% of ads are wasted. People think they are not affected by ads, but this is not true. Most people do not buy the brands they see advertised.
Advertising has to reach many people to find the right buyers. It is a cheap way to talk to many people. But, all advertising has waste. With better targeting, advertisers can reduce waste, but they can never know exactly who will buy. Even the best direct mail does not get a 100% response. This is different from face-to-face selling, where a salesman might sell to everyone he talks to. If advertisers knew who would buy, they would not need media.
If an advertiser gets one million new customers, it is very good. For soap powder, the top brands would be happy with a million new customers. Any campaign that gets 2% of the population is very successful. This is a small part of the population. To succeed, advertising needs to target its message better.'

'Solar Survivor Charles Clover visits Britain's most environmentally-friendly home. Southwell in Nottinghamshire has surprises. The first is Southwell Minster, an old cathedral with 'green' men figures carved by medieval craftsmen. The second is Britain's greenest house, the 'autonomous house', made by Robert and Brenda Vale. The Vales use rainwater for washing and drinking, recycle their waste into garden compost, and heat their house with heat from electrical appliances and their own body heat, plus that of their three children and two cats, Edison and Faraday. The house looks traditional, with a clay roof, and is 300 yards from the Minster. It matches the town's old buildings and was approved by planners even though it is in a protected area. The house is very quiet inside because it is super-insulated with special windows. Inside, you must take off your shoes. It is a sunny day, and the conservatory warms the air for the house. Vale opens windows to let air in because the house is very airtight. Even the cats have their own special door. The Vales, who teach architecture, cared about the environment before it was popular. They wrote a book on green architecture in the 1970s. They designed a house with no carbon dioxide emissions and no mains water. They use composting toilets, rainwater tanks, and copper gutters to keep water clean. Water from washing goes into the garden. They don't use a dishwasher because they don't want to use strong detergents. The house is designed to be good for the environment without being dark or medieval. The only medieval part is the hall, which is tall. The Vales pay no water bills. Last winter, the house used only nine units of electricity a day, costing about 70p. Soon, they will add solar panels to use even less electricity. The house will still use some electricity from the mains for cooking, but it will make extra electricity. There will be enough to charge an electric car. The only heating is a small wood stove, used only in the coldest winter. Is it warm in winter? One February night, Robert was reading and said it was too warm to light the fire. The room was 18C, which is comfortable because there are no draughts. In the past, people were comfortable at lower temperatures because of their clothing. The house is simple and low-tech, with few things to break. It was built cheaply, costing the same as low-cost housing. Commercial builders do not like this idea.'

'The camera never lies Arthur Conan Doyle, who created the Sherlock Holmes stories, thought he was a logical man, like a scientist. But in 1920, when he saw photos of fairies in a garden, he believed they were real proof that fairies existed. He published the photos with an article he wrote, saying fairies were amazing supernatural things. In 1939, the two women who took the photos said they were fake. They just cut out pictures of fairies from a book and put them among flowers. The photos are very beautiful. But the simple trick shows that the camera can lie. Today, we use computer programs to change our digital photos, and it is not true that photography was ever completely honest. From the start, when cameras began taking pictures, those pictures were being changed.'

'Blacksmiths Iron has always been important to people, and blacksmiths, the people who work with iron, have been seen as more than just workers. Before machines were common, blacksmiths were as respected as doctors because they made weapons, armor, and farming tools. They were also seen as artists. In the 1700s, blacksmiths made beautiful ironwork for places like St Paul's Cathedral. The fancy metalwork in French and Belgian buildings was also made by talented blacksmiths. But by the late 1960s, there were very few blacksmiths left in Britain because big factories didn't need them anymore, and new buildings didn't use nice iron designs. In the last 10 years, there has been a new interest in blacksmiths because people like decorative buildings and new interior designs. However, many designs still look old-fashioned, like 'classical' or 'Victorian-style' gates and balconies. In design stores, you often see rusty candlesticks. Luckily, there are new ideas, and some events are happening to show blacksmiths' work. One event is an exhibition by the British Artist Blacksmiths Association (BABA) at the Fire & Iron gallery in Leatherhead, Surrey. Alan Dawson, the secretary of BABA, says we might be starting a new Iron Age because people and blacksmiths are seeing things differently now. Power tools help blacksmiths work more easily, allowing them to bend and shape metal. Dawson says, 'These artists can now express themselves with metal.' About 250 pieces are in the show, from bookends to a spiral staircase. Prices start at £90 and go much higher. Most money goes to the makers, but some helps promote good ironwork. Dawson's pieces include an eight-foot gate and a lamp with a glass shade. He says his style is like drawing with metal. Many artists love working with iron. Susan May, a jeweler, says it's magical because it's soft when hot but hard when cold. Ann Catrin Evans makes door-knockers and handles inspired by castles in horror films. She likes that steel feels permanent. Iron gives people visual pleasure and a feeling of safety. It will likely be used decoratively for many years, as long as we avoid more rusty candlesticks.'

'THE DAY I STOPPED SMOKING I thought everyone would be happy, but one of my colleagues was very angry. 'What do you mean?' she shouted. 'If it was that easy, why didn't you stop years ago?' I couldn't explain how one afternoon I was a heavy smoker, and four hours later I was not. It was strange to me too. The stop-smoking session was a mix of group therapy and hypnotherapy. It happened exactly two months and three weeks ago. I didn't plan to stop and I didn't really want to. I didn't like the pressure from people who wanted me to stop smoking. Also, I had low blood pressure and a healthy family. I didn't cough or feel sick and I got over colds faster than my friends who lived healthier lives. On that normal Thursday afternoon, I went to the Birmingham session of The Easy Way to Stop Smoking to write an article about other people trying to stop. 'I won't try to stop myself, it wouldn't be fair,' I said. 'I'm here to write, not to stop, so it wouldn't be right to expect your method to work on me.' I enjoyed smoking. It made me happy. The counsellor looked at me like he knew something. We could smoke as much as we wanted, and the room was so full of smoke that we had to open the windows. I noticed that when I was told to smoke, I didn't want to, and neither did the others. I think the stop-smoking messages made sense. Just like smoking was a challenge because people didn't like it, stopping started to feel interesting. The idea of not being a smoker made me feel strong. It was a secret feeling just for me. Could I also do other big things? In many ways, it was easy. The craving for nicotine, like hunger, went away after a minute or two and lasted only four or five days. The one thing I thought would be hard without cigarettes, my work, was not a problem. I thought I couldn't work without smoking, but I was wrong. Surprisingly, being at home on weekend mornings was the hardest, and it still is. I think smoking was something I did when I was bored. Yes, I miss my cigarettes, but not too much. Each new experience as a non-smoker is different - eating out, waiting for a plane, checking into a hotel, a theatre break. These are times when I used to smoke.'

Dorothy Hodgkin is the only British woman scientist to win a Nobel prize, but many people in Britain do not know her name. Georgina Ferry, who is writing a book about Hodgkin, thinks she should be famous. Hodgkin was a great scientist and a special person. She lived through important changes in the 20th century, like the growth of women's education and science becoming more global. 
When Ferry started her research, she wanted to read about other scientists. She looked for a book about Linus Pauling, a friend of Hodgkin who also won Nobel prizes. But she could not find any books about him in her local bookshop. This made her realize that people do not find scientists' lives interesting enough to write about. Some scientists, like Peter Medawar, even said that scientists' lives are boring. This idea makes it hard for publishers to sell books about scientists.
Many people think that scientists' lives are not as interesting as those of artists or politicians. Some scientists do not like to be in the media because they do not want to seem like they are promoting themselves. But this can make science seem less interesting to young people. 
Now, more scientists are appearing in public. For example, Richard Dawkins and Steve Jones are seen on TV. This helps people see scientists as real people. Books about scientists are also changing. They used to be very serious and only about work. Now, they include personal stories, like Richard Feynman's book, which is funny and interesting.
Dorothy Hodgkin was very dedicated to her work. She discovered the structure of penicillin and vitamin B12, which won her the Nobel prize in 1964, and insulin in 1969. She also had a family with three children and a husband who was often away. Her personal life is not directly related to her work, but it shows how she balanced different parts of her life. Her story is interesting to everyone, not just because of her science. Understanding science is not harder than learning a new language; it just needs effort. It is important to know about scientists like Hodgkin, just as we know about famous writers and artists.

Margaret and her special skill
Margaret Wilkins has a special skill. She can find water underground using a forked hazel stick. Many farmers ask for her help when their wells dry up. Margaret and her husband have a business that drills wells. They use machines like drilling rigs and air-compressed hammers. But to find water, Margaret only needs her hazel stick. They are successful more than 90% of the time.
This skill is called dowsing. Dowsing is finding water, minerals, or lost things underground. Some people think it is a special sense. There are many ideas about how it works. One idea is that everything on Earth vibrates, and water vibrates more. Dowsers, like Margaret, might feel these vibrations. Some say they can even smell water.
In recent years, there has been little rain, so Margaret has been very busy. She had a waiting list of almost six weeks. Most of her customers are farmers with dry wells. Some customers have holiday homes far from water pipes. Others are building golf courses. Margaret looks for water 50 to 70 meters deep. She makes sure the water is clean and not near any waste. The water is in rock cracks, and it is important to bring it up clean. Cornwall, where she works, has a lot of minerals, so she checks for iron in the water.
Electricity is needed to run the water pump, so the well should be near power supplies. After checking everything, Margaret starts looking for water. On big areas like golf courses, she uses a map and a pendulum. The pendulum swings over places with water. Then, she walks with her hazel stick to find the exact spot. She holds the stick and feels a strange sensation when she is over water. The stick moves up when water is below. It is important to drill exactly where the stick shows. If she and her husband do not agree on the spot, they keep looking.
Margaret's skill is not just an old tradition. Many people are interested in how she does it. She calls it an 'intuitive perception of the environment'. This means she understands the area in a special way. Her skill helps her family run their well-drilling business successfully.

'We changed lives for a day! Have you ever thought about swapping lives with someone else for a day? Maybe you think it would be fun to do something different? We made it happen for four people - read what happened. Amanda (23), a young mother with two daughters, swapped lives with her friend Cindy (30), who works as a waitress at a busy London restaurant. A. Amanda's story I had never been in a place like it before. It was so dark and noisy - there were many people and a great atmosphere. It was very different from my home town, and I wasn't sure I would survive! Being a mother is a busy job, but this was something else! I had just fifteen minutes to learn how to carry a tray of drinks with one hand. The other waitresses made it look easy, but just as I was getting it, the drinks fell off the tray and crashed on the floor. I was so embarrassed, but the other waitresses laughed. Everyone makes mistakes at first! By opening time at 11.30 am, a line had already formed outside and I felt really nervous. I was worried about remembering all the orders, but that wasn't a problem because everything was automated. After a couple of hours, my feet hurt and I couldn't get used to the loud music. Every time a customer spoke to me, I had to say 'Pardon?', which was embarrassing! By the end of my shift at 5 pm, I was very tired and wanted to soak my feet in hot water. I couldn't believe it when one of the waitresses told me it had been a 'quiet' day! I never knew how tiring waitressing would be. I thought it was a job for shy people, but you need to be friendly and calm with many customers! I'm quite shy and I don't think I could handle a busy Saturday night. I wasn't impressed with the pay either. I must have been a bad waitress because even the rich Americans didn't tip me! I was very glad to get back to my children. It seems easy after waitressing! B. Cindy's story I was nervous about being a 'mum' for the day, but I was looking forward to it, too. I was told the girls were cheeky, but I thought I could handle it. I was wrong! As Amanda left for the restaurant, I had to get the two girls dressed and fed. After dropping off Sophie at school and Katie at nursery, I thought I'd have three hours of peace. Wrong! A note from Amanda reminded me that I still had to make the beds, clean the house, and do the washing. At 1 pm, I picked up Katie, went to the supermarket, and then took her home for lunch. But when I brought Sophie home from school, the real trouble started. They turned the sofa into a trampoline and played a game which involved screaming loudly! I decided to let them play, thinking they'd get tired. Wrong again. I thought I had a lot of energy, but they beat me! After much persuasion, I got them into bed by about 8 pm, but then the fun started! How many glasses of water can a child drink? I knew it was just a trick so they could come downstairs and watch TV, but it was tiring to spend all evening making deals with them. I never knew how tiring it could be looking after two small children. You don't get a second to think about yourself - and the responsibility is huge. Even so, I really enjoyed the day. Rosemary (42) runs a dairy farm. She swapped with Hilary (30), a teacher at a primary school. C. Rosemary's story On the farm, I get up at 5.30 am, so sleeping until 7 was a luxury! But I took a long time to decide what to wear. I couldn't wear overalls and boots, could I? Looking at about 400 pupils at assembly, I hoped I blended in and that my fresh face didn't make me stand out as being from the farm. After that, it was time for a maths class. The children worked in small groups, using workcards graded by difficulty - very different from when I was at school and we had to recite tables together! Then I helped with a nature project - identifying and feeding snails. By lunchtime, I was tired and looking forward to a break, but the teachers only have about five minutes to eat. There's so much to do before classes start again. I attended a staff meeting about reports and helped with athletics trials. After lunch, there was a silent reading lesson (bliss!) and then a French lesson in the video room. This was fun because all the children wanted to practise on me, which showed my rusty French. Finally, we went to the school hall for Physical Education. I was tired by now, but the children seemed to have endless energy. The hardest part of the job was standing in front of the class and speaking - even for just two minutes, it's scary. Teachers may get more holidays a year, but I think I'll stick to farming! D. Hilary's story I arrived at White House Farm at 8.30 am, bright and early, only to find out that Rosemary had been up for three hours! Rosemary's 280-acre farm has 100 Jersey cows, 15 calves, and about 800 sheep! As well as milk, she makes ice-cream, yoghurt, and cream, which is sold in shops, restaurants, and tourist places. I spent most of the morning in the ice-cream parlour, bottling milk into containers, squeezing ice-cream into cartons, and sticking on labels. It was hard to stop myself from tasting the goodies! At lunchtime, it was time to check the sheep. I drove to one of the fields and picked up a sheep that had fallen over. If the sheep are left for more than 12 hours once they have fallen over, they could die, so they have to be checked every day. What a nightmare it must be in winter! After feeding the calves, I started the milking. The process took an exhausting two-and-a-half hours. And Rosemary does this twice a day, starting at 6 am, seven days a week, 365 days a year! I found it quite a lonely day. I was surprised how much I missed the children - animals don't talk back! The worst part of the job is not being able to get away from work. The cows always have to be milked twice a day, so it's really hard to plan any time off. Rosemary will only get about three days' holiday this year. Farming seems romantic, but the reality is very different. The income is irregular and I'd hate to be at the mercy of the weather.'

'A trumpet isn't just for Christmas... Many musicians come from homes without music. Hakan Hardenberger is one of them. He is the only son of parents who do not play music. He is from a small town in southern Sweden. At 30 years old, he is famous among trumpet players. His music includes old and new pieces. He looks young and friendly, like the sound of a trumpet. Recently, he played the Hummel Trumpet Concerto in a big concert hall in London. A TV show talked about his work and life in Sweden and London. Hakan was born near Malmo. His career started with a Christmas gift when he was eight. His father liked Louis Armstrong and gave Hakan a real trumpet, not a toy. Hakan loved it and played all the time. His mother found a teacher for him, Bo Nilsson, from the Malmo Symphony Orchestra. Bo saw Hakan's talent and helped him. Hakan is thankful for having such a good teacher. Bo was very passionate about the trumpet. Hakan learned to work with the trumpet's imperfections. He found his own sound early on. Unlike John Wallace, a British trumpet player who played in orchestras, Hakan always wanted to be a solo artist. He admired Maurice Andre, a French trumpeter, and bought all his records. His parents supported his dream. At 15, he needed to study more. America was too far, so he went to Paris at 16 to study with Pierre Thibaud. Thibaud said playing in an orchestra is like digging in the garden. Hakan knew he was good, but at 17, he learned he could also connect with people through music. He entered a competition in Paris. He did not win first prize, but he enjoyed playing. He realized people listened to him even if he made mistakes. Hakan does not like to explain his gift of communication. He believes music's power is in its ability to move people.'

'New In Paperback
A. The story of Tristan Smith takes place in the made-up country of Efica. It is a special story about human power, history, and humor. The author has created a world with its own history and customs. The book is funny and shows the author's deep understanding of people. It is a difficult but rewarding read.
B. Harriet is a middle-class woman with an architect husband and her own business. She would not usually meet Sheila, a working-class woman who cares for her father and grandson, Leo. Their lives change when Leo attacks Harriet's son, Joe. After the court case, both boys do not talk about it. Leo, who was a good student, does not say why he did it. Joe gets better physically but becomes quiet. Harriet is very worried about her son. Sheila feels guilty and asks to meet Harriet. They become friends. The author is good at showing how people deal with big changes in their lives.
C. This book was nominated for the Booker prize. It tells the story of a small Scottish island and its people over many years. The story includes important moments in Scottish history. The main character, Throfinn Ragnarson, disappears and returns after World War II. He learns to appreciate the simple life of his ancestors.
D. After a successful book, the author wrote a sequel with the same gentle humor and observations of family life. Fifteen years after her daughter's death, Aurora Greenway is almost seventy. She has a friend, Rosie Sunlap. Aurora is charming and kind, and Rosie helps her with her life. By the end of the book, Aurora sees that time has passed and a new generation is important. The author shows the sadness in everyday life and how events can be random.
E. Six different people are brought together by millionaire Logan Urquhart to sail around the South Pacific islands on his yacht, the Ardent Spirit. The author uses beautiful language to describe their personal journeys. Each person learns about themselves during the trip. The author uses strong images to show themes of memory and awareness.'

'Five Careers Rebecca Cripps talks to five women about their jobs: the good parts, the bad parts, and their usual workday. A. THE BRAIN SURGEON Name: Anne Age: 34 ANNE'S DAY "I wake up at 6.30am, go to the gym at 7am, and start work at 8am. I begin surgery at 8.30am. I do surgeries all day on Monday and Wednesday, and some Friday afternoons. Most surgeries take three hours, but some take all day. Sometimes I work ten hours without eating or going to the bathroom. Deciding when and how to operate can be stressful. I don't feel stressed during surgery, but I worry about the next day. Brain surgery is often a last option for patients, but when it works, it's amazing. From 10am to 1pm, I talk to patients about their surgeries. I like this and find it easy to talk to them. If they are upset, I try to comfort them, but I don't always have enough time. I leave work between 6pm and 8pm. Some nights and weekends, I am on call and carry my pager. On holidays, I worry for the first three days about my patients, and I dream about surgery at night. I find it hard to relax." B. THE SENIOR DESIGNER Name: Marita Age: 31 MARITA'S DAY "I wake up at 7.45am, leave home by 8.20am, take the train, and arrive at work by 9.15am. On Monday at 10.30am, we have a meeting to talk about our work and any problems. We work in teams. My team has three senior designers, a company partner, and a junior designer. Only ten to fifteen percent of the work is design; the rest is production. I get a brief from the client and spend three or four weeks designing and developing the project. Then I show my ideas to the client. If they agree, we plan the budget and hire photographers and illustrators. I talk to the printers and make sure everything is on time. I manage people and need to communicate well. When their work is ready, I send it to the printers. Managing many jobs can be stressful. Deadlines are always close, and no day is the same. Lunch is at 1pm for an hour. We try to go out, but sometimes I eat sandwiches and work. It's great when the client likes the designs, but disappointing if they don't. I get home at 7.30pm or later. It's hard to relax when I'm busy." C. THE CHAUFFEUR Name: Linda Age: 42 LINDA'S DAY "I wake up at 7am most days, but two or three times a week, I meet a flight and wake up between 4.30am and 5am. At 10.30 or 11am, I might go for a bike ride or swim. Driving is a sitting job, so I watch my diet and exercise. I have a big breakfast and snacks during the day. People ask me about restaurants and shops, so I need to know the area well. Many jobs are booked in advance, so I can check routes. Not everyone is polite. Some passengers are rude, but most are nice, and I have good relationships with regular clients. Sometimes I hear conversations in the car and have to focus on driving. The press has tried to make me talk about clients, but I don't. I work seven days a week, up to fifteen hours a day. I try to sleep by 11pm." D. THE LANDSCAPE GARDENER Name: Tracy Age: 27 TRACY'S DAY "I wake up at 7am, leave home at 7.30am, and start work. My assistant and I maintain gardens we designed. We do some commercial jobs, but mostly private gardens. We spend about an hour and a half at each house. At 11am, we eat breakfast at a cafe. In summer, I work until 10pm; in winter, until 4.30pm. The office is at home, so I check messages and calls when I return. If someone wants a garden, I meet them in the evening. We use old materials to make gardens look old. Sometimes people have bad ideas, but it's satisfying to see a garden finished. It's hard to relax because I hear the business phone. I sleep well because the work is physical, and I'm tired. I'm not very strong, but I'm fit. It's a tough job, but it lets me be creative." E. THE CIVIL ENGINEER Name: Zena Age: 27 ZENA'S DAY "I arrive at the site by 8.30am. I'm an assistant engineer, looking after bridges and a wall that stops cars from driving into a quarry. I check that the contractors follow the plan and safety rules. I help solve problems. The contractors start at 6am, so I first check with the clerk of works about what happened since I left. The rest of the day depends on what he tells me. I look at paperwork or answer design questions. Lunch is usually for half an hour between 2pm and 2.30pm, but I eat as I go. When contractors eat, it's easier to check the site. We check their work, which can cause problems, so we need to be open with them. I see the main engineer once a day. If something important happens, I act before telling them. I leave the site at about 6pm and am always on call."

**Careers: Six People Talk About Their Work Day**
**A. Credit Card Executive**
I wake up at 6 am and get to the office by 7.30 am. I work with credit card users and manage the Membership Rewards program in Europe. I talk to current card users, find new ones, and work with partner companies. I start my day by organizing and checking emails. I handle advertising for the membership program, so I meet with marketing staff and advertising agencies. I have meetings most of the day, but I keep my door open for questions. I travel to different markets in Europe once or twice a week. When I'm in London, I leave work between 6.30 pm and 7.00 pm.
**B. Record Company Executive**
