He was late for dinner, and his stepmother said, 'You're old enough to come home on time. If you won't come home, stay in tonight.' She was a strong woman with fair skin, a little grey in her hair, and a patient smile. She spoke seriously, but Michael, feeling sad, didn't really hear her. He was still thinking about the boys laughing at him.'

**Careers Advice**
Are you unhappy with your job but don't know how to change it? Kitty Doherty has some advice. Many people who want to change jobs go to a careers adviser. You will write a short history about yourself and take some tests called 'psychometrics'. After the tests, you get a report with career suggestions and possible retraining needed.
I tried Career Analysts, a big company that gives career advice. The test felt like a science exam. I was with about ten people, answering questions quickly. It wasn't about passing or failing. The tests included finding mistakes in lists and matching shapes. After the test, I talked with an adviser. He gave me a report with his thoughts and advice. I agreed with most of it, but I was surprised I did poorly in science and technical tests. I was glad to hear I made the right choice with journalism.
Changing your career doesn't always mean a big change. Last March, Donna Laney, 25, lost her job as a marketing manager. Her friends told her to try Career Analysts. 'Losing my job was a chance to look at my career,' says Donna. She found out she was good at design but had to think about the cost of retraining. Other ideas included working in the Far East for a year. She decided to use her skills in a new job as a Public Relations officer. Career Analysts helped her see what she wanted to do.
Some people feel they couldn't have changed without help. Juliet Greene, 26, went to Career Counselling Services. She worked at a bank for six years and wanted a new challenge. The tests showed she liked sciences. After four sessions with an adviser, she decided to study geology. She plans to start a degree in it. Juliet thinks the advice was worth the money and feels happier now.
But careers advice doesn't work for everyone. Amanda Margetts, 24, a sales representative, didn't find it helpful. She wanted new ideas but didn't like the options because they meant less money or more training. She felt a friend could have given similar advice.

'Fun at the Dentist's? If you visit W. Lloyd Jerome's dental office in Glasgow, you will see bright paintings on the wall and a nice blue couch for patients. Jerome says, 'Half of the people only go to the dentist when they have pain. They are scared.' To help with this, he tries to make his office a place where people are not afraid. He does not wear a white coat because it makes people think of pain. Jerome believes dental visits should be relaxing and even fun. This is surprising because many people think of dental visits as painful. Jerome says, 'If people are relaxed and happy, they will forget bad experiences.' He uses virtual-reality headsets to help people relax. 'We were the first in Britain to use them, and people like them. During the first check-up, patients sit on the blue couch and watch a film about underwater animals while I check their teeth. Then, they see a video tour of their mouth.' Many patients enjoy this. The office also smells nice, like oranges, not like a dentist's office. Jerome says, 'I want people to know it's different here. Smell is important. The usual dentist smell can make people nervous.' I found the smell very nice. Jerome is known as Glasgow's most stylish dentist, but he is serious about his work. Relaxation is important, but good treatment is most important. He uses a tool that sprays warm water to clean teeth, not scraping them. It feels strange at first, but it is not painful if you are relaxed. Five years ago, Jerome went to the USA to learn about dental techniques. 'I learned that if you make it easy for the patient, it's easy for you too,' he says. He thinks this is the start of a change in British dentistry. A patient arrives, and Jerome offers him tea and asks what video he wants to watch. The patient seems to enjoy this special treatment. The office feels more like a beauty salon than a regular dentist's office.'

**Chocolate: A Sweet Story**
Chocolate comes from South America. Today, it is a big business around the world. In the UK, people spend over £230 million on chocolate at Easter. This is 8% of all chocolate sales. Only at Christmas do people eat more chocolate.
Chocolate comes from the cacao plant. This plant was first grown by the Aztec, Toltec, and Mayan people in Central America over 3,000 years ago. The cacao tree is a tropical plant. It grows in Africa, South and Central America, the West Indies, and South-East Asia. The fruit of this tree is the size of a melon and has 20-40 seeds. When dried, these seeds become cacao beans, which are used to make chocolate. In English, they are often called cocoa beans. This is a mistake from the 17th century.
The Aztecs used cocoa beans as money. They also made a drink called xocoatl, which means 'bitter water' in their language. The drink was made with spices and used for special events. The Spanish liked it better with cinnamon and sugar. But it took another 100 years for the recipe to spread in Europe.
In the late 17th century, chocolate houses opened in Europe's big cities. People went there to drink chocolate. Until the last century, chocolate drinks were made from solid blocks of chocolate melted in hot water. In 1826, CJ van Houten from the Netherlands made chocolate powder by taking out most of the cocoa butter from the beans.
The chocolate bar we know today started in 1847. A company in Bristol, Fry and Sons, mixed cocoa butter with chocolate liquor and sugar to make a solid block you could eat. Later, a Swiss company added milk to make milk chocolate.
In the early 1900s, French companies led the British chocolate market. In 1879, the English company Cadbury named their factory Bournville, hoping to sound French. But in 1905, Cadbury made the Dairy Milk bar, which became very popular. It was advertised as healthy because of the milk.
Today, people in Britain eat about four chocolate bars each week. To sell more, companies make chocolate bars into ice creams, drinks, or desserts. Meanwhile, cacao farmers still struggle because of low cocoa bean prices in the 1980s. Many small farmers went out of business. So, think of them when you enjoy your next chocolate bar.

'THE SHELL ARTIST Peter Cooke is 83 years old and is very good at making art with shells. He wants to try new things like making paper and working with feathers, but for now, he is happy making beautiful objects from shells. He shows me his work in his apartment and says, "Tell me if I am boring you." But he is not boring; he is very interesting and charming. He points to some shell ornaments above his fireplace and says he doesn't mind if people don't buy them because he loves them. He never planned to sell his work, but friends encouraged him to have an exhibition. Five years ago, he had an exhibition in London, and 70% of his work was sold. His second exhibition opened yesterday. The pieces are expensive, with some costing around £2,000. There are 86 pieces in the exhibition, with prices starting at £225. Cooke says he doesn't set the prices and is happy to talk about them. He believes no one else makes art like his, and the gallery owner told him that people will want his pieces because he will stop making them one day. Cooke wishes he started this art earlier in life because he could have made even more wonderful things. He says he is more limited now because of his age, but his work is still very special. His art is different from the shell items you find in seaside shops. He makes boxes with tiny shells, pictures from shells, and flowers that look real. Cooke has his own way of working and uses materials he finds. He uses cardboard from shirts for flower bases, glue from a sail-maker, and washing-up liquid to clean the shells. He says he has an idea of what he wants to do, and it just happens, but his work shows great attention to detail. Cooke looks for beautiful and tiny shells in places like France, Thailand, Mexico, South Africa, and the Philippines. He only collects dead shells and defends himself against people who say he is taking too many shells. He says people walking on the beach break more shells than he collects, and the sea also breaks them. He would never take shells with living creatures inside. Cooke's work is very beautiful, and he believes it is worth collecting the shells.'

'The Schoolgirl Model When 15-year-old Kira Langer is not traveling to exciting places and appearing on magazine covers, she is probably studying for her school exams. Jane Laidlaw finds out more. 'I'm afraid Kira will be a little late,' the receptionist at the agency told me. 'Oh, fine,' I said, 'no problem.' I was trying to forget all the bad things I had read about models, like being difficult and vain. And now she was going to be late. How late? An hour? Three hours? Maybe she wouldn't come at all. What if she decided to go to the hairdresser instead of talking to me? If she was late, she might be in a bad mood and not answer my questions. But when Kira, the winner of the Looks magazine supermodel competition, walked in, she was smiling, relaxed, and said sorry for being late. She was with her mother. Kira was not wearing expensive designer clothes but a simple black dress and trainers. She was very friendly, very tall, and very pretty. All models under 16 must have an adult with them when they work, she explained. Her mother looked like a normal mum, proud of her daughter. Kira seems a bit surprised by her new fame, which makes sense because it was not planned. Her older sister wanted her to enter the model competition. 'She saw the competition and said I should try it,' Kira remembers. 'I said no, but she sent some photos anyway.' When they called to say she was a finalist, she was at school. Being chosen for the final made Kira confident, and she did very well. She won easily, and the Select model agency in London offered her work. Kira now finds it hard to manage her two lives. But her friends and teachers are used to having a star among them. 'They're really proud of me,' she says. However, some people at her school are not nice about her success. 'They say I think too much of myself.' This must be hard for Kira because she is not self-important. But she says, 'They think that because I'm a model now, I can't stay the same. But the only thing that's changed is I'm more confident - not in a bad way, but I can stand up for myself more.' As a busy model, her social life is affected. The Select agency can call anytime and tell her she has a job the next day. 'If my friends are going out, I can't say I'll come because I don't know what I'm doing the next day. I can't really make plans, and if I do, they sometimes get canceled, but my friends are good about it. They don't say, "Oh, you're always going off modeling now, you never have time for us".' Kira has the looks, ability, and support to have a great career. Not many people can say that before they finish school. I am about to finish the interview with the girl who has it all, and I ask what she would like to do if she wasn't a model. She pauses and replies: 'I'd like to do what you're doing.'

**Father and Son Search for Gold**
Terence and Chris Madden are a father and son team. They have traveled from cold Canada to hot Africa to find gold. Terence is an explorer, and Chris is a mineral expert. They think their mine on a Welsh mountain has a lot of gold. After ten years of digging, they believe they are close to finding gold worth five million dollars. Terence, who is 68 and from Liverpool, says, "We are finding gold as we dig. We just need to dig a few more meters."
Their search started when Terence read about gold in the "Dolgellau gold belt" in Wales. They read old mining journals and newspapers at the Welsh National Library. They chose the best area to dig. They cleared the land, found some gold, and spent ten years getting permission to dig. They also removed old cars and rubbish. They dug out 150 tonnes of rock to make a tunnel and a 10-meter shaft.
Now, they need more money. They spent their savings and need someone to give them £50,000 to dig a bit more. Chris says, "It looks hard to find someone to help, but we have some people to ask."
People in the area are interested in the gold search. Dolgellau, a town that relies on tourists, is hopeful. Peter Woolven, who manages the Royal Ship Hotel, says, "If they find gold, more people might visit. But I hope not too many people come and dig up the hillside."
The Welsh gold industry was big in the late 1880s, but now it is small. One of the last mines, Clogau-St David's, closed recently. But some people are still looking for gold. George Hall, another gold seeker, plans to dig on the other side of the hill. Hall, who is 70, says, "Searching for gold is exciting. Maybe I will be lucky this time."

'IN HOT WATER Rachel Mills is a scientist who works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel Mills teaches and studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemical processes in the sea. She is a teacher at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle, like a small car, and dives three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 'Inside,' she says, 'there is not much space. I can touch the two pilots.' They are used to these conditions. They cannot stand up or move, and they must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours - three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours collecting rock and water samples, and then three hours to go back up to the surface. 'If anything happens, and you have a problem and need to get to the top quickly, you can press a panic button.' The outside drops away, leaving a small escape vessel that goes quickly to the surface. 'No one's tested it yet, but I don't think it would be a nice journey.' 'I didn't know how I would feel the first time I got into the vehicle. It was on the deck of a ship, and I got in with an instructor. He then explained the emergency procedures, including what to do if the pilot had a heart attack! They were testing me to see how I would react in such a small place.' Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year she dived with a Russian crew. 'We went to a place five days west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, is a big area of underwater volcanoes, their chimneys blowing out black smoke. It is where the Atlantic Ocean comes together. The Russian team was putting some scientific equipment there to study the effect of a multi-national programme that would make a hole 150 metres through a volcano.' When she is not at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. 'Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research into the "black smokers".' This is another name for underwater volcanoes - water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. This comes out at a speed of one metre per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees. 'The only time I was scared was when I first went down with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-metre rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a big bang as the shock waves hit our vehicle, and I thought, "I'm going to die." We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When it didn't happen, we couldn't believe it. The relief was incredible - we were still alive!' 'It's such an adventure diving down to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time I look out of the window and see those chimneys, there is such a sense of wonder. Here I am on the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I had studied the black smokers for three years for my PhD. When I got down there and saw them for real, it was such an amazing feeling.''

I was dirty, smelly, hungry, and a bit suntanned. It was the end of my Inter-Rail holiday. My body was very tired. My mind couldn't handle more foreign timetables, money, or languages. "Never again," I said, as I arrived home. I said the same thing the next year. And the next. I just needed to buy one train ticket, and because I was under twenty-five years old, I could travel anywhere in Europe for a whole month. Sleeping in a train corridor is different from sleeping in a bed. The train's movement helps you sleep deeply. Carrying everything in a backpack makes travel simple. You might even throw away socks that smell bad or books you finish reading. This is the Inter-Rail spirit. You don't need to think too much. Just have a ticket in your hand. This train ticket lets young people travel to many countries quickly. On my first trip, my friends and I didn't know how special this ticket was. We thought it was just a cheap way to go to our camp-site in southern France. But we wanted to travel more because there was always another country to see. And it didn't cost us extra. We were not very interested in culture. This was our first holiday without parents, like many other Inter-Railers. We made our own plans and only saw the easiest sights. We wanted to escape guided tours and do something different. I was happy to see just the view from the station in many places. We were there to enjoy ourselves. We were like other Inter-Railers, sharing train floors, food, water, money, and music. The excitement of travel comes from seeing a place that was just a name before. It feels like the city is real only when the train arrives, and you see it with your own eyes. You can understand Europe better by seeing the changing landscapes and different lifestyles. Everyone knows what is there, but it means more when you see it yourself. This is why other people's holiday photos are boring. The train trip won't show you new things in the world, but it is a valuable personal experience. Europe is big, and Inter-Rail helps people see this, even if it takes time.

'It is very disappointing to arrive at an airport in another country and find out that your baggage is not there. You might have to wear the same clothes for hours or days until the airline finds your luggage. Sometimes, you may be in a different climate and have to wear clothes that are not right for the weather. Airlines do not often say how many bags they lose, but it happens to many travelers. Even the best airlines make mistakes, and they cannot always make sure your luggage is on the same flight, especially if you have to change planes. 
Airlines ask you to check in early to give enough time for your baggage to be loaded onto the plane. Minimum connecting times (MCTs) are the shortest times to transfer between flights, and they are also longer to help with baggage transfers. Usually, this system works well. But extra security checks and air traffic problems can delay flights and cause baggage issues. Human error or accidents, like a torn-off label, can also cause problems. These issues are worse at big airports, called 'hubs', because they handle many bags. For example, last year, London's Heathrow airport had over 41 million passengers, with nine million changing planes. British Airways had two million transfer passengers at Heathrow, mostly moving between Terminal 1 and Terminal 4. Even good airports like Amsterdam, Copenhagen, Singapore, and Zurich have bad days. 
The risk of losing baggage is higher at some airports. In the United States, Miami airport is known for losing luggage when passengers connect to Latin America. To avoid losing your baggage, choose direct flights if you can and check in early. If you must change planes, try to fly with the same airline and allow more time between flights. Label your luggage inside and out with your home and holiday addresses, and include flight numbers. If your luggage is lost, contact the airline official in the baggage hall and fill out a property irregularity report (PIR) before leaving the airport.'

'The Kingfisher Wildlife photographer Charlie James knows a lot about the kingfisher. This bird is blue-green and lives near streams and rivers. It eats fish. Old trees hang over the stream, making some parts of the water dark. The main colors are soft greens, browns, and yellows from the sunlight. The kingfisher flies very fast and straight, like a flash of light. It is small, but very powerful. Charlie James loved kingfishers from a young age. He cannot say exactly why he likes them so much. There are many stories about kingfishers. In Greek myth, a moon goddess became a kingfisher. Another story says the kingfisher flew so high that its top became blue like the sky, and its bottom was burned by the sun. This story has some truth. Kingfishers do not have blue color in their feathers. The feathers reflect light, which makes them look blue. The color can change to green when the light angle changes. Many wildlife photographers love kingfishers. They are shy but can be watched from a hidden place. Charlie James first hid under an old blanket to watch them. The bird came close, but it took him four years to take a good picture. He spent a lot of time by streams with kingfishers. School was a problem because it took time away from the birds. He missed classes and did not do well in school. But people noticed his interest in kingfishers. At 16, he worked for a nature magazine. Later, he became a freelance wildlife film cameraman. Now, he wants to make a film about kingfishers with no talking, just beautiful pictures. He likes simple things and wants to show the colors of the kingfisher's wings. His photos show his feelings, but he knows there is more to his love for kingfishers than his work can show.'

'Conducting an Orchestra Conducting an orchestra is not easy. Anne Inglis talks to five new conductors about their work. A. ANNE MANSON Anne Manson, 30, wanted to watch conductor Claudio Abbado in Vienna. She ended up helping him because his assistant was not there. She was not nervous. Anne is American and works with a London opera company. She is becoming known in Europe with help from the British Arts Council. She has helped Abbado many times since then. B. ANDREW CONSTANTINE Andrew Constantine, 31, says the hardest part of being a conductor is getting the right chances. He won a big competition in 1991 after trying twice before. Winning gave him many chances to perform and work with a famous conductor. He hopes people will not only remember him for the competition. The English Chamber Orchestra invited him back, which is good for his career. C. WASFI KANI Wasfi Kani started Pimlico Opera. She enjoys the long practice time for operas. She began conducting in her late twenties. After university, she worked in London until Pimlico Opera became professional. Lessons with Sian Edwards were important for her. She likes the challenges of opera and working with singers. D. ROGER VIGNOLES Roger Vignoles, 48, is surprised to be conducting but finds it interesting. He was a musician in an opera house and worked with good conductors. Last year, he directed Handel's Agrippina from the piano. It was easier than he thought. He uses all his past experience in music. He is open to trying new things. E. WAYNE MARSHALL In 1986, conductor Simon Rattle noticed Wayne Marshall, now 32. Marshall soon conducted a musical in London. It was hard, but he was firm with the musicians. He gives clear instructions and is not afraid to say what he wants. He never studied conducting formally but is determined and knows what he likes.'

'Theme Park Visits If you want to take children to a theme park, there are many to choose from in Britain. We asked five families to try the best ones. Fun Island - The Burns family Last year we went to a big theme park in the US, so we thought Fun Island might not be as exciting. But we were surprised. The park is good for young children, so our three-year-old had fun too. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There is a special dodgems ride for very young kids, which was a big hit. For older children, there are scarier rides, like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! After five hours, Steve and I were tired, but the children wanted to stay because they were having so much fun. Our only complaint is that the park could have a better atmosphere and scenery. But the staff are very helpful, and the park is clean, well-organized, and safe. Wonderland - The McMillan family None of us had been to a theme park before, so we didn't know what to expect. We thought Oscar might be too young, but he loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, with small models of famous buildings! The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a road. We spent six hours there and liked that there were places to rest. The park looks nice, and the staff are friendly. There is something for everyone, even adults. Adventure World - The Jeffree family After seven hours, we still had more to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus with a great trapeze act. We went on the Terror Line, and although the girls were scared, they said they liked it. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. For younger children, Toy Land is fun. The children looked at the new ride, Fear Factor, but they were too small to go on it! The park is well designed, so waiting in line isn't too boring. It's very clean, and the staff are great. On one ride, I couldn't sit with both girls, so a staff member went with one of them. The Great Park - The Langridge family We arrived at one o'clock and were sad that the park was only open until 5 p.m. This is a great theme park for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. I'm usually scared, but I had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slow and then gets exciting. We waited for half an hour for Lightning River, and then it was over quickly! I didn't go on the Big Leap, but it looked fun if you are brave. If the children were older, they might find it a bit boring, but they were the right age and loved it. Fantasy World - The Break-all family The park says there is 'No Limit to the Fun', and we agree. Europe's tallest roller-coaster, the Rocket, is very high, and Ben thought it was the scariest ride, but Jennie said the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters above the ground, was worse! There are about twelve main rides, and the older children went on them many times. Sarah was too small for some rides, but she liked the Long Slide. We found the staff were sometimes nice, but not always. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World. We wouldn't tell the kids we were leaving early.'

'Running a business in the countryside Five women talk about their experiences starting a business in the countryside. A. 'My customers are friends,' says CHRISTINE HOGAN, who has a computer design business. She makes over £200,000 a year and has four full-time workers. 'My husband and I moved from London to the countryside when our children were small. I wanted a job I could do at home. I had worked with computers before, so my husband suggested I start a computer design business. It needed a lot of money and was hard at first. But I was careful and told the bank if I was spending too much. Working from home saves money, and I can work in the evening if I want. It is a small business. People from the area usually come to us to get their work.' B. 'I enjoy being independent,' says MAGGY SASANOW, who designs greeting cards at home. 'I studied art at university and wanted to work in a museum. But when I got married, we moved to the countryside, where there were no museum jobs. So I started my own business and make 50 different greeting cards to sell to museums. I work in a big room upstairs. The bad thing about working from home is there is always something to do, like mowing the lawn. I get business by word of mouth and don't advertise. People send work from London because I am cheaper than other artists. Working alone, I don't share ideas with others, but there are more good things than bad.' C. 'It has been hard at times,' says DELIA TURNER, who makes curtains. 'I started my business eight years ago. At first, my business grew, and in two years, my earnings went from £24,000 to £80,000. I used to have six full-time workers. But I had to let them go because the economy got worse, which was hard because there are not many jobs here. Now, I make curtains at home with my husband's help and use women who work from their homes. I have to lower my prices when needed and look for new chances.' D. TESSA STRICKLAND runs a children's book publishing business from her farmhouse. 'I moved to the countryside three years ago for two reasons. First, because London was too expensive, and second, because I love the country. I like working when I want to. Most of my money comes from deals with Australia, the Far East, and North America, so I have to take calls at odd hours. The bad thing is that it takes discipline to stop working. I publish children's books from different cultures, working with authors and artists. All my work experience was in London, so I felt very alone at first.' E. MEG RIVERS runs a cake business and a shop, making £250,000 a year and has six workers, some part-time. 'I started ten years ago at home. I am very interested in health, so I started making fruit cakes with good flour and eggs. Then friends and family asked for cakes, and soon I was sending cakes all over the country. Seven years ago, I rented a small building, and everything is made there. We have a baker, an assistant, and a professional cake decorator. I don't cook now, as I manage the business side. My biggest problem has been the financial side because we didn't have a lot of money to start with.'

'Meet the Amazing Watkins Family The sons are musicians and composers, and Dad makes the instruments. Matthew Rye reports. Families with musicians are not rare. But it is special to find a family with music writers, performers, and an instrument maker. John and Hetty Watkins, schoolteachers from South Wales, needed a cello for their ten-year-old son, Paul. They found it was very expensive. John says, 'We looked at different dealers, and it was clear it would cost a lot.' So, he thought about making one himself. He found the Welsh School of Instrument Making near his home and went to evening classes once a week for about three years. 'After making a few violins and violas, he tried his first cello,' Paul, now 28, says. 'It was really good. He made me another one later, and I used it until a few months ago.' John has now retired from teaching to make instruments full-time. He makes up to twelve violins a year. Selling one to the famous American player Jaime Laredo was 'the icing on the cake'. Paul and his younger brother, Huw, started playing music when they were young. Paul first played the piano: 'As soon as I was big enough to reach the keys, I played,' he remembers. But soon, he wanted to play the cello. 'My parents wanted me to play the violin because Dad played the viola and needed another violin for his music group. I tried it for six weeks but didn't like it. I liked the cello player in Dad's group. I thought he was cool when I was six or seven. He gave me lessons, and that's how it started. Later, they suggested my brother play the violin too, but he didn't want to.' 'My parents were supportive and relaxed,' Huw says. 'I wouldn't have liked being pushed. Instead of feeling jealous of Paul's success, I wanted to be like him.' Now 22, Huw is becoming known as a pianist and composer. Meanwhile, John's cello helped Paul a lot. With it, Paul won the string final of the BBC Young Musician of the Year competition. At 20, he became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra, using his father's cello until last year. Now, he has a Francesco Rugeri cello from the Royal Academy of Music. 'Dad hasn't said anything about me changing cellos, but he tried both and said my new one is nice! The only thing Dad's cello doesn't have is the power to fill large concert halls. It will get better with age, like my Rugeri, which is 304 years old.' Soon, Paul will be on TV playing the Rugeri in Elgar's Cello Concerto in the new series, Masterworks. 'The history of the performance doesn't change how I play,' he says. 'I will always play it my way.' But Paul can't watch himself on TV because he is playing at the Cheltenham Festival the same night. Huw also can't watch because his String Quartet is playing in London at the Wigmore Hall that evening. John and Hetty will have to be busy to follow all their sons' musical events in the coming weeks.'

'Taking Care of the Countryside THE NATIONAL TRUST The National Trust is a group that wants to protect the British countryside. Gill Page visits the Lleyn Peninsula in North Wales and talks to Gareth Roberts, a warden who works for the Trust. Gareth says a warden needs common sense and must be good with people. He talks to farmers, visitors, and builders. Gareth grew up on the Lleyn Peninsula and worked on his parents' farm. He got the warden job because he knows the area well and has farming experience, even though he didn't have formal training. Gareth still helps on his parents' farm, which helps him understand farmers' problems. He is also strong enough for the job, which includes building fences, planting trees, and making walls. Gareth has learned more about nature conservation since working with the Trust. He remembers collecting flowers and bird nests as a child and now sees how farming has changed the countryside. He says it's not the farmers' fault; they followed government advice. When Gareth started, farmers and conservationists disagreed. Now, they talk and understand each other better. Gareth's work includes conservation, letting people visit Trust land, planting trees, and meeting farmers. He likes finishing projects, but he also spends time on paperwork. Gareth loves his job, even though he is always working. He enjoys talking to most visitors but dislikes when some people act like they own the place. If you have common sense and like outdoor work, you might want to be a warden like Gareth. But don't expect a job on the Lleyn Peninsula soon!'

'The Netball Captain In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain. Kendra Slowinski is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked her. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice. I might see cars slow down, but that's all.' 'My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. 'I have a strict plan to be very fit for them.' These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries taking part. 'We'll have support from people here, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to make netball more popular in this country. Because we are playing here, there will be more pressure. People will expect us to start with a good game.' Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'As far as I know, we have always beaten them, but they will be exciting to play. They have lots of skill.' The England team is ranked fourth in the world. But, as Kendra says, the World Championships will be hard. 'You have to play every day, there's no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But the Championships are different because there's only one chance.' In the fifteen years she has been playing at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. On the court, players are more aggressive. 'You don't train so hard not to win,' says Kendra. 'But after the game, we are all friendlier.' Netball is also more scientific now with fitness testing. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. 'As captain, I need a strong mind and to lead by example. I support and encourage the team.' 'From the start, my netball career was carefully planned,' she says. 'I decided some time ago that this competition would be my last as a player.' She will probably coach young players in the future, but now she is focused on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye.'

'SPECIALIST MUSIC SCHOOLS How can you help a child with great musical talent? It is not always easy to know how to support their gift. Some parents might not notice their child's need until the child becomes upset or difficult. Most schools can help children who are good at subjects like math or English, but musically talented children need special help. Ordinary schools might not have this help, especially if music is not important there. Children with musical talent might do well at a specialist music school. There are five music schools in Britain. These schools help talented children aged seven to eighteen to improve their skills with the help of professional musicians. At these schools, children spend one third to one half of their day on music activities. They have individual lessons, play in orchestras, learn voice training, conducting, and music theory. They also practice for several hours a day in special rooms, sometimes with a teacher. The rest of their time is for important subjects like English, math, science, and languages. These schools are independent, with small classes and many teachers. Most children live at the school full-time. This means they grow up with others who have the same interests. What are the problems? One problem is the cost; it is expensive (PS12,000-PS17,000 a year for boarders). But schools try to help with scholarships and financial aid. Also, not all parents want their children to live away from home at a young age. School directors worry about children as young as seven in such a strict environment. They want to help children become well-rounded people. Being apart from others can be stressful for musically talented children. Their talent might change as they grow up, and pressure to succeed can make them feel like failures. But schools watch each child's progress and offer help if needed. Many former students say they learned a lot from the music teaching, but some worry about the limited academic program. Many talented children are also smart and want more academic challenges. It might be better to wait until the child is older and can decide for themselves about a specialist education. Children who are good at both music and academics might do well in a regular school with a good music program or by taking music lessons at a music college on Saturdays. But this is not possible for families who live far from big cities.'

'An eye for detail Artist Susan Shepherd is famous for her flower paintings. Her big garden around her house gives her many ideas for her art. The garden has many of her favorite flowers, like tulips and poppies. Some plants grow everywhere in the garden. There is a nice mix of colors and shapes in the flower beds along the path in the garden. The people who lived there before loved gardening and left plants that Susan likes. She also got the gardener, Danny, from them. 'It was really his garden,' she says. 'We got along well. At first, he didn't like some of my ideas, but when I said I wanted to paint them, he understood.' Susan likes to paint one plant at a time, not the whole garden. Sometimes she paints a group of plants, but usually, she picks them and takes them to her studio. 'I don't paint everything at once,' she says. 'I paint one flower, which can take a few days, then I add another one. Sometimes it takes years to finish.' Her busiest time is spring and early summer when tulips and poppies bloom. 'They all bloom together, and you're so busy,' she says. She also likes how flowers change as they get older. With tulips, for example, 'you put them in water, and after a day, they change shape. They open and look amazing. At first, they seem boring, but they change with twists and turns.' Susan has always liked plants: 'I studied botany at school and collected wild flowers,' she says. 'I didn't like garden flowers then; I thought they looked fake. I liked wild flowers because they grew in hard places, like rocks.' Now, her garden has plants from faraway places, but they grow well there. She lets the garden grow freely, like an aunt who lets children play as long as they don't break anything. With two art shows coming up, and many flowers to paint, she doesn't have much time for the garden. She has another gardener now, but she knows she needs to work in the garden to stay connected to her art.'

'Keeping the holiday-makers happy Sarah Sutherland-Pilch is a chalet girl. She talks to Veronica Lee while making beds and cooking dinners. This is Sarah's second year as a chalet girl. She is 24 years old and from West Sussex. People call her Pilch. Sarah works in Val d'Isère, France. She cooks and cleans for visitors who come to ski and stay in chalets. Chalets are wooden houses typical of the area. Sarah finished her studies in French and History of Art at Oxford Brookes University last summer. She says being a chalet girl is not a career, but a fun way to spend a year or two before settling down. 'It's a good way to meet people. I meet successful people every week.' Sarah does not live in the chalet. She wakes up at 7 a.m. and walks about a mile to the chalet, which can have up to 18 guests each week. She has her own breakfast before making breakfast for the guests. 'They get porridge, eggs, cereals, fruit, and croissants.' After breakfast, around 9:30 a.m., Sarah cleans up and either makes afternoon tea or cleans the rooms. 'Cleaning is the worst part of the job,' she says. By 11 a.m., she is ready to ski. She skis as much as she can. 'On a good day, we can ski until 4:30 p.m.' Sarah goes back to the chalet to prepare dinner and takes a shower before cooking. 'It's bad if you sleep,' she says. Dinner is three courses and is served at 8 p.m. Coffee is usually ready by 10 p.m. Sarah cleans up after dinner and loads the dishwasher. 'I don't like a messy kitchen in the morning.' Sometimes she talks with the guests, other times they want to be alone. 'Good guests make the week fun, but some weeks are not as good.' Sarah meets her friends at her chalet and they go out around 11 p.m. 'We start at Bananas, then maybe G Jay's, and end at Dick's T-Bar,' she says. But Sarah does not stay out late on Saturday night because Sunday is her busiest day. 'It's a hard day,' she says, 'and you don't want to be tired when cooking breakfast.' Work starts earlier on Sunday, as breakfast must be ready by 7 a.m. After the guests leave, Sarah cleans quickly. 'We clean everything - clear breakfast, strip beds, get ready.' If she didn't shop on Saturday, she does it now. Around 3 p.m., after cleaning, Sarah prepares tea for new guests. 'They arrive around 4:30 p.m. Sometimes they are confused and have many questions. I think it's the mountain air.' Between tea and dinner, Sarah helps guests with ski boots or skis and gets a ride back to the chalet. Then it's time for dinner again and maybe a chat with friends, but not always. 'Sometimes I'm so tired I go to bed early,' she says.'

'Changing lives with a Stranger
Mandie Currie is a zoo-keeper. She spent a day at the magazine Marie Claire. "Choosing clothes for Marie Claire was hard because I usually wear a uniform. First, I went to a photo studio, then to press previews, all before lunch. The zoo is quiet and peaceful, but at the magazine, I was rushing around. Some people in the fashion team seemed stressed. My job is not stressful. At a fashion shoot in the afternoon, I laughed because I usually clean cages or handle rats. I like seeing how magazines work, but I love my job at the zoo, so I will stay there."
Alice Cutler is a fashion assistant at Marie Claire. She spent a day at London Zoo. "I arrived at the zoo in leather boots and dark blue trousers. The zoo gave me a green polo shirt to work in, which was good because I got very dirty. I stroked an elephant and thought Mandie was probably packing clothes. By five o'clock, I smelled bad, but I had a great day. When I stop working in fashion, I might work with elephants, maybe in Africa."
Karen Hodson is a nurse at Hammersmith Hospital. She went with the TV gardening programme Ground Force. "I was very excited to meet the team. Alan Titchmarsh, the presenter, was nice. I liked being in the fresh air. Sometimes, I don't see daylight because of my shifts. It was hard work but fun. I thought I was strong, but I felt weak compared to the team. I didn't know landscape gardening was so hard. I am more enthusiastic than good at gardening, so I will keep my job as a nurse."
Charlie Dimmock is a landscape gardener with Ground Force. She worked at Hammersmith Hospital. "I made beds and gave out tablets. I thought I would faint, but I was okay. The nurses are very friendly, and it felt very 'girlie' compared to my usual work with men. I feel my job is not as important as nursing. My day at the hospital was not fun, but it was satisfying."
Lucy Harvey is a personal trainer. She spent a day with Ryanair as cabin crew. "I changed into the uniform, and I felt different. People looked up to me. Before the flight, our supervisor talked about safety and heart attacks, which I know from fitness training. On the flight to Paris, I gave out magazines. Everyone looked at me, and I felt shy. On the way back, we had 80 schoolchildren who wouldn't sit still. I wished I was back in the gym with one adult."
Sonia McDermott is an air hostess with Ryanair. She spent a day as a personal trainer in a gym. "I was worried about this swap because I don't exercise. I was surprised at how much attention you give to one person. In my job, I meet 130 passengers four times a day. I was surprised at lunch that some trainers didn't eat very healthily, but they drink lots of water. I wouldn't swap my job for this. But it has inspired me to join a gym and be healthier."'

'On the Train: Five Celebrities Share Their Favorite Train Memories. A Andrea Thompson - Newsreader I love the south of France and visit often. There is a train from Cannes that goes along the coast and into Italy. The views of the sea are amazing. It doesn't matter if it is sunny or rainy, it is always beautiful. You can also see nice gardens and houses. The people on the train are interesting, with both tourists and locals enjoying the trip. Raj Patel - Explorer I have taken many train trips, but my favorite is the Nile Valley Express in Sudan. When I was young in South Africa, I missed a family train trip to the Kruger National Park because I was too young. When I moved to England, I saw my first big train station, London Waterloo, and it amazed me. Betty Cooper - Novelist I love the Blue Train because it took my husband and me on our honeymoon across France to catch a boat to Egypt. On the train, my husband gave me a pink dress, which I loved. Someone said pink is good for the brain, and I have worn it ever since. The journey through France and then by boat up the Nile was the perfect way to relax after our wedding. Martin Brown - Journalist We were writing articles about a trip around the world and had to cross a desert in Africa. There was no road, so we took the Desert Express train. The schedule was not fixed, and the driver would wait for people. When the train came, many people climbed on, even on the roof. At night, the train went through beautiful landscapes. It felt like a dream. Arisu Mezuki - Actress Most people like trains from when they are children, but not me. I grew up in Singapore and Cyprus and saw few trains. As a teenager, I made a film in Yorkshire with a railway. The old train line was kept by volunteers. That's when I started to love steam trains. When we were not filming, we rode the train. I went back last year, and everything was the same, even the gas lights on the station platform!'

'Do you want to get your story published? Our expert, Margaret Stubbs, can help you. Many people ask, 'I have written a story or book. Who should I send it to?' First, you need to learn about publishers and practice your writing. Selling your writing needs knowledge about the 'writing world'. No matter what you write, you need to know about the markets you want to reach. The best way to do this is by reading a lot. Visit your local library, bookshops, and newsagents. Reading will show you what publishers want. Remember, things change often. New magazines come out, editors change jobs, and magazines change style. Publishers always want new writers, so we must give them what they want. If you want to write short love stories, first find out which magazines publish them. Get recent copies and see what kind of stories they like. Pay attention to who reads these magazines. Writers often ask me, 'My story was rejected three times. Am I wasting my time?' As a former teacher, I never discourage anyone. But maybe the work is not ready to be published. Most new writers send their work too soon. If you have only written one story, it is not likely to be published. Success usually comes after years in publishing or journalism. When you send your work, keep writing more stories. Write ten or even twenty more. Each story will be better, and you will feel more like a writer. Don't throw any stories away—improve them. I suggest not showing your work to others at first. Remember, every successful writer has faced many rejections. Do everything you can to become a writer. Look for a creative writing course or join a local writers' group. This will help you get ideas and confidence. Think of yourself as a writer and practice writing every day if you can.'

'Waiting at the Train Station On the last day of a bad year, I was at the Baltimore train station. I was waiting for the 10.10 train to Philadelphia. There were more people than I thought there would be. The station did not feel clean and nice like usual. Older couples with matching bags sat on the benches. Many college students sat on the floor with their bags. A man with grey hair was talking to different people. He looked rich: tanned skin, nice sweater, and a soft, beige coat. He asked a woman sitting alone a question. Then he talked to a girl near me. She had long blond hair. I thought I might like to talk to her too. The man asked, 'Are you going to Philadelphia?' 'Well, I'm going north,' she said. 'But to Philadelphia?' 'No, New York, but I'll be ...' 'Thanks, anyway,' he said, and moved to the next bench. Now I was interested. 'Ma'am,' he asked an old lady, 'are you going to Philadelphia?' She said, 'Wilmington,' and he moved on to a couple with matching bags. I stood up and moved closer, looking at the platform like I was thinking about the train. I was going to Philadelphia. He could have asked me. But I knew why he didn't. I probably looked unreliable. He just looked at me quickly and went to the other end of the waiting area. He looked worried. 'Please!' he said to a woman reading a book. 'Tell me you're going to Philadelphia!' She put her book down. She was about thirty-five, older than me. She looked like a teacher. 'Philadelphia?' she said. 'Yes, I am.' 'Could I ask you a favour?' I stopped a few feet away and looked at my wrist. (I don't have a watch.) I could tell she was careful. The man must have noticed too, because he said, 'Nothing too hard, I promise!' They announced my train. People started moving to Gate E, the older couples pulling their bags like big pets. I heard the man talking. 'My daughter is flying out today for a study year abroad, leaving from Philadelphia. I put her on a train this morning, then went for groceries. When I got home, my wife was upset. My daughter forgot her passport. She called from the station in Philadelphia; she didn't know what to do.' The woman made a sympathetic sound. I would have stayed quiet. I wanted to know what he wanted. 'I told her to stay there. I would find someone here to take her passport.' A likely story! Why didn't he go himself if it was so important? 'Why don't you go yourself?' the woman asked. 'I can't leave my wife alone for that long. She's in a wheelchair.' This seemed like a bad excuse to me. It was too much bad luck for one family. I looked at them. The man was holding a packet, not a plain envelope, but a padded one, like a small book. Aha! Padded! So you couldn't feel what was inside! And it looked stapled shut. Be careful, lady, I thought.'

'Gary and Me John Moore, a restaurant owner, writes about his son Gary, who is a famous TV chef. I believe everyone gets a chance in life. My son, Gary, got his chance with cooking, and my chance was to run a restaurant. When I heard about the opportunity, I quickly went to see the place. It was in very bad condition, but it was perfect for me. Starting this business made me remember my childhood. I remember my mother going to work in a factory, and I was upset because I was alone. So, I thought, 'We need time for family.' My wife took care of the children and did all my accounts, while I ran the business. We lived above the restaurant, and we always made sure to have meals together. This was good for our children, Gary and Joe. They are both very confident. From a young age, they would come and talk to our regular customers. This gave them a great start in life. Gary was a lively child. When he was about seven, he jumped into a bath like it was a swimming pool and knocked himself out. When he was older, he worked for pocket money. He started with small jobs and by the age of ten, he was in the kitchen every weekend, so he always had money at school. He was disciplined. He used to wake up even before me in the morning. If you run a family business, it's for the family, and it was nice to see him helping. Gary wasn't very good at school, but he was great in the kitchen. By the age of 15, he was as good as the men working there, and sometimes he was in charge. He would make over a hundred meals, and I knew he would go into catering because he was talented. So when he said, 'Dad, I need to do work experience for school,' I sent him to a friend who has a restaurant. Gary recently started playing the drums and now he has his own band. I wonder what will happen to his cooking if the music becomes successful. My advice to Gary is: if you try to do two things at once, you might not succeed in either, so focus on what you know you can do well. He understood when I said: 'Gary, if you want to succeed, do it by the age of 30. If not, it might be too late.' Gary went to catering college at 17, and on his first day, he and the other new students were given a morning's work. But within an hour, Gary had finished everything. That's my son! In the end, he was helping others. We can't believe how successful Gary's TV cooking show is. I'm very proud of him. I've always told him that if you want something, you have to work hard for it, because no one gives you anything. He saw his chance and took it. You talk to your children as they grow up, and if they remember even a little of what you say, you should be happy. The things Gary says and does make me think he listened sometimes.'

'Finding a Flat in Dublin Finding a good flat in Dublin that you can afford is very hard. The best way is to know someone who knows someone leaving a flat. But if you are new in Dublin, like Jo, you don't know anyone. So, you stay in a hostel and search for a flat. Jo felt Dublin was a big unknown place. She didn't think much about why she was going there. Everyone at her school thought they should leave their small town and see more of life. Some of her classmates went to towns like Ennis or Limerick, but Jo was the only one going to Dublin. Jo's mother thought it was good for her to stay in the hostel because it was safe. Her father worried it might be cold. Her sisters, who worked as waitresses, thought she was crazy to stay in a hostel for a week. Jo didn't know her family was still talking about her as she answered an ad for a flat in Ringsend. The ad said, 'Own room, own TV, share kitchen, bathroom.' It was close to the post office where she worked. Jo hoped it was nice and not too expensive. There was no line for this flat because it was more like 'Third Girl Wanted.' The 'own TV' part made Jo think it might be too fancy, but the house looked normal. It was a red-brick house with a basement, but the flat was upstairs. A girl with a college scarf was leaving and said to Jo, 'Desperate place. They're both awful.' Jo continued up the stairs. 'Hello,' said a girl with 'Nessa' on her T-shirt. 'Did you see that snobby girl leaving? I can't stand her type.' 'What did she do?' asked Jo. 'She just looked around, made a face, and said, "Is this all?" in a fancy voice. We wouldn't want her here, right, Pauline?' Pauline wore a very colorful shirt and had bright hair. Jo was surprised because Pauline was a punk. Jo had seen punks on O'Connell Street but never talked to one. 'I'm Jo, I work at the post office and I called about the flat.' Nessa said they were about to have tea. She had three mugs: one for 'Nessa,' one for 'Pauline,' and one for 'Other.' 'We'll put your name on it if you stay,' she said kindly.'

'Dolphins and Their Problems People love dolphins. We like to see them in marinas, movies, and TV shows. But the Whale and Dolphin Conservation Society says dolphins are in trouble. Mark Simmonds talks about the problems dolphins face. Dolphins are special to us. They are very smart, understand human feelings, and make us dream of freedom in the sea. TV shows like Flipper and Seaquest make us love them more. But these shows do not show the real problems dolphins have in dirty and overfished seas. The number of North Sea harbour porpoises (a type of dolphin) has gone down by up to 89,000. You might think dolphins are protected by law and live in safe places. But this is not true, and not helping them could be a big problem for wildlife. There are 40 kinds of dolphins in the world. In northern Europe, the most common are striped, common, bottlenose dolphins, and harbour porpoises. The first two live far out in the sea and are seen only in small groups. We do not know much about them. Bottlenose dolphins and harbour porpoises used to be common near European coasts. Bottlenose dolphins are very social and were found on the Channel coast and in British rivers like the Thames. Now, they are only in Moray Firth in Scotland and Cardigan Bay in Wales. The few left have skin injuries, showing they are stressed. Dolphins have complex habits, making it hard to know why their numbers are going down. Overfishing is a big problem. It reduces fish stocks and threatens dolphins. Porpoises need to find food quickly. If fish are taken by fishing, they may not find food in time. They can also get caught in fishing nets, which they cannot see. Modern fishing uses big nets that float or move fast in the sea. Many dead dolphins have been found on beaches in France and Cornwall. Marks and cuts on them show they died from getting caught in nets. Waste and chemicals in the sea can stay in dolphins' bodies. For example, pesticides dissolve in fat, so dolphins can eat them, and they build up in their bodies. Female dolphins can pass these poisons to their young through milk. There is a case of a young dolphin dying from its mother's milk. Another problem for dolphins is human noise. Dolphins live in groups and use sound to understand their world. In the sea, noise from ships and oil wells travels four times better than in the air. This noise may disturb dolphins in ways we do not know yet.'

'GETTING FIT Exercise is very important for your mind and body. It helps you feel balanced when life is busy and stressful. You might think, "Oh no, not another article about exercise!" But there are many good reasons to exercise. Exercise makes your muscles stronger and changes your body shape quickly. It helps you stand or sit correctly, which is called good posture. Good posture prevents injuries. Exercise also helps your heart, lungs, and blood circulation. You might have heard these reasons before and feel bored. But did you know exercise can help with depression, tiredness, and sleep problems? It also helps control stress and can help with some medical conditions. There are many types of exercise like aerobics, jogging, and weightlifting. Be careful not to train too hard, as it can cause injuries. Start slowly and ask your doctor if you are unsure. Good posture is important for how you look and feel. A stiff or slouching body can be unattractive and have less energy. Imagine a balloon pulling your head up to help you stand straight. This helps you breathe better and look slimmer. Stretching your muscles makes you more flexible and helps prevent injuries. Stretching should be part of your exercise routine and should be done slowly and carefully. The best exercise routine includes a warm-up, stretching, an energetic workout, and a cool down.'

**In Their Natural Habitat**
Why do film-makers Amanda Barrett and Owen Newman leave their comfortable homes for many months? They want to find the perfect picture. In the jungles and plains of East Africa, it is hard to find producer Amanda Barrett and cameraman Owen Newman. They are now in the Ngorongoro Crater, where it has rained for six months. This rain causes problems. Newman said they bought an expensive tool to help when their car gets stuck in the mud. Amanda can then pull him out safely. Together, they have made some of TV's best wildlife films, like their famous film about leopards. Even when this film was on TV, they were back in Africa, looking for another shy animal, the jackal. 
Traveling film-makers have been going around the world to film wild animals since TV began. I talked to Newman at a safari lodge. He said they sometimes argue but solve it quickly. They do not see one as the leader. They both see animals in the same way. When they travel, they set up tents every night. But now, they have a fixed camp. They start at 5 a.m. and make tea the night before, keeping it warm in a flask. They eat pre-packed meals, heated by whoever is free. They can be away for up to eight weeks, so food can be a problem, says Newman. 
Living in remote areas is hard, but they can get close to animals. Newman remembers filming lions. One lioness would greet all the lions and their car too. Newman first worked with Barrett in 1988 on a film called 'The Great Rift'. Two years later, they filmed Arctic foxes together. They spend four months filming for each half-hour film. Before starting, they need to get a script approved. Newman says they work well together because they share the same ideas. They want to make films that show the true spirit of the place and animals and touch people's hearts. Newman believes it is better to make people feel something than just think about it.

**The Netball Captain**
In our series on women in sport, Suzie Ellis met England's netball captain, Kendra Slawinski. Kendra is the captain of England's netball team. When I met her, she had a busy day. She taught at a local school and then trained in a supermarket car park. I was surprised about her training place. 'Don't people look at you strangely?' I asked. 'I'm too focused on my movements and my feet to notice,' she said. 'I might see cars slow down, but that's all.'
'My whole life now is about being my best for the Championships,' says Kendra. She follows a strict plan to be very fit. These are her fourth World Championships, and they will be the biggest ever, with 27 countries. 'We'll have home support, which is special,' she says. 'It's important to improve netball's reputation in our country. Playing here means more pressure. People expect us to start with a good game.' Their first game is against Barbados, right after the opening ceremony. 'We have always beaten them, but they are exciting to play. They have lots of skill.'
The England team is ranked fourth in the world. But the World Championships will be hard. 'You have to play every day, no rest between games. In a series, you can lose the first game and still win. But in the Championships, there's only one chance,' says Kendra. In the fifteen years she has played at the top level, the sport has become harder and faster. Players are more aggressive. 'You train to win,' says Kendra. 'But after the game, we are all friendlier.'
Netball is now more scientific about fitness. 'We must think and train like world-class players,' says Kendra. As captain, she believes it's important to have a strong mind and lead by example. She supports and encourages her team. 'From the start, my netball career was planned,' she says. She decided this competition would be her last as a player. She might coach young players in the future, but now she focuses on her last big event. As she leads her team in the opening ceremony, she might have a tear in her eye. Her loyal supporters will be with her every step.

'In hot water Rachel Mills is a scientist who works at the bottom of the Atlantic Ocean. Rachel Mills teaches and studies marine geochemistry. This means she looks at the chemical processes in the sea. She is a teacher at the Oceanography Centre at Southampton University. When she is not teaching, she goes into a small steel vehicle, like a small car, and dives three kilometres down into the Atlantic Ocean to study underwater volcanoes. 'Inside,' she says, 'there is not much space. I can touch the two pilots. We can't stand up or move, and we must stay inside until someone opens the door from the outside. A dive can last for 16 hours - three hours to reach the ocean floor, ten hours to collect rock and water samples, and then three hours to go back up to the surface.' 'If there is a problem and we need to go up quickly, we can press a panic button. The outside part drops away, and a small escape vessel goes up fast, like a ping-pong ball in water. No one has tested it yet, but I think it would not be a nice trip.' 'I didn't know how I would feel the first time I got into the vehicle. It was on a ship, and I got in with an instructor. He showed me what to do in an emergency, like if the pilot had a heart attack! They wanted to see how I would react in a small space.' Now Rachel has made six dives. Last year she dived with a Russian team. 'We went to a place five days' sail west of the Canary Islands in the Atlantic. Here, on the ocean floor, there are many underwater volcanoes, blowing out black smoke. It is where the Atlantic Ocean is very active. The Russian team was putting some scientific equipment there to study the effect of a big project that would make a hole 150 metres through a volcano.' When she is not at sea, Rachel is in her office at the Oceanography Centre, Southampton. 'Two-thirds of my salary comes from teaching, which I love, but I do it so I can continue my research into the "black smokers". This is another name for underwater volcanoes - water comes out of the rock and looks like black smoke. It comes out at one metre per second and at a temperature of 350 degrees.' 'The only time I was scared was when I first went down with the Americans. We were towing equipment on a 50-metre rope when suddenly there was an explosion. There was a big bang, and I thought, "I'm going to die." We looked at each other in silence, waiting. When nothing happened, we couldn't believe it. We were so relieved - we were still alive!' 'It's such an adventure diving to the deepest part of the ocean. Every time I look out of the window and see those chimneys, I feel wonder. Here I am at the bottom of the sea, and no one else on this planet has ever seen them before. I studied the black smokers for three years for my Ph.D. When I got down there and saw them for real, it was an amazing feeling.'

**Interview Tips**
First impressions are very important. People decide what they think about us in the first few minutes. They look at how we dress, our eye contact, our body movement, how fast or slow we talk, and our voice. Mary Pearce studied to be a teacher. She says, "I worked hard to earn my degree. When I graduated, I was very confident." She applied for a job at a primary school and got an interview with the Head Teacher. "I noticed a small hole in my jacket that morning," she remembers. "I would have changed, but I knew it would make me late, and I think it's important to be on time." Mary didn't get the job. Her friend, who also teaches at the school, told her the Head Teacher said, "If someone doesn't take the time to look their best at an interview, what kind of teacher will they be?"
Simon Grant, a hotel manager, says, "People who look like they care about themselves are more likely to care about their jobs. People think it's what's inside that counts, but in an interview, you should try to look your best." Many people forget how important it is to look professional. For example, Janet Goodwood worked for ten years as an assistant in a big company. When the office manager left, she applied for the job but didn't get an interview. "I thought it was a mistake, so I asked the Director of Personnel what happened," she says. "He told me I didn't look like an office manager. He suggested I improve my wardrobe before I apply again. I was shocked. I do a very good job, and the way I dress shouldn't matter."
Movement and gestures also affect an interviewer's first impression. Psychologist Albert Mehrabian found that 7% of our message comes from words, 38% from voice, and 55% from facial expressions. If our facial expressions and words are different, the listener will believe the facial expressions. So make sure your words and body language match. Mixed messages will confuse the interviewer.
It is also important not to look too desperate for the job or too eager to please. When Sheila Rice, a marketing specialist, applied for a promotion, her interview went well, and she got the job right away. "I was delighted," she says. "But I showed too much excitement. Once the boss saw how excited I was, he knew I wouldn't say no. So, he offered me a lower salary than I wanted. I'm sure I could have got more if I controlled my excitement."
Finally, think about what you say and how you say it. David Artesio, a manager of an employment agency, suggests learning about the company before the interview. "The annual report, for example, will tell you about the company. Mention something that interests you during the interview. This will show your interest in the company." Business consultant Marian Woodall suggests having a few questions ready and speaking in short sentences. She says, "Poor communicators talk in long paragraphs. Successful communicators talk in short sentences and clear points."

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring. He lost his job suddenly and used the money to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel, and now he sells meat to them and by mail. He is happy not to be in an office, but he still works long hours.
**The Painter**
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby, and he enjoyed it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counsellor helped him. Most people need to work for money, but Ron's children were grown up. He moved to the north of England, away from friends, but they still visit him.
**The Hat Maker**
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer for five years. Now, she makes hats in her London flat. She liked her job, but the hours were too long. She didn't want to work more, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she didn't. She likes having deadlines and being in charge of her work. She misses talking to colleagues but enjoys being responsible for her product.
**The Masseur**
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur at the Life Centre in London. He liked the excitement of finance but not the work. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health, so he learned about massage. He now works part-time and feels in control of his life.

'Dedicated to their sports Four young sports stars talk about their lives. A Darius (runner) I have always liked sports. I played many sports, but I was best at football and running. When I was 14, I tried out for a professional football club, but I chose running instead. My best moment was when I ran for my country in the youth team and won a medal. Sadly, it did not get much media attention. I hoped to get sponsorship because training is expensive. I train at home in winter and then go to Florida for three weeks before the season starts. It is fun there because the facilities and nightlife are great. But I must be disciplined. If friends ask me to go out before training, I say no. I wish I could go, but dedication is important in this sport. My main goal is to go to the next Olympics. That would be fantastic. B Gabriel (surfer) The surfing community is small, so you meet the same people at competitions. Professional surfers are serious, and the best waves are often at dawn. So, you cannot go to late-night parties. I do not mind that, but I love sleeping in, and I have to give that up too. It is worth it because I won the National Championships last year. After a win, I have a big night out, and if I win money, I go somewhere nice. Winning the championship helped me get a job on a TV surfing series. I guess I am a bit of a celebrity now. C Dieter (yacht racer) With five guys on a boat, we have a lot of fun. We celebrate a win in style. People say we act childishly, but we do not look for media attention. Reporters care more about our celebrations than our race results. I am away for eight months a year, so it is nice to come home and hang out with friends. You cannot always think about the sport; it is not healthy. I am known in sailing, but I am rarely recognized on the street. I would not like to be a celebrity. I get nice letters asking for signed pictures, and I reply to all of them. It takes time, but it is worth it. D Tomas (tennis player) It is great to walk on the court and feel the crowd's support. At the last tournament, it got crazy with people crowding around. I still enjoy being noticed by fans when I am out shopping. But it has downsides. My last girlfriend did not like it when I got attention from female fans. Tennis players travel a lot, and that is why we broke up. It was hard, but you must make sacrifices in sports. You have to be serious and professional. I do not mind too much. I focus on my game now and will enjoy other things after I retire, which comes early in this sport.'

'Shopping with Children Shopping with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not a sweet breakfast cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't buy all this, and I feel bad for saying no all the time. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to make choices. I can't win." Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number is likely to grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why parents say no to buying things. They don't find reasons like "sugar is bad for your teeth" convincing when compared to fun TV ads. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food because if children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children." The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, doesn't allow advertisers to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, 'Tell your mum to buy this,' the effect is the same." Some parents find it stressful to decide which things to buy and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads. Her son is critical of ads, and they look at labels together. She says, "We don't have many arguments in the supermarket now because the children don't ask for things I won't buy." Parents also say they are not always consistent. Mike, a father of two, says, "We say no to sweets for the kids because they're bad, but we buy chocolate for ourselves. It's nice to buy good things, and it's normal for children to want that too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on how I feel. If I'm happy, I'm more likely to say yes. It's hard to be consistent." Supermarkets could help by removing sweets from checkout areas or having play areas for children. Parents might spend less if their children are not with them, but shopping without a child's demands might bring more customers.'

**Title: The Merrion Hotel: Luxury and Technology**
The Merrion Hotel is a new five-star hotel in Dublin. It took almost two years to change four old houses into this hotel. The hotel has the latest technology for both staff and guests. 
The General Manager, Peter MacCann, wants his staff to know guests by name. For other details, he uses a computer system. This system helps treat returning guests in a special way. It cost £250,000 but will save money over time. For example, if a guest likes certain music CDs, they will have them ready on their next visit. 
Room temperature is important for guests. A special system lets guests change the temperature a little. The front desk can also change it more if needed. 
Business guests are important for the hotel. Each room has three phones, two phone lines, a fax machine, and video-conferencing. The hotel is ready for future technology changes. TVs and DVD players can be updated easily.
The hotel has 145 large and comfortable rooms. There is a swimming pool, gym, six conference rooms, two bars, two restaurants, and a beautiful garden. 
The food at the hotel is excellent. Chef Patrick Guilbaud, who has two Michelin stars, moved his restaurant to the hotel. This is good for both him and the hotel. He has a new kitchen and better parking. The hotel offers a great place to eat without financial risk.
With technology and a great staff, the Merrion Hotel is ready to succeed.

'Where I get my energy Emma Marsden asked six women how they stay energetic. A. Jeanette Kupfermann Journalist and author: 'I get energy from excitement. I like doing new and challenging things. Learning something new gives me a lot of energy. I also get energy from rhythm, like dancing flamenco. Dance is fun and gives me energy. If you are bored, you can feel tired. Doing something useful, even if it's small, gives you energy.' B. Linda Kelsey Magazine editor: 'I have a lot of work, but I enjoy it. I love being at work, so it doesn't make me feel tired. I need a lot of sleep, and when I get it, I feel good. If I sleep only six hours, I feel tired. Exercise gives me energy, but it's hard to start. I do yoga once a week and try to exercise at home.
