After exercise, I feel happy. I feel tired at work between 3 and 5 in the afternoon, so I eat something then.' C. Annie Nightingale Disc jockey: 'I don't eat healthy food for energy. I think my energy comes from being positive. I don't like negative people. I think we should enjoy life. I enjoy my work, and the last two years have been exciting. I work with young people, and they give me energy. I like taking photos and writing songs for fun. It helps me relax when I travel.' D. Floella Benjamin Author and children's TV presenter: 'My energy comes from doing things I enjoy. I believe in my work and my family. Being positive helps. I love working with kids because they have a lot of energy. Smiling at people and getting a smile back gives you energy. I try to eat healthy and don't smoke or drink, but I don't have an exercise plan. I get energy from playing with kids.' E. Deborah Moggach Author and playwright: 'I love making a garden from nothing. I did it once with a concrete garden. I broke the concrete and added soil. It was better than exercise. I get energy when people want to read my writing. I also like walking in nature. If someone finds me, I say I didn't know it was private. It's fun and makes me feel young.' F. Katherine Monblot Therapist: 'You need to like and respect what you do. I like taking risks and get bored easily, which keeps me active. Doing things you don't like makes you tired. I used to be on committees, but they took too much time. You have limited energy, so use it for important things.'

'ICE SKATING Ice skating is a very old activity. People have been skating for thousands of years. Long ago, people used skates made from animal bones. These bone skates were used until about the year 200 AD when iron skates came to Scandinavia. In Scandinavia, rich people thought skating was an important skill. In the early 1900s, skating was calm and stylish. But in 1924, at the Winter Olympics, an 11-year-old girl named Sonja Henie made skating more athletic. This made skating more popular. Today, skating is both an art and a sport. It is beautiful and hard work. For beginners, balance and control are very important. You can go faster when you get better. Your body position helps with balance. Keep your legs slightly bent and your knees bent to keep your weight in the center. Lean a little forward. Relaxation is very important in skating. To start, your heels should almost touch, and your feet should point outwards. Push forward with your back foot and make a small movement with the other foot. It is not too hard, right? As you practice, you can make bigger movements. Learning how to fall is one of the first things a skater should learn. Even the best skaters fall. To fall safely, try to relax. This makes the fall less painful. To get up, use your hands to kneel, then stand. Once you can skate confidently, you can try different styles like figure skating, freestyle, distance, speed, and pair skating. But first, learn figure skating and then basic freestyle. Most ice rinks have teachers to help you learn. You can soon learn the basic moves and then the turns, jumps, and spins of freestyle. Good skaters look relaxed and move easily. To be like them, you should do exercises regularly. It is dangerous to skate with a stiff body. Warm-up exercises should include legs, back, and shoulders, especially ankles and knees. After skating, do the same exercises to avoid stiffness. Skating helps with balance, coordination, relaxation, and movement. It is good for your heart and lungs and makes your body stronger. Skating with swimming or jogging is a great way to stay healthy and fit.'

**Young Stars and Their Lives**
**A. Annika Reeder, 15**  
Annika won a gold medal for gymnastics at the Commonwealth Games. She wants to be a physiotherapist and compete in the next Olympics. "The work is very hard now. I have no time to watch TV or go out with friends. I only do gym and school. I try to take training day by day. When I am very tired, my coach sometimes gives me a day off, but usually, I keep going. You can't take too many days off, or you get stiff."
**B. Annika's Mother**  
"Annika showed great talent from a young age. Some parents push their children, but it doesn't work. To perform like Annika, you have to want it yourself. People say we gave up a lot, but they don't see what the sport gave us. We love it and what it did for Annika. Before gym, she was shy and hid behind me, but now she has met people from all over the world and is confident."
**C. Sarah Stokes**  
Sarah started show-jumping at ten and won the British National Championship. "It's good my mum and dad like show-jumping because they train me and take me everywhere. Shows last from one to five days. I never get tired of it. I love show-jumping events; they are exciting and fun. Even without Mum and Dad, I would do it because I am determined. I want to qualify for the British young riders team and win a gold medal at the Olympics."
**D. Sarah's Mother**  
"Sarah loved horses from age 1. At 5, she got up early to exercise her pony. To qualify for big shows, you have to jump all over England. We save money by sleeping in our horse box. Sarah is well-organized and happy on a horse. Watching your child succeed at something they love is wonderful."
**E. Jane McShane, 10**  
Jane is Britain's Under-14 Chess Champion. "Tournaments are friendly. I know everyone, and it's fun. When I play, I don't concentrate much. I should, but I just look around. I'm not scared of being proud. I don't talk about my success at school because I don't like embarrassment."
**F. Jane's Mother**  
"Jane played her first game at 5. My father said, 'Let's see if she likes it.' He tried to teach me when I was young, but I was bored. Jane loved it from the start. By the end of that day, she knew all the moves, and by 6, she was beating adults. I'm happy when she wins, but if she wanted to stop, I wouldn't stop her. I don't want to put her down because she is special. If she has this gift, let her use it."

'We are all getting taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, he is Britain's tallest man at 228 cm. Every ten years, people in Europe grow about one centimeter taller. More tall people are born each year. This does not mean we are becoming a super race. We are becoming like our ancestors, the Cro-Magnons, who lived 40,000 years ago. In the past, people ate many different plants and animals. About 9,000 years ago, farming started, and people began eating mostly wheat, rice, and maize. This poor diet made people less healthy. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Farming spread because it could support more people, even if they were not well-nourished. Now, in Europe, the US, and Japan, people eat better, like our ancestors did. The average man in the US is now 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is good, but it also causes problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, and there is less leg-room in planes and trains. Clothes makers have to change their products. We cannot grow forever. Scientists think we might reach an average height of 193 cm this century. But as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, people were rounder and taller to keep warm. As the planet gets warmer, we might become thinner and smaller. So, global warming might make us shrink.'

'Studio Audiences What is it like to be in the audience when a TV show is made? Cosmo Landesman found out. Studio audiences are a common part of TV, but many people don't know much about them. When we see them excited on game shows, we wonder - who are these people? Some people think studio audiences are not very important. I heard that even TV workers don't respect them much. I thought studio audiences were just people who wanted to be on TV for a short time. But there is no typical studio audience. They come from all kinds of backgrounds. TV shows try to get different people for different shows. Some people like to watch TV at home and don't understand why others go to a studio. Why would someone get tickets, travel far, and sit for hours in a studio to watch something they can see at home? One idea is that people want to be on TV for a moment. I didn't believe this until I talked to Angela. She said she came because she might be on TV. Another idea is that people are curious to see behind the scenes. But many people said they came because a friend gave them a ticket. Not many of us have been in a studio audience, but we think we know what it's like. You sit with strangers, and someone shows signs that say APPLAUD or LAUGH, and you clap or laugh. This might be true for some shows, but not all. A studio manager said, 'We hope a show is good enough not to need these signs.' Is there a difference between watching in a studio and at home? Claire thinks sitting in a studio is 'more exciting', and Charlotte liked being part of live TV. 'Last year I saw my favorite comedian. At home, you miss a lot.' I missed seeing live actors because I could only see the back of someone's head. The first scenes were so far away that I watched on a studio screen. Going to a studio might not be the best way to watch TV, but that's not the point. For most people, it was just fun and a free night out.'

'Favourite places
Bruce  
I don't like wild places without people. I like places with people. It's the same when I travel. I like pretty villages with old temples, not empty deserts. When I was eight, I went to school in England. On Saturdays, I rode my bike to the village of Lastingham. It was in a nice valley. Riding my bike was fun and made me feel free. I liked to explore the hills, valleys, and old villages. I am from Scotland, so the landscape was familiar but also different. I still visit there today. I wrote about my adventures in my diary. That was my first try at travel writing, which I became famous for later.
Sophia  
There is a small train that goes from Hythe to Dungeness. It is run by people who love trains. I always travel first class because it is not much more expensive. The view is not amazing. The train goes across Romney Marsh with its sheep and next to a canal. But there is one part of the trip I like. The train goes through back gardens. We can see people doing things like making tea or washing dishes. I see myself as a woman in a small train, looking into other people's homes. I like the simple landscape. Just fields, sheep, and a faraway grey sea. It makes me look closely to find something new.
Matthew  
The Hartland Peninsula is a beautiful and quiet coast. The beaches are hard to get to and have many rocks, so not many people come here. Some brave surfers come, but most people like to look at the sea. The coast faces the Atlantic Ocean and is known for shipwrecks. There are walks along the coast and trips inland to valleys with oak trees, ferns, and wildflowers. We stay in simple places with a family in the village of Southole.
Annette  
My favorite place in England is the Trough of Bowland. It is a big open area perfect for hiking. Not many people live or visit there. It is a quiet and empty place, and I like the space. I found it by accident when I was a student. Since then, I visit every year, sometimes alone, with my boyfriend, and now with my son. It has not changed much since my first visit. Having a child makes these visits special. It makes me sad that he is growing up in a city.
James  
I bought Glenthorne, my favorite house in Britain. I wanted peace and to connect with my English roots. I grew up in Sri Lanka, but at twelve, I went to school in Devon, England. I used to ride my bike around the moors and village streets. We had a story about a place we never cycled past: if you went down the driveway, you'd never return. That place was Glenthorne. It's my dream place. It's a magic, quiet, romantic house. You can't hear anything except the sea, wind, and birds.'

'ANIMAL ADVENTURE We are a family who loves animals. One afternoon, my daughter called me at work. She found a big pine snake and asked, 'Can we keep him?' I said, 'Yes, but only for one night.' We have a special tank for animals we find. One night is enough to look at them and read about them in our book. I came home late. I started cooking when I heard my sons shouting, 'Oh, Mother! Help!' I ran to their room. Domino, our cat, had Bianca, a white mouse, in his mouth. Bianca was a gift for Mother's Day. (Some mothers get perfume.) Domino ran around the room with the mouse. I tried to catch him but tripped and fell. Then I saw the snake. It was escaping from the tank. The room was full of noise: the cat, the mouse, the kids, and the dog barking. The pot boiled over in the kitchen, so I turned off the gas and came back. I caught Domino by the tail and saved the mouse. The mouse was not hurt. Domino caught the same mouse three more times, but the mouse lived a long life. After saving the mouse, I looked at the snake. It was hard to catch. I sat on the floor and waited. Slowly, the snake relaxed. I picked it up and took it to the garden. I wanted it to go to a tree. But when I let go, the snake went over my shoulders like a scarf. We stood there, me, the kids, and the snake. My eldest, DJ, said, 'Mum, you're warm, and the shed is not.' The kids helped the snake move to the tree. It climbed the wall and disappeared over the roof. As the last part of the tail vanished, my three-year-old, Clay, said, 'Wow, that was one big snake!'

'Write me a letter! Today, we use phones, fax machines, and computers a lot. Because of this, writing letters is disappearing. But I think getting a letter is special. It is exciting to see a letter arrive, to see who sent it, and to read it. I have been writing letters all my life. I started with small notes to my mother. She always told me to write thank-you letters for Christmas and birthday gifts. It didn't matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters. When I left home at 18 to study medicine in London, I wrote a letter every week to my mother, and she wrote back. Sometimes my father wrote too, and his letters were funny and long. The letters from home talked about everyday things. We also made phone calls, but I remember the letters more. I also got letters from boyfriends. Many of them had to work or study far away, so we wrote letters to stay in touch. Writing letters made our relationships better. I could say things in writing that were hard to say in person. I love letters that come with birthday or Christmas cards. Notes are nice, but a letter with a lot of news is better! It's even better when it comes in an airmail envelope with pretty stamps. I get letters from Mangala in Sri Lanka, a friend I trained with 20 years ago. I also have a penfriend in Australia and another in Vancouver. There is a lady from France who writes to me. We met in a restaurant on holiday. My husband took her photo, and I asked for her address. If she hadn't written back, we wouldn't be friends now. But she did, and now we write to each other often. I can practice my French because she doesn't speak English. We have visited each other too. My biggest letter-writing success was this summer. My family and I visited my American penfriend in Texas. We had been writing to each other for 29 years but never met. Everyone was surprised that we wrote for so long. The local newspaper even wrote about it on the front page. I am happy my children also write letters. Like my mother, I tell them to write thank-you letters. My daughter writes me little letters, just like I did to my mother. She and my son have penfriends in Texas, thanks to my penfriend. I think people should not stop writing letters. It is a special way to communicate.'

Careless tourists damage old rock art
Many old pictures carved into rocks in France are being destroyed. Scientists are worried that the 36,000 drawings on rocks in Mont Bego in the French Alps are being damaged quickly. They might not last for future generations. The mountain was once a place for prayer and worship. It has 4,000-year-old drawings of cows with horns, fields, and gods. But as more people visit, the pictures are being ruined by graffiti. Jean Clottes, from the International Committee on Rock Art, says, 'People think the pictures will always be there. But if the damage continues, there will be nothing left in 50 years.' He has seen tourists stepping on the drawings and wearing away the rock. Some visitors even take parts of the rock home. 'When people can't take a good photo, they rub the drawings to see them better,' he said. 'The weather polishes the drawings, and if the sun is shining, visitors rub them to make them look fresher.' Other researchers say people scratch their own drawings or names into the rocks. Experts do not agree on how to save the drawings. Henry de Lumley, from the Museum of Natural History in Paris, thinks the only way is to stop people from going there, except on guided tours. He says if not, the site will be destroyed, and research will be reduced. Clottes disagrees. 'Henry de Lumley's idea is too strict and will cause protests,' he said. 'The site is a historic monument, and we must save it.' David Lavergne, a regional architect, also wants to keep the site open. 'Henry de Lumley's idea isn't ideal,' he said. 'We want people to see the site, but it is hard to stop damage because the area is big. We don't have enough money for guards. We may need to charge a fee. There is no government funding.' In Nice, Annie Echassoux, who also worked on the site, is worried that as the mountain becomes easier to reach, damage will increase. She thinks the area should be roped off and guides provided. 'You can't say the plan can't go ahead because there is no money,' she said. 'That is not good enough. Money must be provided because this is a historic site. If we don't act, we will lose the drawings for the next generation.'

'Shopping with Children Shopping with children can be very difficult for parents. One mother says, "They want everything they see. If it's not a sweet breakfast cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. Usually all three. I can't buy all this, and I feel bad if I do. But I also feel bad if I say no all the time. I try not to take them shopping, but then I worry they won't learn how to choose things. I can't win." Research shows that children ask to buy something every two minutes in a supermarket. More than £150 million a year is spent on advertising to children, mostly on TV. This number will probably grow, and supermarkets are where this advertising works best. Children often don't understand why parents say no to buying things. They don't believe that sugar is bad for their teeth when they see fun and exciting ads. Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says, "Most parents care about what their children eat and have ideas about healthy food, but these ideas are not always right. It's good for parents and children to talk about food. If children only learn from TV ads, they get a one-sided view. Parents don't like competing with ads and having to say no to their children." The Independent Television Commission, which controls TV ads, does not allow ads to tell children to ask their parents to buy things. But, as Dibb says, "The goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something. So even if they can't say, 'Ask your mum to buy this,' that's what they want." Some parents find it stressful to decide which things to buy and which to refuse. One mother says she talks a lot with her children about food and ads. Her son listens to ads but is critical of them. They look at labels together, and now her children don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy. Parents also say they are not always fair when they say no. Mike, a father of two, says, "We say no to sweets because they are bad, but we buy cream and chocolate for ourselves. It's nice to buy good things, and children want that too. But I still get annoyed by their demands. It depends on my mood. If I'm happy, I might say yes. It's hard to be fair all the time." Supermarkets could help by not putting sweets near the checkout or by having play areas for children. Parents might spend less if their children are not with them, but shopping without a child's demands might bring more customers.'

'Climbing Walls In the past, climbers went to the mountains. Now, people can climb anywhere, inside or outside. At the World Cup Climbing Championships in Birmingham, a French climber named Francois Lombard is climbing on a wall. The National Indoor Arena, where the event is held, is also known for the TV show Gladiators. Both events have a wall for climbing. This is possible because of new technology. Before the 1960s, climbers practiced on cliffs. In winter, they climbed in cold places like Scotland or used buildings to stay fit. They needed strong fingers and wanted to avoid boredom. Sports centers started building climbing walls with special bricks. Don Robinson, a teacher, made a climbing wall at Leeds University in the 1960s. He used natural rock in concrete blocks. Many walls like this were built in the 1970s, but they had problems. They were only vertical, unlike real cliffs with different shapes. Also, climbers got bored because the walls couldn't change. In 1985, Francois Savigny from France made a new material for climbing holds. These could be put on and taken off walls easily. French companies also used steel frames to make climbing walls. These frames were lighter than concrete and could be set up anywhere. Climbers could change the holds for new challenges.'

'Do you want to be an actor? If you tell someone you want to be an actor, they will probably say it is 'risky'. Acting is a risky job because there are more actors than jobs. Some friends might say you are crazy, but others might not. Everyone will give different advice. It is your choice, and you must take responsibility for it. There are no easy ways to become an actor. There are no exams to pass, and no guarantee you will get a job after training. It depends on luck and talent. But there is always a need for new actors, and acting can be exciting and glamorous. Sometimes, it can also be rewarding. People often ask what talent is. I think it is natural skill and imagination. Imagination is hard to measure. Talent also needs courage and belief in what you do. Why do people want to act? It is hard to explain. In theatre, the important thing is the connection between the actor and the audience. This connection is important in all acting. It is why actors love to act. If you ask actors how they succeed, they might not know. They know about their skills and others' skills, but they do not assume success will last. Disappointment is a big problem for actors. Last month, you might have been out of work, selling clothes, or waitressing. Then, you get an audition, but you might not get the job. Actors do not talk about their chances. They find ways to handle the stress of auditions and rejection. Nobody likes rejection. Remember, from the start, you might face rejection. You are saying you are ready and talented for the job. If you do not care enough, no one else will care for you.'

'Cookbooks for Everyone We are happy to show you our special selection of the best cookbooks. A. When people think of a famous TV cook, they often think of Delia Smith. Her recipes come from many countries and are easy to follow. Her book, Delia Smith's Complete Cookery Course, is very popular. It has simple advice and many great recipes. If you want just one cookbook, this might be the one. B. Raymond Blanc became a famous chef in just 15 years. He has a TV show called Blanc Mange and a book with the same name. Raymond wants to help us cook better by explaining how ingredients work. The book has over 80 recipes and explains why some dishes might not work. It is a useful book for learning to cook well. C. Le Cordon Bleu is a famous cooking school known for French cooking. To celebrate its 100th anniversary, they have a new book called Le Cordon Bleu Classic French Cookbook. It has 100 classic recipes. The book starts with basic cooking tips and has sections for Appetisers, Main dishes, and Desserts. The recipes have step-by-step pictures. Chefs from around the world share their best recipes. D. Fast food? No way! Good food doesn't have to take a long time. Nigel Slater, a food editor, wrote a book called The 30-Minute Cook. He believes you can make tasty food quickly. His book has over 200 recipes that you can make in 30 minutes. Nigel's recipes are easy and delicious. If you think fast food can't be good, try his recipes.'

'We Are Getting Taller Chris Greener was fourteen when he told his teacher he wanted to join the navy. The teacher joked, 'Do you want to be the flagpole on a ship?' because Chris was already almost two meters tall. Today, he is Britain's tallest man at 228 cm. Every ten years, people in Europe grow about one centimeter taller. More tall people are born each year. This does not mean we are becoming a super race. We are becoming like our ancestors, the Cro-Magnons, who lived 40,000 years ago. Long ago, people ate many different foods. Women gathered herbs, fruits, and berries, and men hunted animals. They ate about 85 different wild plants. But 9,000 years ago, farming started. This changed everything. Farmers grew wheat, rice, and maize. These three plants now give us more than half of our food. This diet was not good for us. People became less healthy. In Ohio, scientists found that when people started farming corn, they became sick and underweight. Tooth decay and diseases increased. Farming spread because it could feed more people than hunting and gathering. But people were not well-nourished. Only recently have diets improved in Europe, the US, and Japan. Now, the average man in the US is 179 cm, in Holland 180 cm, and in Japan 177 cm. This is good, but it brings problems. Beds are still 190 cm long, and there is less leg-room in planes and trains. Clothes makers have to change their products. We cannot grow forever. Scientists think we might reach 193 cm this century. But as a species, we are actually getting smaller. During the last ice age, people were rounder and taller to keep warm. As the climate warmed, we became thinner and smaller. If the planet keeps getting hotter, we might shrink more. So, global warming could make us smaller.'

**A New Life**
**The Farmer**
Matt Froggatt used to work as an insurance agent in London. Now, he has a sheep farm. He worked in the city for 14 years, but it became boring. He lost his job suddenly and used the money to start the farm. He met a chef from a famous hotel, and now he sells meat to them and by mail. He is happy not to be in an office, but he still works long hours.
**The Painter**
Ron Ablewhite was a manager in advertising. Now, he is an artist. Painting was his hobby, and he enjoyed it more than his job. He decided to leave his job and become an artist. A career counsellor helped him. Ron and his family moved to the north of England. They left their friends, but many friends visit them now.
**The Hat Maker**
Katherine Goodison was a lawyer. Now, she makes hats in her London flat. She liked her job, but the hours were too long. She did not want to work more, so she left. People thought she would get bored, but she is always busy. She likes being in charge of her work. She misses talking to colleagues but enjoys being responsible for her hats.
**The Masseur**
Paul Drinkwater worked in finance for 16 years. Now, he is a masseur in London. He liked the excitement of finance but not the work. He almost lost his job in 1989, so he quit and traveled for a year. He wanted to work in health, so he learned about massage. He now works part-time as a masseur and feels happy and in control of his life.

'A Winning Game Two brothers are finding that their childhood game is good for business. Dave and Norm Lagasse, two brothers with big beards, live in Santa Fe, New Mexico, USA. They are in their forties and remember their childhood. In front of them is a wooden board with round plastic pieces. They are playing an old game called pichenotte. Their grandfather, Lucien Rajotte, was a grocer from Quebec, Canada. He brought the game to the USA and taught it to his family. Soon, the family played the game every weekend and holiday. Dave says they had 'the best time ever'. The family moved to New Mexico, but they still played the game. Grandpa's pichenotte board was made from old wooden food crates. Visitors were often interested because the game was unknown in southern USA. Three years ago, Dave saw the old board was broken and made a new one. It was very nice. A relative wanted one, then a friend wanted another. The brothers took a new board to a sports bar in Santa Fe. People watched and said, "No way I'm playing that silly game." But soon, they couldn't stop playing! People asked about the game's history. Dave found out it started in India with a game called 'carroms'. It changed to 'squails' in Britain, and British people took it to Canada. Pichenotte is the French-Canadian version from Quebec. Pichenotte is a game of skill for two to four people. Each player has 12 pieces or 'pucks'. They 'flick' the pucks with their finger across a board. Flicking a puck into a small hole is 20 points. Three rings around the hole are worth 15, 10, and 5 points. Eight small posts are obstacles. The game lasts about two minutes. The game was popular at the Santa Fe bar, so the brothers made more boards. They took them to markets and craft fairs. Many people liked the game, and it became more popular. Championships started, and a trophy called the 'Lord Pichenotte Cup' was made. The boards sold quickly, so the brothers started a business. They made a workshop in their garage and made over 450 boards. The boards are made of birchwood and mahogany, weigh 12kg, and are 1cm thick. Norm says, 'They're very strong because they need to last a long time.' The boards cost $595 each and are sold on the brothers' website. There are no professional pichenotte players or TV shows yet. But soon, the brothers hope their garage will have a luxury car instead of wood. Until then, they enjoy playing the game they hope will make them rich.'

'WELCOME TO THE MODEL VILLAGE When you enter the Model Village, it is hard to believe that a few years ago this was just empty land with lots of bushes. People thought it was useless land. But one man, with help from his wife, changed it into the beautiful place you see today. Many tons of soil and clay were moved to make the flat land into the nice shapes you see now. Machines helped, but there was also a lot of hard work. After shaping the land, about 1,000 tonnes of good soil were added to make the grass, flowers, and rock gardens. Many trees and bushes were planted. These plants had to be strong because the village is near the sea and has strong winter winds. Most plants came from local garden shops, but some came from Canada and New Zealand. Colin Sims thought of the Model Village, and he made over 100 models in nine years. The village opened in 1972. The models are made from stone, concrete, special wood, and plastics to last in all weather. Colin learned from experts about how materials last in different weather, and he became an expert too. The models are all the same size compared to real life, and every small detail is important. The Model Village is very popular because of its high quality. The way the models are made is used in other model villages in England and is taught in some schools. The buildings in the village show traditional British styles. One of the best buildings is the Manor House, a 13th-century stone building with a brick tower. It looks like manor houses in the West Country. As you walk around, you will see the Castle, St Mary's Church, a zoo, and a mini golf course, which is new. Please stay on the paths and do not touch the models; if you do, it can take hours to fix them. You can take photos from the paths. Dogs are welcome on a short lead. To enjoy the Model Village more, you can press buttons in front of some models to make them move. At the end of your visit, we would like to hear your thoughts. We are always planning new models, and your ideas can help us. We also want to know if any models are not as good as the others. We hope you enjoy your visit and come back again. Please tell your friends about us.'

'Every week, British tabloid newspapers show pictures that invade people's privacy. These pictures often break the rules set by newspaper editors. Sometimes pop stars pose for photographers, but this is not common. Usually, these pictures hurt famous people because they show private moments. Few people ask the Press Complaints Commission (PCC) for help. The PCC is an organization that deals with these problems. These pictures are rarely important for the public. Do private photos of pop stars help solve crimes? How did a picture of a famous actress on a hotel balcony help public safety? The actress was upset about these pictures before. She was in a hotel, a place where she should expect privacy, so she had a reason to complain, but she didn't. The PCC did not investigate, which is surprising. They should also look into a recent story about a pop star's love life. The pop star, like the actress, did not complain. Shouldn't the PCC do something about these attacks? At first, this seems like a good idea. It would lead to many decisions against newspapers. Other newspapers and TV would report these decisions. The public would not support the newspapers, and editors would stop publishing such pictures. Photographers would also be affected and might stop taking these pictures. If the PCC acted like a 'police officer', there would be problems. How would it decide to start an investigation? Should it ask the victim to complain? And if the person still did nothing, should it continue? Celebrities might expect every story about them to be investigated and be upset if it wasn't. The role is too big. How could the PCC watch all British newspapers and magazines? There is also the embarrassment factor. Even if someone's privacy is invaded, would they want an investigation? Most people just want to forget and move on. Some might have other reasons to stay quiet. They might have a worse story they want to keep secret. Even the PCC might become the enemy. A British comedian was secretly photographed on his honeymoon. He didn't complain then or later when it happened again on a family holiday. He was afraid the newspaper would publish the pictures again with a new story about his anger. This fear is understandable. People think they will be targeted again if they challenge the tabloids. It is hard to find an easy solution to this problem.'

'There is a lot of advice for students leaving college and starting their first job. This article talks about moving to a second job. We are not talking about people looking for a second temporary job or those leaving a bad job quickly. We are talking about people who are taking a real step in their career. You have learned some skills and have an idea of what you want to do. What kind of job should you look for? It depends on your long-term goals. Do you want to specialize in a field, move up to higher responsibility, or change to a different field? Whatever you choose, pick your second job carefully. You should plan to stay in it for two to three years. This job will be important when you apply for your next job. It should show that you are serious about your career. It should help you grow and give you more responsibility. If you want to travel, now is a good time. You can do temporary work when you come back and then find your second job. Future employers will be happy to see you have traveled and are ready to focus on your career. Juliette Davidson worked for three lawyers after leaving St. Aldate's College. It was a good first job because they were supportive. She learned about office work and improved her skills. But there was no chance to move up. So, she left, bought a plane ticket, and traveled for a year. Now, Juliette is a Personal Assistant to Brenda Cleverdon, the Chief Executive of Business in the Community. 'In two and a half years, I have become more skilled and my job has grown,' she says. 'My boss wanted to help me develop. My job title is the same, but my duties have changed. I started with typing and phone work, but now I do most of the correspondence and budgets. I also handle different questions, from company chairmen to people starting their own business. Brenda involves me in her work and gives me projects and events to organize.'

'Confident people - what's their secret? Confident people may look like they were born that way, but most say it's a skill they learned. Nina Hathway asks five people how they did it. A Jenny When I left school, I was very shy. I thought I would always be shy. When I was twenty-five, I helped at my daughter's school. I was scared, but I did well. Someone said I should go to university. I was nervous on my first day, but my confidence grew. Working at the school changed my life. B Michaela Four years ago, my father got sick, and I had to run the family business. I was scared and acted too aggressive. I learned that to be confident, you must believe in yourself. If work is too hard, I don't feel bad if I finish tasks the next day. When things are difficult, I tell myself I have nothing to lose. Fear makes you less confident, so I talk to myself to forget my fears. C Lisa People think I'm confident, but when I look calm, I'm really scared. In TV, you must look confident. Interviewing people showed me that everyone gets nervous. My mother once said, 'Who's looking at you? Everyone worries about themselves.' I remember this. You gain confidence by doing things that scare you. I was nervous for my driving test, but I passed. After that, I felt less scared. D Barbara My confidence comes from enjoying my work. I've built it over the years. If you learn from mistakes, you're more confident next time. I work hard and am liked in the restaurant, but not everyone likes me. I don't let it bother me. You must like yourself, not try to be what others want. My company has training courses that help my confidence. They also help us set small goals. It's better to achieve small things than aim too high and get nothing. E Kim After college, I worked as a secretary. In meetings, I was scared to speak. I finally got the confidence to speak up. In politics, I was nervous speaking in public. I told myself, 'People do this every day, so you can too.' I wrote notes to help me. Everyone is a little nervous speaking in public. The secret is to tell yourself, 'Nothing is impossible.''

'Visit to Malaysia Paul Forster goes to a kite-flying festival and spends a night in the forest. Adnan Ali smiled when I gave him his broken kite. 'You can keep it,' he said, 'it's a tradition - if the line breaks, finders are keepers ... and I have many more.' He showed me a pile of beautiful kites at his feet. All were 120cm wide and long, made of tissue paper and bamboo. We sat next to them under the trees behind the Beach of the Seven Lagoons in Kelantan, and watched Malaysia's biggest kite festival. In the middle of the beach were 10 platforms, where helpers held the kites, and a row of competitors waited to fly their kites. When the whistle blew, the crowd cheered and the kites flew up like rockets. More than 500 men and boys joined the competition, which lasts five days every year. Each person entered four different kites, judged on decoration, stability, and flying. 'Flying kites isn't hard,' said Adnan, 'but making them takes skill. Visit me at home and I'll show you how.' I accepted his invitation. At his house, I drank cold tea and ate fish crackers. As it got dark, he asked me to come back the next day to fix his kite, but I couldn't. Instead, I explored the southern part of the state, driving towards Kuala Lumpur into the rainforest. I took a wrong turn and the road ended at a river. A boat was there to take people across. I saw a sign that said: 'Jelawang Jungle 3 km.' It would have been good to know that most of this path was uphill and slippery. When I got there, a man named Baba was waiting with tea. He took care of a kitchen and bamboo huts. I decided to stay, trying not to think about insects under my mattress. The night was very dark and full of sounds. A waterfall was nearby and many animals made noises. In the morning, I saw a great view of green mountains. In the afternoon, it rained. First wind, then lightning hit the trees. I got very wet. Going downhill, I wondered how butterflies avoided the rain. I also worried about my car being washed away. Luckily, my car was still there, covered in mud. In Kota Bahru, Kelantan's capital, people asked me questions: 'Where are you from?' 'How old are you?' They were very friendly. Kelantan is famous for its kites, but I remember it for its kind people.'

'What kind of shopper are you? We all go shopping, but we shop in different ways. Do you know what kind of shopper you are? Abby Edwards asked some people ... A. Melanie, 22, dancer I love shopping! I spend a lot of money. When I have money, I go shopping and I feel happy. I can't walk past sale signs. My boyfriend is the same, so we shop together a lot. We are a shopping couple! B. Brenda, 40, office manager I don't like shopping. My husband does most of the food shopping because he cooks and knows what he wants. I don't shop for clothes much. I take my 6-year-old son and 14-year-old daughter to buy clothes, but I don't enjoy it because we like different things. I don't spend money on myself often, so when I do, I feel bad and don't tell my husband the real price. The real price is always too high. C. Juliet, 28, personnel manager I only shop for things I need. I don't like shopping and only go when I must. When I shop, I know what I want and I don't buy anything else. Shopping makes me tired and I always want to do something else. D. Anita, 35, TV producer I like to look around sometimes, but I know what I want and where to find it. I don't waste time and I shop quickly. I have some clothes I don't wear, so maybe I'm a careful shopper who sometimes makes mistakes! E. Lizzie, 41, secretary I don't like shopping at all. I don't like shopping for clothes because I can't find what I want or anyone to help me. The shops are too noisy and messy, and I don't like it. I don't shop for clothes often because people give me clothes. For food, I go to the supermarket once a week and finish quickly! F. Lisa, 22, actress I'm a happy shopper. Sometimes I go shopping with my friends, and we buy things. I don't look for something special, but if I see something nice, I buy it. G. Suki, 26, art gallery assistant I'm a careful shopper. I like shopping, but I don't buy much. I know what I want and don't spend too much. Sometimes I shop to feel better, but I feel worse because I spend too much! H. Ann-Marie, 29, nursery worker I love shopping, but not on busy days like Saturday. I'm a careful shopper. I know what I want and I look in many shops to find the best price. I take a long time! I. Linda, 32, restaurant manager I don't like shopping. I work in the city, so shops are not fun for me. When I have to shop, I go, but I don't try clothes on because it's too much work. Sometimes clothes don't fit, but I don't mind. I prefer to make a few mistakes than spend a lot of time shopping.'

'NEW CHANCES WITH AN OPEN UNIVERSITY DEGREE The Open University can give you a degree, just like other universities. But you can keep working while you study. It can also help you find new hobbies. If you have never studied before, you will enjoy learning new things. You will meet many different people. Your degree might also help you get a new job. You don't go to the Open University for classes. You study at home with TV, radio, and computer programs. You can go to one class a month at an Open University center if you want. There are exams, like in any university. If you want to know more, fill out the form below. It could be the start of a great new time in your life.'

**Gallery News**
**Easter Quiz for Children**
During the Easter holidays, children can join a quiz about "Surprises." You can get the free quiz sheets at the Orange Street entrance. Children will look at 14 surprising paintings and answer questions about them. The quiz is available from 25 March to 9 April during normal gallery hours.
**New Picture**
The Gallery has a new still life painting by Dutch artist Jan van Os from the 18th century. This large painting (89.1 cm x 71 cm) shows flowers and fruit in bright colors on wood. It is signed and dated 1777 and 1778 because the artist waited for flowers to bloom in different seasons. Miss Violet Churchman gave this picture to the Gallery in memory of her sister Ida Nancy. You can see it in Room 25.
**Special Exhibition**
The exhibition "Painting in Spain during the late 18th century" started on 15 March in the Sunley Room. The Gallery has new works by three Spanish painters: Paret, Melendez, and Francisco Bayeu. The exhibition also includes Francisco's brother Ramon, Antonio Gonzalez, and two Italians, Corrado Giaquinto and Giovanni Battista Tiepolo. The exhibition is open until 31 May.
**Lecture News**
There are lectures every Wednesday for the special exhibition. On 5 April, Lizzie Barker will talk about Melendez. On 12 April, Sarah Symmons will talk about Luis Paret. On 19 and 26 April, Juliet Wilson will talk about Francisco Bayeu. On Tuesdays in April, Erika Langmuir will explain how artists tell stories through pictures.
**Gallery Restaurant Improvements**
The Gallery restaurant now has better service and more food choices. It has new kitchens and offers many hot and cold dishes at good prices.
**Information for Visitors**
Free guided tours of the Gallery are every day at 11.00 am and 3.00 pm (except Sundays). These tours show some of the Gallery's best pictures and important European paintings from the 13th to the early 20th centuries.

'Little Chefs On Saturdays, a group of children aged ten to fifteen learn how to cook. These classes are very popular, and 30 children are waiting to join. Parents pay £280 for the course. Children have fun and learn to make good food. Bill, who is ten, says, 'I love my mum's cooking, and now I can cook better than her. The teachers make us laugh, especially when we eat the food we made.' Flora, who is twelve, finds it hard to cut onions. 'I love cooking. I cooked for ten friends, and they liked it. My mum said I should have a hobby instead of doing nothing on weekends. I liked staying at home, so I wasn't sure at first. But now I'm happy I came.' Their teacher, Philippe, says, 'It's great fun. Children listen and remember better than adults, but the kitchen is not always tidy when they cook! Adults always learn more about food. If parents teach their children to cook when they are young, they can make food for themselves when they leave home.''

'The Outdoor Centre Fees are for a car with four people. Each extra person costs 50p. You pay the fees at the main office. The centre is not a private club. It is a place for everyone to enjoy outdoor sports and fun activities. If you come with a group, please tell the centre before you visit. Windsurfing - One-day course Beginner windsurfing courses are on Saturdays and Sundays if the weather is good. Learning to windsurf is very fun. You will remember the first time you sail on the water. Boards with small sails are for beginners. Course fee: £32.50 (this includes all equipment) One-day adventure course This is a great chance for you. Try sailing, climbing, surfing, and archery. This course is for adults to enjoy outdoor activities in a fun way. You do not need to be very fit or have done these activities before. You just need to be interested. Course fee: £22.50 Play Park The Play Park is for children from two to ten years old. It is one of the best in the country. It has sand and water play, slides, a big ball pool, a play castle, and more. Next year, the centre will open a new Play Palace and Play Ship. Group day and residential courses We also have day and long weekend courses for groups. Schools, colleges, and youth groups visit us often. There are three big rooms with twelve beds each. You can book for groups of up to 36 people (minimum 12). Summer adventure holidays (for 8-14 years old) Sailing Climbing Windsurfing Fun Games Safety is very important at the Outdoor Centre. All staff know First Aid and can teach the activities. We make sure all children do activities that are right for their age and abilities. For this programme, children must be able to swim 25 metres and be healthy.'

'STAMP COLLECTING - A HOBBY THAT CAN GROW Many people of all ages enjoy stamp collecting. It is interesting and fun. Every year, more people start their own stamp collection. It can be a hobby for life. Starting a collection is easy because stamps are everywhere. You can find stamps on holiday postcards, birthday cards, and letters from friends. When you start collecting seriously, you might want to join the Stamp Collectors' Club. This club helps collectors get new British stamps. As a member, you can order new stamps for your collection. You can get them in three ways. We can send you a complete set of stamps on an envelope, or in a colorful pack with information. Or, we can send you the stamps to put in your own book. The Stamp Collectors' Club has about 70,000 members. You can join too. A two-year membership costs just £5. If a group joins together, you can get a discount. This is great value for money. When you join, the Club sends you a Starter Pack for free. It has 100 stamps and a nice box to keep them in. You also get a 4-page guide to collecting. It has tips and addresses of shops that sell stamps. Every two months, you get the club magazine. It has competitions, quizzes, and lets you exchange stamps with people around the world. Why not start a fun adventure? You will enjoy looking at the many different stamps in your collection. You can also search for special stamps. Join the Stamp Collectors' Club today and enjoy stamp collecting. To join, fill out the form and send your fee. Your Starter Pack will arrive within 28 days.'

'MONEY What is money? Money is like a gram or a kilometre. But you can use money to buy things. For example, a five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. The note is just a piece of paper that is cheap to make. Long ago, people did not have money like today. There were no banks or shops. Mr. Green, the farmer, traded his corn for Mr. Hive's honey. They exchanged things they both needed. Later, people made their own 'currencies' to trade more easily. Different currencies joined together, so now everyone uses a national currency.'

'Write a winning story! You could win £1,000 in this year's Fiction Prize and have your story printed in Keep Writing magazine. Ten other lucky people will win £100. We need people who can write good stories. The judges are Mary Littlejohn, a novelist, Michael Brown, a TV reporter, and Susan Hitchins, Keep Writing's editor. They want interesting and original stories. Last year, detective stories were popular, but the winner wrote a love story. You can write about anything, but here is some advice: Write about what you know This is important advice for every writer. Last year, many people wrote about love, family, and problems with friends. You need to make ordinary situations interesting. Make the reader want to keep reading by writing about ordinary things in a new way. Get your facts right If you describe a town or explain how something works, make sure it is correct. Do not write about things you are not sure about. Hold the reader's attention Make the beginning interesting and the ending a surprise. A bad ending is not good. Develop the story carefully and think of something unusual for the end. Think about the characters Make the people in your story seem real by using good words. Your story must be your own work, between 2,000 and 2,500 words, and typed, double-spaced, on one side of each sheet of paper. We cannot accept stories by fax or email. You must include the application form with your story. We cannot return your story or discuss our decisions. You should not have had any fiction printed in any magazine or book in this country, and the story must not have appeared in print or on radio or TV anywhere in the world. Your £5 fee will go to the Writers' Association. Make your cheque payable to Keep Writing and send it with the application form and your story. The closing date is 30 July, and we will tell the winner within one month. If you win, you must agree to have your story printed in our magazine.'

'THE FIRST WOMAN SCIENTIST Hypatia was born in Alexandria, Egypt, in 370 A.D. For many years, she was the only woman scientist in history books. Hypatia's father was the director of Alexandria University. He made sure his daughter got the best education. This was special because most women then could not study much. After studying in Athens and Rome, Hypatia went back to Alexandria to teach mathematics. She became famous for her new ideas. We do not have her books now, but we know she wrote important math works. Hypatia also liked technology and made some scientific tools. At that time, many rulers were afraid of science, and people connected to it were in danger. One day in March 415, Hypatia was attacked in the street and killed.'

'NENE VALLEY RAILWAY About the Railway The Nene Valley Railway is 12 kilometres long. It goes through the beautiful Nene Park. It starts in Peterborough and ends at Wansford, next to the main road. There is a 2-kilometre extension that takes passengers to Yarwell, the quiet end of the line. Ticket prices: adult £10.00, child £5.00, Family Ticket (up to 2 adults and 3 children) £25.00. Prices may change on public holidays. Nene Park Nene Park has golf courses and a big Caravan Club site. You can have a fun day with your family here. There are many hectares of parkland with lakes for boating, picnic areas, a nature reserve, and a small railway. Wansford Wansford Station has a special collection of old trains from Europe. You can see famous trains like the De Glen Compound from France and the German Class 52 Kriegslok, the largest working steam engine in Britain. You can visit these trains all year, even if the Nene Valley Railway is not running. The buffet, bar, and souvenir shop are open only when the train is running. There is an entrance fee of £2.00 for adults and £1.00 for children at Wansford. A Famous Railway Nene Valley Railway is popular with film makers because it can look like a railway from any part of Europe. The James Bond movie Octopussy was filmed here. Come and see where it was made. Services for Schools From May to July, the Railway has special services for school groups. Teachers can bring students to visit and do projects. There is an educational pack for £1.50 plus postage. At other times, schools can hire the train ('Teddy Bear') with up to 3 carriages on non-service days. Book one month in advance. There are special low prices for groups of 60 or more students. Call 01780 784444 for more information. Private Hire of Trains The Railway is a great place for family events or company visits. You can have a fun afternoon or evening here. Special programmes can include buffet, bar, entertainment, discos, etc. For more information, contact the General Manager at Wansford Station.'

'Grass Grass is a very successful plant. There are over 9,000 types of grass, and they are found everywhere in the world. Grass can live in very cold places like the Arctic and the Antarctic. Grasslands have many animals, from small insects and birds to big animals like cows and lions. All these animals need grass. Grass grows back quickly after it is cut or damaged. New leaves grow from below the soil, not from the top. This is why many animals can live in one place. When they eat all the grass, new grass grows again for them to eat.'

'The Young Achiever of the Year Kal Kaur Rai loves fashion. She just won the Young Achiever of the Year award at the Asian Business Awards. Since she was a child, she liked drawing clothes and making patterns. Her parents own a supermarket, and she never told them she wanted to make fashion her job. She thought they wanted her to do a different job, so she studied management at university. After university, she moved to London and worked in an advertising agency. She had to go to events but couldn't buy the expensive clothes she liked. So, she made skirts and tops for herself. Her friends liked her clothes and asked her to make some for them too. A small shop in London agreed to sell her designs. Her clothes sold well, and nothing came back. This made her happy, so she left her job, took a PS20,000 loan, and started her own clothing brand. Kal's parents were not angry about her new job and said they would help her, which made her very happy. Now, her clothes are in over 70 stores, and her business makes over PS500,000. Her clothes are in fashion magazines, she designs for pop stars, and she won this award. Her business has grown a lot, and she feels very lucky. 'What I do is my hobby - and I get paid for it! But remember, I've worked hard for this.''

'SUNNINGDALE HOTEL The Sunningdale Hotel was built in 1913 and opened by Princess Louise. Many people from different countries have stayed here. In the last 80 years, over 50,000 guests from 174 countries have visited Sunningdale. The hotel is on a main road to the town centre. It is about 20 minutes by bus from the town centre. Buses to other parts of the town stop outside the hotel. Do not take buses with the blue sign Express because they do not stop near the hotel. An underground station is less than 100 metres away. The main building has 200 single rooms. Each room has hot and cold water basins. Showers, baths, and toilets are at the end of the corridors. The hotel has a shop, sitting rooms, four TV rooms, a table tennis room, a library, and a laundry. There are eight pianos for guests to use. There is parking for cars. Free newspapers are provided, and you can buy stamps at the office. Guests staying a long time must pay weekly in advance and give one week's notice before leaving. Both short and long-term guests are welcome, but long-term guests get rooms first. Meal times are: breakfast 7 am - 9.30 am; lunch 1 pm - 2 pm; dinner 5.30 pm - 7 pm. During the week, if you study or work late, you can ask for dinner until 11 pm by writing your name on the late list or calling before 7 pm. There are 10 menu choices for breakfast and dinner. No animals or fires are allowed. Please keep noise down, especially between 11 pm and 8 am. If you arrive by train, it is best to take a taxi to the hotel because it is far from the main railway station.'

'Tom Cruise Tom Cruise is a very famous actor. But his life was not always easy. When he was a young boy, Tom was shy and had trouble making friends. He liked acting in school plays. After High School, Tom went to New York to find a job. He worked as a porter and went to drama classes. In 1980, a film director named Franco Zeffirelli gave Tom his first role in a movie. Ten years later, Tom was very successful and was one of the highest-paid actors in Hollywood. He earned millions of dollars for each movie. Today, Tom still acts in movies and is very popular with many fans all over the world.'

'LITTLE CAT, LITTLE CAT, WHERE HAVE YOU BEEN? Bo the cat wanted to explore a furniture van. She had a bigger adventure than she thought. The driver found her after driving more than 500 kilometres. It was the end of a long day. The driver and the cat were both hungry! He gave her some milk and started asking questions. He called his last customers, but they did not lose a cat. It was late, so he took Bo home for the night. The next morning, he took her to an animal hospital. The cat's owner was looking for her too. After searching everywhere, he remembered the furniture van that came to a neighbour's house. Luckily, he remembered the company's name. He called their office and soon Bo was back home safely.'

'The Ghan Train Mark Ottaway traveled by train from Darwin, in the north of Australia, to Adelaide, in the south. The Ghan train goes across Australia, from the warm north to the colder south. It is often called the 'famous Ghan', but it is known for being late. The idea of a train from Darwin to Adelaide started in the 1920s with a line from Adelaide to Alice Springs. But there was often flooding, making it hard for trains to pass. A new line was finished a few months before my trip. The train can go up to 115 kph, but it is not a high-speed train. There are few stops, and most passengers are on holiday. The Ghan does not offer luxury like the Orient Express, but the food is very good. The railway was first built to carry goods, not people. It was thought that sending goods from Europe to Australia's south via Darwin and the train would save time and money. The Ghan says it is the world's first north-south railway. As I waited to get on the Ghan, I saw that everyone was excited about the trip. Most of the travelers were older Australians. Our first stop was at Katherine, where the Ghan waited for four hours. Some passengers took a boat trip. I got off at Alice Springs and went on a two-day trip to Uluru (Ayers Rock) with a small group and a guide. Climbing the rock is not encouraged now, so we just walked around it and watched the sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many people stop here. After Alice Springs, the view from the train is not very interesting. There is a lot of flat land with cattle. But on the third day, we reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and even if the train did not do everything the ads said, it took me to some of the most amazing places in Australia.'

'Climbing to the top of Britain Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis in Scotland. Because it is in the north, the weather can be very cold. Climber Keith Hewitt talks about his first time on Ben Nevis. It was February, my first big winter climb. We went up the north side of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It is six hundred metres high - maybe the longest climb in Britain. We planned to camp for three days in the 'Carries', which are like big bowls in the mountain walls halfway up. We carried tents, sleeping bags, and metal spikes for our boots. You need them because the snow is very hard, like ice. Even though some people in the group were very experienced, we took all kinds of safety equipment, like lights to get attention, hard hats, and extra clothes. The weather forecast was good, with no strong winds, but we still felt nervous when we started. Ben Nevis in winter is always difficult. The path soon went up, and my legs felt tired. I was the weakest in the group, so I had to rest more often. The others sometimes stopped to let me catch up, but when I reached them, they started again. I promised myself to train better before a climb next time. After 200 metres, we reached the start of Tower Ridge, the path to the top of Ben Nevis. It is only one and a half metres wide, and the mountain drops hundreds of metres on each side. We knew we had to stay calm and focus on every step as we moved slowly. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, 48 kilometres away. But we were not so lucky because there was mist. On Ben Nevis, going back down to camp can be as hard as going up. You need to read a map well because a wrong turn could lead to dangerous slopes in winter. I was happy we took turns to do that job. That first time, I only felt happy when I was safe in the tent. But at least I made it to the top.'

Anna's New School
This week has been very exciting because we moved to our new school building! It is a wonderful place. The builders used wood for the whole building, just like our old school. But this school is special because it is one of the first in my country to be very good for the environment. It took many months to build, so we watched it happen. It was exciting to see the builders clear the land, but it was sad to lose some nice open space. The building machines were very loud, and sometimes the builders had to stop because of the rain. We thought the building would never be finished.
Now, we have five big classrooms, much bigger than in our old school next door, which was very old. We share one room with people in the town for meetings. There is also a nursery, a nice dining room, and big changing rooms. We are excited to use them when our new sports field is ready.
When you come into the school, you will see there are no heaters! The heat comes from us - the children, the teachers, and the computers. The building keeps all the heat inside, and it keeps the sound inside too. When we sing, it feels like we are in a concert hall!
Another interesting thing is the tree on the roof! The builders put it there because it is a custom in Austria, where the roof was made. The electricity for lights and computers comes from a wind turbine on a hill behind the school. We visited it with our teacher yesterday. It spins very fast and is so big you can see it from far away! We took pictures to put on the website.
Even though we are using the school now, some parts are not finished yet. For example, we are doing a play for parents, but we have to go back to our old school hall for it. The new hall will be ready next year. We are very happy with our new school, and our teachers say we will learn much faster here!

'A Fun Weekend A month ago, I didn't know that on a Saturday in November, I would be 30 metres above the ground and enjoying it. Now, I looked down at the river far below and understood why people love rock-climbing. My friend Matt and I arrived at the Activity Centre on Friday evening. The place to stay wasn't great, but we had what we needed (beds, blankets, food), and we were happy to be out of the city and in the fresh air. On Saturday morning, we met the other ten people in our group. Cameron came with two friends, Kevin and Simon, while sisters Carole and Lynn came with Amanda. We all came from different places and didn't know the area. We knew we would spend the weekend outside, but we weren't sure what we would do. Half of us went caving in the morning while the others went rock-climbing, and then we switched at lunchtime. Matt and I went to the caves first. Climbing out was harder than going in, but after a lot of pushing, we were out at last - covered in mud but happy and excited about what we did.'

'Letter to the Newport Evening News On Saturday afternoon, I left my handbag on the bus. In my handbag, there were my cheque book, address book, and my purse. My purse had about £50 in cash and some credit cards. When I realized what I had done, it was too late. I didn't know what to do. I am 72 years old, I was far from home, and I was very worried. I stood by the side of the road and cried. A young man asked me what was wrong, and I told him what happened. He gave me some money for my bus fare home. When I told the bus driver what happened, he said I should keep the fare. I got home safely, and the telephone rang soon after. It was the manager of CityBus, the company that owned the bus where I left my handbag. He said they had my handbag and offered to bring it back to me. I got my handbag back, with everything still inside. I want to say how wonderful everyone was who helped me that day, and how much I appreciate their kindness and honesty. Mrs. B. James, Newport'

'Sharks Sharks are some of the scariest animals in the ocean. They are good at finding food because they can see well and feel movement with special lines on their bodies. This makes sharks dangerous for smaller sea animals that they eat. Sharks are like other fish in some ways, but their bodies are different. For example, most sharks need to swim all the time to breathe and stay alive, so they almost never sleep. Also, if sharks are turned over on their backs, they can stop moving. This helps researchers who study sharks. It lets them learn more about these interesting animals.'
