'Joining the Kirov Ballet
I'm Nathalie. Last year, I joined the Kirov's ballet school in St Petersburg, Russia. I was one of the youngest foreign students. At my first ballet class, I was nervous because I didn't know anyone. Everyone asked me questions in Russian. I tried to speak Russian, and then they spoke in English, so we could talk. Now, six months later, everyone is nice to me. My Russian is much better, and I understand my teachers. 
For the first two weeks, my mum stayed with me. When she left, I was a bit sad. I called home late at night once because I felt lonely. The classes in Russia are very hard compared to my ballet school in England. I eat a lot to have enough energy. This makes me confident I can do well. In the evenings, I watch my favorite films on my computer, but sometimes I fall asleep before the film ends. Now, I feel at home here. I like walking around the city and going to the shops, even in December when it was very cold. I bought a fur hat because it was minus 10°C, but the Russians said it was not very cold for that time of year! At least my room was warm and cozy.
Right now, we are preparing for a new show. There is also a competition for young dancers, and I will enter. I feel very lucky to be here.'

'THE ICEHOTEL For many years, people visited the Arctic in the summer to see the midnight sun. In winter, only a few people lived there with the snow and ice. In the late 1980s, people thought winter could be special too. In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit opened an art show in an igloo (a house made of snow) in Jukkasjarvi, a small town on the frozen Torne River. This place, called Arctic Hall, had many visitors. One night, some visitors decided to sleep in the Arctic Hall. They liked it very much, and this started the idea of an ice hotel. Today, the ICEHOTEL is famous around the world. When winter starts, snow builders, architects, and artists from many countries come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. As soon as one part is ready, it opens to visitors and guests, while other parts are still being built. The first part is ready in December, and new parts open each week until January 7th, when the hotel is finished. The hotel is built outside with natural winter materials, so the finish date can change. In spring, the hotel melts. Inside the hotel, the temperature is always between -5°C and -8°C, even if it is colder outside. Warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves are included in the hotel stay. Guests should also bring sweaters, a scarf, and many wool socks. Shoes should be bigger than normal to fit thick socks. If you plan to visit, you can buy warm clothes and socks on the ICEHOTEL website. You can order these when you book your visit, and they will be in your room when you arrive. The hotel is in Jukkasjarvi, 200 km above the Arctic Circle, but only 15 km from Kiruna airport and 17 km from Kiruna train station. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the ICEHOTEL.'

'Shopping for furniture A report by Dave Worthington Homestyle is a new furniture shop. It had to close soon after it opened at midnight last Thursday. Up to 6,000 people came to the shop. There were many special offers, like a leather sofa for £45 (only until 3 am) and a bed for £30 (only between 3 am and 8 am). The shop's normal hours will be 9 am to 9 pm every day. But Homestyle said it would stay open for 24 hours on the first day. However, it had to close in half an hour. A police officer said: 'The police knew many people would come, but they were not patient. The shop was full, so the managers closed the doors. People outside got angry because they thought everything would be sold before they could enter. They did not want to wait quietly. Also, there was a long line of cars trying to get to the car park. Many people left their cars in the road and walked to the shop. This blocked the road.' One customer, Jenny Smith, got into the shop. She said: 'I waited for three hours and didn't have time to buy what I wanted. But the staff were calm and explained what was happening. They had no choice, as it wasn't safe. I will come back when they reopen, but I don't want to wait in line again.'

'Membership The Short Story Society helps writers in Britain today. It started in 1899 and is now one of Britain's most active arts groups. Society Magazines We make several great magazines, including the popular Short Story Review. This magazine has short stories by some of Britain's best writers and gives new writers a chance to have their work printed. Another magazine, Short Story News, has interviews with writers and information about events, competitions, and festivals. You can see some articles from recent issues on this website. National Short Story Competition We have the National Short Story Competition, the biggest competition of its kind. It is open to anyone aged 18 and over, and short stories on any topic are accepted. Stories should be between 1,000 and 1,500 words long. There is no entry fee for Society members (non-members pay an entry fee of £5). The competition runs from April to the end of October each year. The ten best stories will be in the Society's annual book of short stories. The winner will get a publishing contract to make their own collection of short stories. Education For nearly thirty years, the Society has taken writers into classrooms, giving children and teachers new ideas and building confidence in their writing. Current projects include the Young Writer of the Year, which started in 1998 and is open to writers aged 11-18. All winners get book prizes and can study on a five-day course taught by professional writers. The Writers' Cafe The Writers' Cafe is the social center of the Society. It is relaxed and stylish, with freshly cooked vegetarian food, excellent coffees, and cold drinks. It is a great place to read the Society's magazines. The Cafe also has monthly exhibitions, short courses, and readings. It is in the heart of London and is open from 11.00 am to 10.00 pm Monday to Friday and 11.00 am to 8.00 pm on Saturday. Society members get discounts on selected products and events. Becoming a Member We have members worldwide, and anyone aged eighteen or over can join. If you want to join The Short Story Society, click here and fill out a registration form.'

'Free-diving in the Caribbean Tanya Streeter has four world records in free-diving. Free-diving is a sport where people dive deep into the ocean on one breath of air. In 2003, Tanya Streeter became the first person to dive 120 metres deep and come back up without help. She had gone deeper a year before but used a balloon to come up. This time, she held her breath for over three and a half minutes. She was the first woman to break a man's world record in any sport. Fourteen safety divers watched her dive. Some people say free-diving is too dangerous because of accidents, but Tanya thinks safety and training are very important. Most free-divers focus on one or two events, but Tanya's training is always the same. She spends most of her time training on land at the gym. She also trains in the pool and the ocean. She uses an exercise bike to make her heart strong. She does not run because she wants to protect her knees. Instead, she walks fast to stay fit. When she practices diving, she often travels. She does fourteen dives in four weeks, with a rest day between each dive. It is important she does not get tired. When Tanya is not training, she appears in public to promote sports products. She also helps environmental groups by doing research or making films. Tanya grew up on the Caribbean island of Grand Cayman. She loved swimming and exploring rock pools to see sea life. She says her life now is like her childhood dreams. Tanya is famous in some countries, so people listen to her about the environment. Tanya is in her thirties and wants to keep breaking her own records. She started free-diving at twenty-five and does not plan to stop for many years.'

'CARTOON FILMS Cartoon films can do many things. If you can draw something, you can make it move on the cinema screen. New ideas and computer programs make cartoons fun for everyone again. In the late 1970s, people thought cartoons were only for children. But then, some directors had new ideas. They showed that both adults and children could enjoy cartoons. Not every cartoon film was a success. The Black Cauldron, for example, did not do well because it was too scary for children and too simple for adults. Directors learned from this, and film companies started making a lot of money again.'

'New TV Star Caroline Benson talks about her first TV role 'I never thought I would spend my first year at university filming The Finnegans. I had only acted at school, but I loved the book since I was eleven. My grandmother said I was like Polly Finnegan, and I always wanted to play her. I took a year off to travel before university. While I was in Chile, my mother emailed me about plans to make the book into a TV show. I knew I had to try for the part. My mother was surprised, but she sent my photo to the director and convinced him to meet me. I flew back and got the part. Filming started a week after university began, so I got permission to be away for three weeks. When I returned, I woke up at 6.00am to write the essays I missed. I didn't tell my university friends, but they found out and thought it was great. It was an amazing experience. After university, I want to be an actress. I'm not from an acting family, but my grandfather was an opera singer. I've tried for other TV roles but haven't got any offers yet. I don't know how I did it all, because I had a busy social life too. When filming finished, I didn't know what to do. I've been in two college plays since then. I haven't been home much, and now my first year at university is over, I'm going to Greece for the summer with friends.''

'No Title When I opened the first 'Body Shop' in 1976, I wanted to make enough money to take care of my children. Today, 'The Body Shop' is a big company growing all over the world. Since we started, I have learned many things. You can find what I learned in this book. I think our company has something important to say about running a good business without losing our true beliefs. This is not a normal business book, and it is not just about my life. The message is that to do well in business, you have to be different. Business can be fun, it can be run with love, and it can do good things. In business, like in life, I need to enjoy myself, feel like a family, and be excited by surprises. I want the people who work for 'The Body Shop' to feel the same way. Now, this book shares my ideas with everyone. I hope there are no limits to our 'family' and no limits to what we can do. I find that exciting. I hope you do, too.'

'A TRIP ON THE BEAUTIFUL DOURO RIVER JULES VERNE offers a 'hotel ship' trip on the Douro river in Portugal. The ship, MV Lady Ivy May, can take 160 guests in double rooms. All rooms have a private shower and toilet. The ship has air-conditioning, a sun-deck, lounge, bar, dining room, shop, and library. Plan Day 1 Leave in the early evening from London Heathrow to Oporto. Your guide will meet you and take you to the Lady Ivy May, where you will sleep. Day 2 In the morning, you will see Oporto. Then, you will return to the ship and go to Entre-os-Rios. This trip takes four hours. Day 3 You will continue up the river. In the early evening, the ship stops at Peso da Regua, where port wine is made. At dinner, you can try the food and drink from this area. Day 4 After breakfast, you will go by bus to the old town of Lamego. You will visit the cathedral, some churches, and a museum. The museum was a palace and has many paintings, tapestries, and sculptures. You will then return to the ship and sail to Tua. Day 5 Here, the Douro is very narrow. If the river is deep enough, you may go by a smaller boat to the Spanish border at Barca d'Alva. You will return to Tua by bus and see many things on the way. Day 6 In the morning, you will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a great view of the Douro valley. You will return to the ship for lunch and then take a train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will wait for you. Day 7 You will visit Vila Real before returning to the ship for lunch and then go down the river to Oporto. You will sleep on the Lady Ivy May. Day 8 You will arrive in Oporto with time for sightseeing and shopping before your flight home to London Heathrow.'

'HONEY Honey is a sweet liquid made by bees. It has water and sugars. Bees can travel up to seventy-five thousand kilometers and visit over two million flowers to make just half a kilo of honey. The color and taste of honey depend on the type of flower. There are more than three hundred types of honey. Lighter-colored honey is usually milder in taste than darker honey. In ancient times, honey was the main sweet food because sugar was very rare. Honey was very important to the ancient Egyptians, who used it as money. Today, honey is made and eaten all over the world. Research says it can help with tiredness and improve sports performance. Honey is not just food - it can help with sore throats and is used in many skin and hair-care products.'

'Norwich Norwich is the capital of East Anglia, a part of Britain. People have lived there for more than two thousand years. It started as a small village by the River Wensum. By 1066, during the Norman invasion, it was one of the largest towns in England. Norwich has two cathedrals and a mosque, making it a popular place for different religions. The first cathedral was built in 1095 and recently celebrated its 900th anniversary. In 1994, Norwich celebrated 800 years since it became a city with a Royal Charter, which allowed it to govern itself. Today, Norwich is smaller than London or Manchester, with about 150,000 people. In the 16th century, it was the second largest city in England. It grew for 300 years and became rich, known for having many churches and pubs. Now, there are fewer churches and pubs, but the University of East Anglia was built in 1964. Norwich has many students and is a modern commercial centre, especially for insurance services. The city offers entertainment like theatres, cinemas, nightclubs, cafes, restaurants, and arts centres. Norwich also has a football team called 'The Canaries', with green and yellow colors. The city has a modern shopping centre called 'The Castle Mall'. Builders made a big hole in the city for over two years to create it. The roof of the Mall is now a city centre park with water pools and trees. People are happy that the old market is still there, next to the new shopping centre. Both places are popular, showing that Norwich mixes old and new well.'

'The Albuquerque Balloon Festival Every autumn, the sky above Albuquerque, a city in the south-western United States, becomes full of bright colors. This is the Albuquerque Balloon Festival, a nine-day event every year. The first festival was in 1972 for the 50th birthday of a local radio station. There were about twelve hot-air balloons, and they took off from a car park in the middle of Albuquerque. Since then, the festival has grown. This year, at least a thousand balloons from many countries are expected at the festival's current location outside the city. What to see The pilots talk to each other by radio and light up their balloons at the same time. These are called 'balloon glows' and are great for taking photos. You must arrive just after nightfall or before 5.30 am to see these 'glows' as the balloons rise into the dark sky. During the day, you can walk around the balloons and talk to the pilots as they get ready to fly. The balloons come in all sizes and colors, some shaped like animals, cartoon characters, or famous products like soft drinks and fast food. Kids will love it. In the afternoon, you can also take a balloon ride over the desert with one of the many companies offering flights. Another option is to take the cable car from the desert to the top of the nearby mountains, the longest ride of its kind, and enjoy a view of the festival from above. There are many other attractions for visitors of all ages, including balloon races and fireworks on the first and last three nights of the festival. The Albuquerque Box This is a local wind pattern that is perfect for balloonists. The Sandia Mountains protect the balloons from strong winds and create gentle winds at different heights. This means that by going up or down, skilled pilots can control where their balloons go. Practical advice Buy your tickets in advance (they are available online) to avoid long lines at the festival. Wear several layers of thin clothing. At night and in the early morning, it can be cool, but during the day, sunglasses and sunscreen are important. Bring a flashlight for night events and, of course, bring your camera. If you don't use a digital camera, you'll need high-speed film for evening and night pictures.'

'The Eden Project The Eden Project is in the south-west of England. It is one of the UK's most popular places to visit. When you see it, the big 'biospheres' look like something from a science-fiction movie. Each biosphere has a different climate. This shows visitors how important the relationship between people and plants is. It is surprising to see how many things we use every day come from plants: wood, rubber, fruit, rice, sugar, coffee, and chocolate, for example. There are over 135,000 different types of plants here. Even if it is cold outside, electric heaters keep the plants warm. In the Rainforest Zone, it is always wet because of a big waterfall. Another zone is like the environment of the Mediterranean, California, and South Africa. There are plans to build a desert zone soon.'

'No Title Some people did not like this year's book, New Writing 3, but I don't know why. It has 500 pages of new writing for only £6.99, which is great! Most of the book is fiction, with parts of novels and short stories. There are fun stories by famous writers like Candia McWilliam and Rose Tremain. It's interesting that less famous writers wrote mostly about food. Be careful with Jane Harris's Those Nails - don't read it after eating. It has some scenes that might make you feel sick! There is also good work from nineteen poets, like R. S. Thomas and John Burnside. There are parts of novels being written by Jim Crace and Jane Rogers. Lastly, there is a little non-fiction, including a funny article by Alan Rusbridger about newspapers, and an interesting piece about herself by Ursula Owen. This is a special collection, and I am excited to see what next year's book will have.'

'No Title "The best age to start learning the violin is between three and six," says Margaret Porter, a violinist and music teacher. "This is when you are learning about the world." Margaret lives in London and likes to teach children who are three or four years old, but she also teaches some five-year-olds who really want to learn. She started teaching the violin in 1972, and her first class was with her children's five-year-old friends. Margaret's students have group lessons. Each group has about twelve students, and each lesson is one hour long, every two weeks. Also, each student has one private lesson with her every week. Parents must come to the classes too. It is important that parents are interested in the lessons. From the first lessons, students learn to play by listening. They do not try to read music until they have been playing for many years. There is a big difference between their playing and reading music for a long time. Margaret says her method is not to make great violinists. She suggests that students who do very well should leave and study the violin with more traditional methods.

'Moonshine The band Moonshine released their third CD last week. 'Here Again' is the new CD after 'The Waves'. There are some changes since the last CD. Tom Wilcott is now playing bass guitar instead of Simon McVee, who left the band last year. Tom Simpson is the new drummer. The first song on the CD is a dance song, showing the band is not only playing slow songs now. The second song is also a dance song and is even louder. Most of the other songs are in the band's usual slow style. These two songs will surprise many fans. They could become hit singles because they are very good. Singer Rob Letchford sings perfectly on these songs. Fans should be happy he recorded them before he had problems with his throat. Because of this, the band had to cancel their next tour. (People who bought tickets do not need to worry because all the concerts will be rescheduled when Rob is better.) On this CD, Moonshine shows they can make great music in different styles, from slow to dance. I think the best songs are at the beginning, and the last few songs are not as good. Despite this, 'Here Again' will probably be a big hit and bring more success to the band.'

'San Francisco San Francisco is a city on the coast of northern California. The first Europeans to find the area were led by a Spanish explorer named Gaspar de Portola. He saw it for the first time in 1769. Even though San Francisco Bay is a great natural harbour, it was found by people on land, not by people on boats. In 1849, many people came to San Francisco to look for gold. But it was not the gold seekers who became rich. The richest people made money by owning banks and law firms. They built big houses on a hill called Nob Hill. Today, tourists visit San Francisco to see famous places like Chinatown and the Golden Gate Bridge. Many also take a short boat trip to Alcatraz Island to see the old prison.'

'SAMUEL PEPYS Samuel Pepys wrote the most famous diary in English. His diary tells us about life in England from 1660 to 1669. Pepys writes about big news stories, like a disease, enemy ships on the River Thames, and the Great Fire of London. He also writes about himself, like sleeping in church or looking at pretty girls. He talks about his home life, like a fight with his wife and how they made up, and his worry about her being sick. Pepys liked books, music, the theatre, card games, and fun parties with good food. He was a busy man with many important jobs. He was a Member of Parliament and President of the Royal Society. He is also known for his work with the British Navy.'

'The History of Shoes In the past, shoes were not comfortable or fashionable. Early shoes were probably animal skins that people tied around their ankles in cold weather. We still use leather today, but we also use other materials like silk, plastic, or cotton, depending on fashion. About one hundred and fifty years ago, people started wearing a different shoe on each foot. Before that, both shoes were straight and could be worn on either foot. All shoes used to be made by hand, but now most shoes are made by machines in big factories. Sewing machines helped the shoe industry make many cheap shoes for more people.'

'Running Club for Women When I hurt my back, I had to stop running for a while. I wanted to help more women try running. I wanted to show them it is fun and help them feel confident to run. I started a running club for women in my area. I was upset because many race organizers complain there are not enough women in the sport, but they do not provide separate changing rooms for women. I put up posters, and 40 women joined the club. They were young and old, fit and not fit. They wanted to lose weight, but I don't think they thought about running before. When they did think about it, they imagined hard training. They did not think about talking and smiling while running in nice places, like by a river. At first, they ran for only one minute. Now they can run for thirty minutes. They also learned about diet and fitness from other runners. I wanted to help women's running, and I have enjoyed watching them get better - almost as much as they have enjoyed it themselves.'

'THE HISTORY OF THE IDITAROD - THE LAST GREAT RACE ON EARTH In the 1880s, people found gold in Alaska, the most northern state of the USA. Many people went there to find gold and become rich. New towns were built quickly. One town was called Iditarod, which means 'far, distant place'. In 1909, Iditarod grew very fast and became the largest city in Alaska for a short time. In summer, boats could bring important things to these towns. But in winter, the rivers and ocean froze, so boats could not travel. In 1910, a winter path was made for dog teams pulling sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This path was called the Iditarod Trail. It took about three weeks for a dog team to travel across Alaska. They stopped at 'roadhouses' where the drivers and dogs could rest and eat. The trail was used every winter until the 1920s when planes started to be used instead of dog teams. But in 1925, a disease called diphtheria was in the city of Nome. The medicine to cure it was in Anchorage, far away. Planes were new, and people were not sure if they could fly in the cold. Also, the best pilot, Carl Eielson, was not there. So, they decided to use dog teams to bring the medicine. The trip was over 1,000 kilometers, mostly on the Iditarod Trail. It took twenty teams six days to finish. Leonhard Seppala, from Norway, traveled the first 400 kilometers. He trusted his dog Togo to find the way in the snow. The last part was done by Gunnar Kaasen, who had worked with dog teams in Alaska for 21 years. His lead dog was Balto. Balto saved the team from falling into icy water. The diphtheria was stopped, and Balto became a hero. Now, there is a dog sled race every year from Anchorage to Nome, following the 1925 route. It is called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.'

'Sweden's Ice Hotel The village of Jukkasjarvi is in Swedish Lapland. In winter, it can be very cold, sometimes -40°C. But 6,000 people visit every year to see a special hotel. This hotel is made of ice. You can eat, drink, and sleep in rooms made of ice. You can even get married there. The bar is also made of ice, so you should not put hot drinks on it! The bedrooms are about -4°C, but guests get special sleeping bags to stay warm. You can also get warm clothes if you need them. The hotel is new every winter because it melts in summer. It takes 10,000 tonnes of ice and 30,000 tonnes of snow to build the hotel.'

'Maria Mutola In 1988, Maria Mutola was the only girl playing football in a boys' team in Mozambique. 'We won,' she said. 'At first, no one thought it was a problem that I was a girl. But then the team we beat complained.' A local newspaper wrote about her, and Jose Craveirinha, who helped other African athletes, heard about Maria. He went to see her and saw her playing football. He noticed she was very fast. 'He talked to me about running. I didn't know what he meant. I only knew football. Then he bought me running shoes and took me to train. It was very hard, and my legs hurt.' But Jose talked to her parents and convinced them she could be successful and help the family. They agreed to let her go with him to train. In 1991, she finally went to train in the United States. She had said no before because she would miss her family. Her life was different from the girls she met in the US. She says, 'They were good athletes, but I worried about my parents having enough food, while they worried about dresses and make-up. They didn't know much about me or my problems. But I knew I was lucky to be there. The trainers were great, and I learned a lot.' Today, Maria still runs and lives most of the year in South Africa with her mother.'

'The Skywalk The Grand Canyon in the United States was made by the Colorado River. People visit the Grand Canyon Park to walk, run, and mostly to see the view. The view is very beautiful, and the Skywalk makes it even better. The Skywalk is 1219 meters above the bottom of the Grand Canyon. It is a platform with glass walls and floor, so you can see the rocks below. Up to 120 people can stand on it at the same time. It opened in 2007, and many people have visited it since then. You must wear special covers on your shoes to keep the glass clean. Walking on the Skywalk feels like you are a bird flying high in the air.'

'THE ROCKIES The Rocky Mountains are a long group of mountains in North America. They start in the North-west and go down to the middle of the continent. The Rockies are smaller than the Alps, but they are still very beautiful. There are many roads in the Rockies, but the best way to see them is by train. You start from Vancouver, a very nice city in Canada. Vancouver is near the water and the mountains. People can ski just 15 minutes by car from the city center. Before, thirty trains left Vancouver every day to go across the country. Now, there are only three trains a week, but the trip is still exciting. You sleep on the train, which is fun, but you see some of the best views at night.'

'ZOOS People started keeping animals in zoos over 3,000 years ago. The rulers of China opened a big zoo called the Gardens of Intelligence. In many old zoos, animals had to perform for visitors. This does not happen now. Today, zoos are for people to see animals behaving naturally. Most cities have a zoo or wildlife park. But not everyone likes zoos. Some people think zoos are good because they help us learn about animals and nature. Without zoos, this would be hard. Other people do not like zoos because they think it is wrong to keep animals in cages. They also say that in some zoos, animals live in dirty places and eat bad food.'

'JAZZ By Katie Atkins, aged 14 I play the trumpet in my school jazz band. Last month, we had a jazz competition with bands from local high schools, and our band won! Each band wore different clothes, from black school uniforms like my band to bright T-shirts. We didn't look like adult professional bands, but we were used to playing in competitions, so the music was really good, especially because everyone was so young. Players from each band even made new tunes on stage. It was exciting to watch, but even better when my band played! We have a great jazz band at my school, but not everyone who wants to play can join - only about half can. But anyone who wants to play goes to jazz practice before school, and we often spend time together after school, listening to jazz and learning about it. There are also trips to jazz summer camps around the country - I've been to a couple and learned a lot. Adults are often surprised that young people like jazz. My music teacher thinks it's because pop music isn't hard enough for people like me who are serious about music. But I find jazz exciting because it's both new and old - you can make your own music, but you also feel part of its history, playing on stage like great jazz performers before you. My school is really lucky because we have great teachers and parents who support us. Without them, we wouldn't get far with our music!'

'Watering the Desert It can rain between November and March in Marrakesh, Morocco. It doesn't rain often, and when it does, the city's water pipes can't handle the sudden floods. The streets become like rivers. But, because many winters have been dry recently, people are happy when it rains. Marrakesh's parks and gardens are not green because of the rain. They are green because of underground channels. These channels were made in the 11th century. They bring water from the mountains all year. Dry places that get water this way are called oases. South of Marrakesh is Skoura. Here, people use every piece of land to grow food. They make small squares with water channels. The Atlas mountains, covered in snow in winter, are a beautiful background.'

Gareth Ellis
Gareth Ellis is 13 years old. He is the youngest son of Alan and Kath. Alan is an engineer, and Kath is a nursery teacher. Gareth has older brothers who work in banking and computers. But Gareth wants to be a clown. 
Three years ago, Alan, Kath, and Gareth joined the circus. Kath says, 'People laugh when we tell them, but it's true. Gareth has wanted to be a clown since he was three years old when we took him to the circus.' 
When Alan lost his job, he and Kath looked for jobs in the circus. They both got jobs with a famous circus, and Gareth started training to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and come home in the winter. Gareth's brothers take care of the house when they are away. 
Kath says, 'It wasn't easy. We had a lot to think about. We only had a car and a small caravan to sleep in, and we left our nice house. The only thing Gareth missed was his long, hot baths.'
Gareth says, 'People ask about my education, but everywhere we go, someone teaches me. I use the same books as my classmates at school, and I have a computer. I have never fallen behind.'
And the future? Kath says, 'It was a hard decision, but it was the only way for Gareth to learn to be a clown. I'm happy it's working, and we like it.' 
And Gareth? 'I will be the main clown in a circus one day,' he says, 'maybe Bippo's circus.'

'Eight-eighteen News Eight-eighteen News is a news group for young people. Our members are aged 8-18. We collect news and write reports, stories, and articles. We send these to big newspapers, magazines, TV, radio, and websites. You can read or listen to our news on the Eight-eighteen website. We have three places in the country where young people can meet and work on projects. We want to open more places. Our news group started in 1994 and was called 'Young News'. More than 2,500 young people have been members. Sophie was one of them. She says: 'I first heard of Eight-eighteen when they interviewed me about hip hop music. I was surprised by the chances they had. Age didn't matter, they did the stories by themselves. I went to the Eight-eighteen place in my city, got training, and was a member until I was 18. Eight-eighteen helped me do more than I thought. With the skills I learned, I got a job at 19. Now, I am the youngest worker at a big news website, checking articles before they go online.' Get involved at every level When you join Eight-eighteen, you will get training and join meetings every month to decide who will write each news story. Eight-eighteen helps members share skills. 'Peer trainers' are members who are 12 years old and over. They teach new members basic journalism skills. As they get better, some members teach young people and adults outside Eight-eighteen, often in youth clubs and summer camps. Older staff help them on these trips. Eight-eighteen News has training for new members three times a year. Our next training is in February. If you or someone you know wants to join, call Director Den Ley at 01622 657874 for more information. The Eight-eighteen programme is good for children with all levels of reading and writing skills. Membership is free and there is no test to join.'

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights Website**
Welcome to our website. Here is what you need to know before booking a flight. During the short Antarctic summer, we take tourists in a big plane (Boeing 747) from Sydney, Australia, over Antarctica and back. Flight dates for next year are not set yet, but if you book now, you can change the date if needed.
**Questions**
These are answers to common questions about Antarctica Sightseeing Flights.
**How long is the flight?**
The flight is about 12 hours. After four hours, we usually see the first sea ice and icebergs. We spend four hours over Antarctica and the rest of the time flying back. On the way, experts who have lived in Antarctica talk about the environment and history, and answer questions. A camera near the pilot shows you what the pilot sees from take-off to landing.
**Will I get a seat next to a window?**
All passengers get two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you change to the seat on your second pass. Business and first class passengers have a window seat for half the flight and a seat next to the window for the other half. Economy passengers have a window seat or a seat next to it for half the flight and an end of row seat for the other half. Over Antarctica, we encourage you to move around the plane to see the sights. The pilot flies in long 'figure 8s' so everyone can see well from both sides of the plane.
**What happens if the weather is bad?**
We have 17 different flight plans. Our captain checks the weather on the morning of the flight and chooses the best direction for clear views.
**Will I see penguins and other wildlife?**
Most Antarctic animals live at sea level, over 3,000 meters below the plane, so we can't see them well. We do not land on Antarctica to protect the environment. To see Antarctic animals, you need to join a boat tour.
**Can I take photographs?**
Yes! You can bring your camera. We also have fun photo opportunities on the plane where you can try on Antarctic cold weather clothes.

'Winter Driving Winter can be dangerous because it is hard to know what will happen, and accidents can happen easily. Fog can be at the top of a hill. Ice might be under the melting snow, ready to make you slide off the road. The car coming towards you might suddenly slide across the road. Rule Number One for driving on icy roads is to drive smoothly. Quick movements can make a car hard to control. So when you turn the wheel, touch the brakes, or speed up, do it gently and slowly. Imagine you have a full cup of hot coffee next to you. Drive so you don't spill it. Rule Number Two is to watch what might happen. The more ice there is, the further you need to look down the road. Test how long it takes to stop by braking gently. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. In general, allow double your normal stopping distance when the road is wet, three times this distance on snow, and even more on ice. Try to stay in control of your car at all times to avoid trouble.'

'Craigie Aitchison Craigie Aitchison was a painter from Scotland. He went to London to study law, but he chose to go to art school instead. At art school, he found drawing classes hard, but he kept painting. In his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art in Italy. He liked early Italian artists, and this shows in his work. He loved the green and brown colors of the Italian fields and the clear light there. He wanted to show this light in his paintings. He painted colors in thin layers, from light to dark, but he says he never knows how it will look. He says, 'It's a secret - because I don't know myself. I don't start by painting yellow, knowing I'm going to put anything on top.' Aitchison makes it sound easy. 'Anyone can do the colors - you can buy them. I simply notice what you put the colors next to.' He never makes drawings before he starts a painting because he thinks he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, he changes his paintings many times before they are done. This is why he likes models who don't ask to see their pictures while he is painting them. 'If I feel they're worried and want to look at the painting, I can't do it.' Since he moved to London, he does not feel part of the Scottish painting scene. He says he does not want to follow any tradition, but just paints the way he can. However, his work still influences young British painters.'

'Rock Band Two years ago, our 14-year-old son, Ben, asked us for a set of drums for his birthday. At first, we did not like the idea because of the noise. 'It's better than watching TV or playing computer games in my free time,' Ben said, 'and it will keep me out of trouble.' In the end, we agreed. 'All right,' we said, 'but you must think about the rest of the family and the neighbours when you play.' That was just the start. Because drums are not easy to move, the other members of Ben's band started coming to our home with their guitars and other equipment. So, for several hours a week, the house is loud with their instruments and singing. At least Ben's hobby is good for our health: when the band starts playing, my husband and I go out for a long walk. And I must say that, although their music sounds a little strange, they are a friendly and polite group of young men. I cannot say if they are good at music - after all, I didn't expect my parents to like the same music as I did when I was a teenager - but they do play often in local clubs for young people. Our main worry is that they won't spend enough time on their school work because of their music, though this hasn't happened yet. I always tell Ben how important his studies are. But one thing is certain - Ben was right: it has kept him out of trouble and he is never bored.'

'Atlantic College Last week I visited Atlantic College, a great private school in Wales. It is special because it gives young people important experiences outside the classroom, and they can also study for their exams. The students are between 16 and 18 years old and come from all over the world. In the morning, they study. In the afternoon, they do helpful activities like working on a farm, helping people with learning difficulties, or checking rivers for pollution. Atlantic College students come from many different countries and backgrounds. Not many can pay the PS20,000 fees for two years, so there are grants. A quarter of the students are British, and many of them get government help to attend. "I really admire the college for trying to help young people understand each other," said Barbara Molenkamp, a student from the Netherlands. "You learn to live with people and respect them, even if you don't like them. During the summer holidays, my mother saw that I argued less with my sister." In short, Atlantic College gives its students a great education with methods that really work.'

'Being an older student I am 32 years old and I have just finished my first year at university. I go to lectures often, and I have learned to read books quickly and write long essays. I decided to go to university after being away from school for fourteen years. I worked as a secretary and made good money, but I was bored because I did not have to think much. I felt sad because I thought I would stay in that job forever. I was jealous of the students at the local university. They looked happy and full of hope. I wanted to be like them. Now, as a student, it is hard to make friends with younger students. They often think I am a teacher and ask me questions I cannot answer. I also feel different from the teachers because, even though we are the same age, they know much more than I do. But I am happy to study because I need a qualification to get a good job, which is very important to me. Unlike most eighteen-year-olds, I like spending weekends with my books more than going to parties. I also enjoy student benefits like long holidays and discounts at the theatre and cinema. I sometimes worry about what I will do after university, but I hope going back to school was a good decision.'

'Henry Ford Henry Ford was born on a farm in Michigan in 1863, but he did not like farming. When he was fifteen, he started working as a mechanic. In 1893, he made his first car. After driving it 1,500 kilometers, he sold it and made two bigger cars. In 1903, he started the Ford Motor Company. He used strong but light steel to make cheap cars for ordinary people. In 1908, he made the first Ford Model 'T', which cost $825. He soon sold 100 cars a day. By 1927, the Ford Motor Company was worth $700 million. Early Ford cars were simple and cheap, but this sometimes meant less choice. 'You can have any color you like,' said Henry Ford of the Model T, 'as long as it's black.' '
